Ottawa, August 8, 1929.

Sir:

I have your 262/29 of the 26th ultimo, with reference to reroofing the Alberni Indian Residential School. The Department wishes you to purchase the highest grade cedar shingles from the Alberni Pacific Lumber Co., of Port Alberni. I trust that these can be secured at $4. per thousand. You should also arrange to have them hauled to the school, at an estimated cost of $36. You may also purchase, to the best advantage, the galvanized nails, flashing and gutter material, as well as the material for scaffolding, etc., as mentioned in your Estimate No. 1, which you enclosed. You may engage Mr. L. A. Pinco, of Alberni, to lay the shingles by contract. You should offer him $2.50 per thousand. You may also arrange to have the shingles dipped in linseed oil at $2 per thousand. Mr. Pinco should be offered this work as well.

The Department relies on you to arrange for this work at your earliest convenience and trusts that you will be able to keep the cost within your estimate of $1182.80.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

E. H. Frost, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Alberni,
B. C.
Subject, renewing roof covering Alberni Indian Residential School

Sir;-

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of the Department's letter of 15th instant re the above matter and beg to advise the Department that this work was recommended last year, since which time minor repairs has had to be made. Estimates were submitted in letter No. 123/28, dated May 29th, 1928.

Since receiving the Department's letter of 15th instant I have made exhaustive enquiries regarding the cost of various kinds of roofing and am submitting the estimated cost of each separately.

I respectfully beg to state that in my opinion the most suitable material for the purpose in question is the Johns Manville Asbestos Shingle, this material is more expensive but when its wearing qualities, weatherproofing and appearance as well as its fire resisting abilities are considered I am of the opinion that the extra cost is compensated for.

Estimates on separate forms are enclosed herewith,

Your obedient servant,

Ed. E. Frost

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Edward E. Frost,
Indian Agent,
Port Alberni, B.C.

Dear Sir:

We thank you for your inquiry regarding Canadian Johns-Manville Flexstone Asbestos Shingles.

Prices f.o.b. Dock Alberni, would be $10.15, per square nett.

In standard Red or Green we could fill this order out of our present stock, but if you desire any of the other colours as shown by the enclosed pamphlet it would be necessary to bring them through from Montreal which would require approximately one month from receipt of order. As the standard Red is by long odds the largest seller no you could confine your order to this colour and get practically immediate delivery.

Mr. H. D. Layfield, direct representative of the Canadian Johns-Manville Company will be in Port Alberni on Thursday or Friday of this week and will be glad to furnish any additional information you may desire.

We will be pleased to hear further from you and await your reply with interest.

Yours very truly,

LEMON, GONNASON CO., LTD.
Per, M.F. Crowe.

Dear Sir;-

Enclosed find bill of Mr.A.S.Hanna,for plumbing done at the school.

This was a case of emergent plumbing.The large hot water tank that supplies hot water to the whole school is heated by a steam pipe from the boiler,we found the steam boiler filled with water and over flowing.On examination the steam coil in the tank had broken and let the water direct from the water system into the boiler.When we opened the tank we found the steam coil had rusted out and had to be replaced by a new one with new fittings as per enclosed bill.

There was no time to ask for authority,nor could we estimate the extent of the repairs until it was done.

Sir:

I have the honour to bring to your attention the condition of the septic tank at the Alberni Indian Residential School. This tank is not functioning and needs prompt attention, as it may cause further trouble by backing up and blocking the main drain.

The tank is approximately 21 x 6 x 6 feet and is believed to be divided into 3 sections, 2 of which have man holes with covers. The center section (if the tank is in 3 sections) having no man hole; the first or intake section contains nearly 5 feet of concealed solids; the third or outlet section contains about 3 feet of solids through which it is difficult to force a measuring stick. Waste water from the school is passing through the tank without changing colour.

All the water from the laundry, baths and toilets as well as the rainfall from some portion of the roof is turned into this tank. Of the latter detail I am not certain as there is no plan showing where the down pipes lead to.

I am of the opinion that the failure of the septic tank to function properly is due to the excessive quantity of water that is passing into it. This trouble is not new but the tank has been kept in operation by occasional flushings with the fire hose while agitated, but I am afraid that remedy will not work in the present instance owing to the density of the matter now congregated.

The reason this matter is being referred to you is that it is considered inadvisable to take the time to refer the matter to Ottawa before some steps are taken to help the condition.

Your instructions are requested please as to what steps are to be taken as the cost of remedying the matter cannot be estimated except by some person who is qualified to judge the cause and remedy it.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am attaching hereto for your information copy of a letter just received from Mr. Indian Agent Frost, of Fort Alberni, with regard to the septic tank system in connection with the Alberni Indian Residential School which it is explained is not functioning properly, giving considerable trouble.

As this matter required immediate attention I have asked Mr. Webb, of the Dominion Water Purification Reclamation Branch, to have one of his staff proceed to the school without delay and make an examination of the system to see what the trouble is and if necessary to afford any immediate relief that he may deem proper and to let me know at as early date as possible as to what the cost will be to put this system in proper shape. I will then inform you by wire and request that authority be given to have the necessary work undertaken.

Apparently, the trouble seems to have been caused by allowing all the rainwater from the roofs as well as the water from the laundry and baths to go through the septic tank with that from the toilets which, I understand, is not the proper thing to do if such systems are to function properly. At the Kamloops, Lytton and Alert Bay Schools, I believe they have a separate drainage system for the carrying away of the water from the laundry, rainwater from the roof and the baths and only that coming from the toilets is allowed to enter the septic tanks. It may, therefore, be that the Engineer in his report will state a separate drainage system should be constructed at the Alberni School.

Sir:

Having received your instructions to make an examination of the septic tank at Alberni Indian school, this installation was first visited on March 31st and again on April 16th.

DESCRIPTION OF CONDITION OF TANK

On the former date the tank was found completely filled with sludge which was so compacted that it was difficult to force a pointed stake down through it to the bottom. Both the settling chamber and the syphon chamber were found to be in this condition. As it was, of course, impossible for the automatic syphon to function, all the liquid part of the sewage was flowing over the surface of the sludge and out through the emergency overflow pipe. At some time previous to my visit this pipe had been broken off and the sewage from the tank then flowed on the surface of the ground down the hillside to the lower flat.

PRELIMINARY RECOMMENDATIONS

As it was urgently necessary that steps be taken immediately to remedy the conditions described, a memorandum was given to Mr. Frost, Indian Agent, recommending that the tank be cleaned out, the sludge buried and while this was in progress that the sewage be diverted to a

C. E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
temporary cess pool. The cost of this work was estimated at $200.00. While it was realized at this time that the filter beds below the tank were quite probably blocked with solid sludge no attempt was made to ascertain their condition, it being considered that this could best be done when the flow from the tank was again diverted to these beds.

**SECOND EXAMINATION OF TANK**

Notification having been received from Mr. Frost that the tank had been cleaned out and was ready for inspection, a second visit was made on April 16th. On my first visit it had been impossible to obtain the dimensions of the two chambers of the tank and this information was now obtained. It was found that the tank had been very thoroughly cleaned out at a cost approximately as estimated and was ready to be again put in use. On examination of the system below the tank outlet it was then found that alterations to this system would be necessary as hereafter described.

**CONDITION OF FILTER BEDS**

At the time of my first visit the only information available as to the filter beds was contained in a block plan of the school and grounds on file in Mr. Frost's office. On my second visit information became available that the filter beds as originally installed on a steep side hill functioned for only about one year. At the end of this time many of the pipes had washed out and were lying on the surface of the hillside. The filter bed was then abandoned and a pipe line laid leading directly from the syphon chamber to
the Somass river without any intermediate filterage, as shown on attached plan (Appendix No. 2).

Unfortunately this pipe was laid with open joints and not to line or grade and with no manholes for cleaning purposes. On digging it up at various points it was found that it was completely blocked for at least 150 feet past the septic tank and probably is blocked for nearly its whole length and so is now useless as a tank outlet.

When this was discovered, arrangements were made to install a temporary drain from the tank to the cesspool and to put the tank again in operation. This disposal of the sewage will function satisfactorily for a few months pending the construction of a new outlet pipe to the Somass river which is hereinafter recommended.

RECOMMENDATIONS

It is recommended that a new outlet pipe be constructed leading directly from the siphon chamber of the septic tank to the Somass river as shown on plan (Appendix No. 1). Flanged vitrified pipe 6 inches in diameter should be used and should be laid with cemented joints to accurate line and grade. At two points where changes in line and grade occur manholes for cleaning purposes should be constructed. A third manhole should be constructed where the sewage inlet pipe enters the septic tank and in this manhole there should be provision for temporarily turning the flow of sewage into the cess pool during periodical tank cleanings. The cost of this construction is estimated at $903.25 as itemized in Appendix No. 1 of this report.
It is also recommended that during the next year the tank should be closely observed and the settling chamber be cleaned out when the solids on the bottom reach a depth of two feet or more. The period required for such accumulation will then be ascertained and the tank should thereafter be cleaned out at the regular interval thus determined. Ordinary good practice is to clean these tanks once a year but as this tank is smaller than the standard size, special precautions are necessary.

GENERAL OBSERVATIONS.

(a) Capacity of Septic Tank

The settling chamber has dimensions as follows: Length 12 feet, width 4.5 feet, height to overflow 4.5 feet. This gives a daily capacity of 15 gallons to each of the 125 occupants of the school as compared to a standard capacity for such installations of 40 gallons. Thus the tank is apparently much too small for the purpose it serves. However, the fact that the tank has been in use for ten years without cleaning and without giving serious trouble until the present time indicates that with proper attention it should in future function satisfactorily. The figure of 40 gallons sewage per capita daily has no doubt been obtained from observations under different conditions than those here existing and is quite probably an over estimate of the sewage from an institution such as an Indian school.
As far as I could ascertain without digging up the drains there is no roof drainage admitted to the septic tank. Laundry water, bath water and kitchen waste pass through the tank but it is probable that these wastes will be satisfactorily eliminated as there are no filter beds in connection with the disposal system.

If, however, after the system is put into operation it should be found that these wastes are causing difficulties in the operation of the septic tank separate plumbing will then have to be provided and this water disposed of in some other way, possibly in surface irrigation of the school gardens.

(b) Filter Bed Not Necessary

As originally designed and installed the effluent from the septic tank passed through a filter bed situated on a hill side to the south of the tank. While no excavations were made at this point, the soil in the vicinity of the tank and in the flats through which the present outlet pipe passes is a fairly heavy clay and quite unsuitable for filtration purposes. From the time that this filter bed was abandoned to the present time the liquid tank effluent has been discharged directly into the Somass river. As the
point of discharge is within the area of tidal influence the water in this vicinity is not used for drinking purposes. When the tank is working properly the effluent is a liquid and is unobjectionable in appearance or odor and does not create a nuisance along the banks of the river. Under these circumstances it was not considered necessary to make any alteration in the present system of disposal which has now gone on for several years without any local protest.

(c) Maintenance of System

It should be remembered by those who are in charge of the maintenance of such systems that a septic tank installation is far from an ideal system of sewage disposal and will only function properly when it is carefully watched and prompt action taken to remedy any irregularities in operation as they arise. The following are the conditions most likely to cause trouble:

1. Excessive accumulation of solids in the settling chamber.
2. Failure of operation of the automatic siphon.
3. Clogging of the filter bed system (usually caused by condition No.1).

The latter condition will not need to be watched in this case as no filter beds have been provided.

Sir:

As instructed in your letter of June 4th, 1930, I left Vancouver for Port Alberni on July 21st and commenced work on the installation of a new sewer outlet pipe for the Alberni Indian Mission School on July 22nd. From this date to August 11th this work was continuously carried on with five men employed. Owing to the necessity of furnishing transportation for the men to and from their homes in Alberni, it was impossible to employ a larger number of men without providing an extra car for use on this work.

The construction carried out followed closely that recommended in my report dated April 30, 1930, the only variation being that in place of the manhole shown on the inlet side of the septic tank, a smaller concrete diversion box was constructed. A section of wrought iron pipe 2 feet 6 inches in length carries the sewage from the school across this box and into the septic tank. When it becomes periodically necessary to clean out the septic tank this pipe will be lifted out and the sewage will then drop to the floor of the diversion box and be carried through a drain down to a cess pool. This will allow the thorough cleaning of the septic tank which, without some such provision, would be very difficult.

C. E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dom.Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
739 Hastings Street, West,
Vancouver, B.C.
Concrete manholes at stations 1 + 00 and 3 + 00 are each 5 feet in depth and 3 feet 2 inches square on the inner dimensions. The walls and base of these manholes are 6 inches in thickness. The inner and outer forms for these manholes were designed for easy removal and the same set of forms were used for both manholes and could have been used for further similar construction if such had been necessary. Photos showing these forms in place are appended hereto.

Six-inch bell end vitrified sewer tile was laid from the septic tank to the river along the lines indicated in the original report. This pipe was laid exactly to the line and grade specified and after laying, it was possible to see through the pipe from end to end between manholes. All joints were packed with jute and the collars then filled with neat cement grout. A ten-foot length of cast iron pipe was set at the Somass river outlet to prevent any chance of the drain being blocked through river erosion. The drain discharges in tidal water between low and high tide mark. It was thought advisable to discharge the pipe above low tide mark as this makes the outer end available for cleaning purposes.

After construction was completed the siphon chamber of the septic tank was flushed and as far as could be ascertained, the new drain was functioning satisfactorily.

Appended hereto is a detailed statement of the cost of this installation and also photos taken while the construction was under way.

EXTRACT from Report of Mr. G.H. Barry, Inspector of Schools for B.C., dated June 10th & 11th, 1931, regarding his inspection of the ALBERNI INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL. - Original on File 159-1-6.

DORMITORIES:

The general condition of the dormitories was satisfactory, with the exception of the JUNIOR BOYS' DORMITORY in which the beds were untidy. This room did not seem to be well ventilated. There was a distinct smell of urine. This was also particularly the case in the toilet situated in the wash room attached to the above dormitory. The Principal stated that this toilet was cleaned each morning. It was not very clean when I inspected it. There was water on the floor. There were no signs of overcrowding in the dormitories, except in the case of the JUNIOR GIRLS' DORMITORY. This room is about 30 ft. by 30 ft. with a 12 foot ceiling. There were 28 beds in this room. This gives about 36 cubic feet per child, which is hardly sufficient. There is a ventilation system throughout the school.

SANITARY CONDITIONS:

The boiler room was very untidy. Debris from wood used as fuel has been allowed to collect. There is a big pile of this in one corner of the room. I see no reason why the boys are not instructed to keep this room clean. The grates of the fire box and the bridges in the furnace are broken. These should be repaired during the vacation.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF INDIAN COMMISSIONER DITCHBURN, DATED JUNE 26, 1931, FORWARDING MR. BARRY'S REPORT ON THE ALBERNI INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL. - Original on File 159-1-11.

As regards the fire escape, your file 159-1-5 contains full information with regard to the same. It would however, do no harm and be of small expense to have Inspector Barry's suggestion carried out.

(See next Page)
FIRE PROTECTION:

There are two fire escapes. The position in which these escapes have been located is a very poor one. They are quite near together, one on each side of the entrance steps. The lowest section of each escape is the usual swinging type. This section is balanced by weights, so that in the normal position the section is raised from the ground. These swinging sections at their lowest position are six feet from the ground.

When the escapes are in use for practice drills, some member of the staff has to stand below the escape and watch the children as they jump from the lowest step of the escape. This system of escape is, in my opinion, a very bad one for use in schools. As the entire object of fire drills is to train children to escape from a building in an orderly manner, it is very necessary that the children are protected as much as possible from fear. During a fire there is of course a great danger of panic caused by fear. If children are badly frightened each time a fire drill is held, through difficulty in descending the escape, the value of such a drill is greatly decreased. These swinging sections, particularly when they do not reach in their lowest position to within a foot or so of the ground are a cause of fear to young children.

The principal of the school has promised that each time a fire drill is held there will be some one of cut hands, etc., to be treated, sometimes several cases. The children seem to hurt themselves on the escapes.

I beg to recommend that the iron rail on the front entrance side of the lowest platform of each escape be cut away, and two wooden steps be built on each side of the entrance doorway to connect the entrance veranda with the lowest platform of the escape. This will enable the children to step from the escape to the floor of the veranda in front of the main door of the school. From this the children can walk down the front steps of the school.

There is no direct exit from the senior boys' or senior girls' dormitories to the fire escapes. The nearest method of access in each case is through a bath-room and then through the wash-room to the escape. The door between the bath-room and the wash-room is kept locked to prevent the senior children going into the junior dormitories. The key of the door might well be kept in a glass-fronted box attached to the wall.

The only other method of gaining access to the escapes from the senior dormitories is through the door of the room, across a passage, through the door of the junior dormitory, and then through the wash-room to the escape.

The windows leading from the junior dormitories to the escapes are kept locked, by permission of the Department. Bars are kept under the windows in each case. The same arrangement holds good in the intermediate dormitories.

There are three fire extinguishers of the pump type, four hydrants with hose attached inside the building, and two stand pipes outside. I had the city water turned on through one of the outside stand pipes and hose. The pressure was only sufficient to send the water up to the eaves of the school. I was unable to throw water on the roof of the main building.

Fire drills are held regularly. In the drill which I supervised, the children were clear of the school from the classrooms in under one and a half minutes.

There are in addition 15 fire extinguishers located in various parts of the school building. I would suggest that some of these be tested from time to time.

Replying to your letter of the 26th ultimo, forwarding Mr. Inspector Barry's report on his inspection of the Alberni Indian Residential School, I have to inform you that we are communicating with the Principal regarding the overcrowded conditions in the junior girls' dormitory, proper ventilation and cleanliness in the junior boys' dormitory, cleaning of the debris in the boiler room and the repairs required to the grates of the fire box and bridges in the furnace.

I have to request that you will arrange to carry out the Inspector's recommendation that the iron rail on the front entrance side of the lowest platform of each escape be cut away, and two wooden steps built on each side of the entrance doorway to connect the entrance veranda with the lowest platform of the escape. This will enable the children to step from the escape to the floor of the veranda in front of the main door of the school, which the children can walk down the front steps of the school.

The Inspector also states that the access to the fire escapes from the senior boys' and senior girls' dormitories is through a bathroom and then through the washroom, and that the door between the bathroom and washroom is kept locked to prevent the senior pupils going into the junior dormitories. He recommends that the key of the door be kept in a glass fronted box attached to the wall, and I have to request that you will arrange to have a suitable box installed in which the keys could be kept.

Accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the above authorized expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Ottawa, July 9, 1931.

Rev. Sir:

Mr. Barry, Inspector of Schools for British Columbia, in a report on his inspection of the Alberni Indian Residential School, has drawn attention to the overcrowded condition in the junior girls' dormitory. He states there are 28 beds in this room, while there is only air space to accommodate 22 girls. I would, therefore, request that you arrange to reduce the number of beds in this dormitory to 22.

The Inspector also states that the junior boys' dormitory did not seem to be well ventilated, the beds were untidy and the toilet in the washroom attached to the dormitory was not properly ventilated. He also states that when he inspected this dormitory it was not very clean and there was water on the floor.

The Inspector further states that the boiler room was very untidy. Debris from wood used as fuel had been allowed to collect, there being a big pile in one corner of the room. It is also stated that the grates of the fire box and the bridges in the furnace are broken.

I have to request that you will make early arrangements for proper ventilation and cleanliness in the junior boys' dormitory and in cleaning up the debris in the boiler room.

Relative to the new grates and repairs to the bridges in the furnace, I have to request that you will arrange to have this equipment installed and the furnace placed in good condition during the present summer, the cost of same to be paid from per capita earnings or other receipts of the school.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. F. E. Pitts, B.A.,
Principal,

Dear Sirs:

In the report of Mr. Pragnall, Inspector of Indian Agencies, you will note his recommendation re some kind of refrigeration at the school.

Dr. McDonald, Veterinary Inspector of Dairies for B.C., has also inspected last week and recommended that we should have some better way of cooling milk.

In this climate we never have any ice except manufactured ice and the price is prohibitive for cooling purposes. In the winter it is about as difficult to keep meat as it is in the summer for during the rainy season it gets slimy and moulds quickly. Consequently, it is difficult to kill our own meat and to keep any quantity of it for more than a few days.

The cost of an electrically cooled Frigidaire plant, built in would be between $650.00 and $700.00. The cost of a Lord electrically cooled cabinet would be $285.00 for medium size and $375.00 for the large size.

Sir,

I have the honour to advise the Department that repairs are necessary to the Washing-Machine at the Alberni Indian Residential School.

The Reverend Principal requested me to examine the machine on the 3rd instant, which I did. The machine had been allowed to dry out during the holidays in order that the necessary repairs might be more definitely determined, and after careful examination, I am of the opinion that it can be made serviceable to last three years, probably longer, for an estimated cost of £45.00.

The agitators inside the barrel are rotted out also the section of wood near the doors in the barrel and some wood brackets used for supports inside the barrel.

The main portions or parts of the barrel or container appear fairly sound and with the renewal of the parts named, I believe, the machine can be made to operate satisfactorily for a period of at least three years.

I am sending under separate cover a portion of the wood from one of the agitators as evidence of their condition.

If the Department approves of and authorizes the expenditure stated can a reply be sent by wire as the machine is now sufficiently dried out to work on and the time remaining before it will be needed is getting short.

Sir;-

I have the honour to advise the Department that I was called to the Alberni Indian Residential School on 22nd instant to enquire into the cause of the flooding of the boiler room. I found 3 or 4 inches of water in the boiler room and that more water was coming in through the wall, which appeared to be due to the choking of the carry off drain for the buildings being stopped up. The drain was uncovered and found to be blocked in places for a distance of about 40 feet. I instructed the Rev Principal, Mr. Pitts to have the drain taken up and re-laid, the estimated cost of which will be approximately $85.00.

Rev. Sir:

The Department has received the report of Mr. Inspector Barry on his inspection of the Alberni Indian Residential School in which he draws special attention to the fire alarm system. He states that he found the fire alarm battery out of order and that new batteries were required. He recommends that large size dry cells be used rather than the present 6 volt battery.

I have to request that you will take immediate steps to have the fire alarm system placed in a good, workable condition and ready for instant use in case of fire. You should see that this system is regularly tested and kept in proper working order at all times. In this connection I have to refer you to circular letter of February 5th, last, a copy of which is enclosed herewith, setting forth the Department's requirements to overcome fire hazard. It is expected that the principals of all residential schools will follow the instructions contained in the circular referred to and give this most important matter their serious attention. I shall be pleased to hear, at an early date, the action taken in having the alarm system at your school placed in good working condition.

EXTRACT from Inspector Barry's Report regarding his visit to the ALBERNI INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL on April 26th, 1932. - Original on File 159-1-6.

It may be pointed out in passing that the provisions of the Department's letter 1-1-5 dated February 5, 1932, are not being complied with in this regard.

There is no direct exit from the senior dormitories to the fire escapes. The exit is in each case through a bath room, and then through a wash room. As recommended in my last report, boxes containing keys to the locked doors between the bathroom and the wash rooms in each case have now been provided. These boxes have glass fronts and are on the wall near the locked door on both the boys' and girls' sides of the school.

I beg to recommend the supply of 12 small mattresses and 12 large mattresses, to take the place of an equal number which are now of no further use.

I found that the fire alarm battery, a 6 Volt Battery, was out of order. A hand bell was therefore rung for the alarm. It is impossible for me to understand how the Principal of a school where lives may be in danger at any time is content to leave things in this condition. A proper supply of large size dry cells would be far better than a 6 Volt Battery. They would not be as likely to run down; but in any case the fire alarm system should be regularly tested, and kept in proper working order.

WEST COAST AGENCY INSPECTION REPORT (NO.3)

SCHOOL.

Dear Sir:-

I visited the Alberni Residential School, and thoroughly inspected same. I found everything in the buildings and outbuildings very clean and tidy. In fact, though I searched thoroughly, I have no adverse criticism to make. There were one hundred and fourteen children in the school at the time of my visit. There had been a lot of influenza, but were all getting better. As it was Saturday, the day of my visit, I did not hear the children in the classrooms. They were having meat stew, potatoes and carrots for their midday meal and bread and butter and beans for supper. I requested that the fire extinguishers be refilled. I again took up the matter of the locked window screens to the fire escapes, and after talking it over with the Principal, and at my earnest request, he promised to substitute wax seals instead, which, I understand, has been done. I don't think he will have any trouble in this connection. The jacket heater is in very poor condition. What is required there is a small tubular boiler.

The herd consists of from ten to fifteen dairy cows, with a well kept barn, and there should be plenty of milk for the children.

The manual training is being carried out, but seems to be in rather the commencement stage; possibly it will improve, but I am not sure whether the instructor is first-class. I believe it is rather hard to get a good man. I will look into this at my next visit.

Yours truly,

Sir;-

I have the honour to call the Department's attention to the attached account, Vou No 100, amounting to $46.55.

I beg to state that this expenditure was compulsory and had to be made at once.

The auxiliary heating system at the Alberni Residential School, used when the main system is not needed, has been giving trouble for the past two years. The Department has been asked to defray the cost of repairs twice and the School has paid for several minor repairs until it was decided that a replacement would be less expensive than trying to keep the defective system in service. The replacement was made last month when the system again gave out. The replacement (a drum heater with inside coils) is far cheaper than a new heater of the previous pattern. It gives greater heating surface with less cost for fuel and is easy to keep in repair.

I respectfully recommend the Department's favourable consideration of this account as I consider it a legitimate charge against the Department.

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir: re: Inspection of Boilers and Machinery,
Indian Residential School, Alberni, B.C.

On August 16th, 1933, I made an inspection of the mechanical plant of this School, which consists of,

One Horizontal return tubular high pressure boiler,
No. 43367 B.C., 66" diameter and 12' long, having 54
12" x 4" tubes, longitudinal joint double rivetted lap,
rated at 84 H.P., built in 1920, making it now 13 years old.

The Laundry consists of one large washing machine and
one 24" Hydro Extractor driven by a 5 H.P. motor, and
has a 7 H.P. Z type Fairbanks-Morse gas engine as an
auxiliary unit steam for the laundry water being
supplied by the main boiler.

Boiler No. 43367 B.C.

I gave this boiler a careful inspection, hammer and Hydro-
static test and found that the shell, stays and rivets of
the boiler in good condition. The tubes have a lot of pit
blisters and pitting on the tubes is quite intense. Some
of the pits are quite deep and in a short time several of the
tubes will need renewing.

I would recommend that before the firing season commences,
two zinc plates be installed in the boiler 4" x 6" x 1" in
size, one to be installed on the top and the other in
the bottom, screwed from the stays and placed near where the
stained water from the system enters, also the use of a solution
of Sal soda and lime water in the proportion of 1 1/2 Lb. Sal
soda to 4 gallons of clear lime water, using about 1 gallon
of the solution per month. This will help to arrest the
pitting, but I am afraid that it is gone too far in some places
to arrest it before it has eaten through the tubes. Also after
the firing season this boiler should be emptied and thoroughly
dried, opened up and a free circulation of air allowed to pass
through it.

I also found that two of the rivets of the flange on the
bottom of the boiler into which the return from the heating
system is screwed sounded loose and had been slightly leaking.
Boiler No. 43367 B.C. Continued.

Also the return pipe which together with this flange is exposed to the direct heat of the fire is getting quite thin and will need renewing. On tracing it back to the main return outside the boiler setting I found it badly corroded externally; nearly all the joints including the joint of the equalizer were corroded and showing moisture. The whole of this pipe should be renewed as soon as possible.

Owing to the construction of the setting of this boiler the fusible plug where now placed does not get the direct heat of the fire. It should be changed to the front end where it would give much better protection for the boiler.

I then gave this boiler a hydrostatic test of 50 Lb., and found all seams quite tight except the return flange which was leaking where it was riveted to the shell plates and the two rivets before mentioned were leaking quite freely. These rivets must be cut out and new ones installed and the flange recaulked.

Brickwork.

The brickwork is in a very fair condition. In the furnaces quite a number of courses have the fireclay burnt out. This should be plastered with a coat of high temperature cement 1/2" thick. There are also several small cracks in the brickwork which should be pointed up.

Generally.

The Laundry machinery is in a fairly good condition and is well guarded.

The general condition of this plant is very good. It has the appearance of being well looked after.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 10 Lb. and condition, on account of tubes, fair.

The test cocks, water gauge and main steam valve are in good condition. The steam gauge is 1 Lb. light. The safety valves work freely and are set to blow off at 10 Lb. water pressure.

The blowdown cock must be overhauled, ground in tight and made to work freely.

Approximate cost of repairs is as follows,

Renewing return pipe from boiler to main return with 3" extra heavy black pipe, including slight alterations to blowdown pipe and feed line, Fifty Dollars ($50.00). This is to include new rivets and caulking.

Generally, Continued.

Removing and repairing brickwork to allow of removal of return pipe including facing furnace and pointing up cracks, Thirty Dollars ($30.00).

Renewing fusible plug where present placed, Two Dollars and Fifty Cents ($2.50).

If altered to new position and a new steel plug installed in present position of plug, Five Dollars ($5.00).

Two zinc plates and hangers, Ten Dollars ($10.00).

Total cost approximately One Hundred Dollars ($100.00).

Yours respectfully,

Sir;-

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of the Department's letter of 25th instant calling for an explanation re purchase of fire fighting accessories for the Alberni Indian Residential School as shown in Voucher No 180, amounting to $13.60.

I beg to advise the Department that on visiting the Alberni School during May I instructed the Principal to test all his fire appliances and make good any defects found, but I failed to instruct him to report to this office what defects were found before he replaced them. When testing the apparatus it was found that 2 nozzles and some packing gaskets were defective and that 2 extra nozzles were necessary to fully complete the fire protection equipment for use, these were purchases by the Rev Principal at a cost of $10.05.

Early in June, during my absence from Port Alberni, a logging slash was fired near the school which caused burning debris to fall on the roofs of school out buildings and as these are located some considerable distance from the school proper, all fire fighting apparatus was called into use. It was then found that 2 extra reducers were needed to enable exterior and interior hose lines of different sizes to be coupled up together, and these were purchased by the Rev Principal and the purchases reported to me on my return to office.

Had the fire fighting apparatus not been in serviceable condition, most probably, the out buildings would have been damaged.

Under these conditions the purchases were made on my order to the Rev Principal, without first having obtained authority from the Department. Voucher No 180 is returned herewith for consideration.

Dear Sir:

Yours of Oct. 31st, #301/33/S1 received re repairs on steam boiler.

In reply: The Engineering Firm who estimated repairs state that it will take them at least three days to do the work and that the heating plant would be out of use for that length of time.

As the weather is now cold and damp and we have no other method of heating the school, it would be dangerous to the health of all concerned to undertake this work at present, especially as there is not likely to be any breakdown of the pipes mentioned in the repairs. The boiler is not used for any engine and seldom carries more than 2 or 3 lbs. of steam. I understood from the engineer from the Public Works Department, who made the inspection that there was no immediate necessity of making the repairs and he gave me the certificate for operation of the boiler till August 15, 1934.

I therefore request the Department to sanction the delay in these repairs until the warmer weather in the spring, unless a leak should occur that would necessitate immediate action.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF G. H. BARRY, DISTRICT INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS, VICTORIA, B. C., on his visit to ALBERNI Indian Residential School, Dec. 12, 1934. - Forwarded under cover of Asst. Commissioner Perry's letter dated January 2, 1935.

ALBERNI INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

LAUNDRY: The laundry was quite clean. There is a very great need here for some better system of drying the clothes. In my last report I suggested a small room for this. Such a room could easily be partitioned off from the present laundry in the N.W. corner of that room. Steam pipes could be run into the partitioned-off space from the boiler which is located under this part of the laundry. The cost would perhaps be in the neighbourhood of $250. As reported last year, this would provide a proper system of drying clothes. Should this be authorized, the question would arise as to who should pay for the work, and this would be a matter for the Department to decide. I have no special opinion with regard to the matter.

The laundry machinery is worked by electricity. The extractor is reported as too small for the work to be done. I consider that it will take care of the necessary work for some time to come, even if it were too small a machine when placed here. As reported previously, the school supplied a laundry stove during the past two years. This is giving satisfaction.

BOILER ROOM: This is as clean as it is possible to keep it. Water collects on the floor. This water comes in from the ground outside and at the back of the school. To drain this water may be a very difficult matter. I understand that there is a drain. It is just possible that this existing drain is not working properly, though I have no particular reason to state that this is so. The boiler room here is quite differently arranged to those in our other Indian Residential Schools. It is open to the weather to a certain extent and that may account for the water now on the floor, as may the fact that a large quantity of wet cordwood is piled up here.

Several pipes in connection with the boilers were renewed since my last inspection. This is one of the boilers inspected by Mr. T. J. Arnall.
Sir:

I have the honour to refer to my wire of above date re water supply to the Alberni Indian Residential School.

The pipe across the Somass River was carried out by the present flood, and water for fire protection, washing, heating, cooking and sanitary purposes has now to be carried by hand.

The present system was installed in August 1922, H. M. T. Hodgson was engineer in charge of the work. The approximate cost was $500.00. The distance across the Somass River was then over 300 feet. The pipe was 2 inch and was buried 2 feet at the deepest point and 6 inches at the shallowest and covered with flat boulders. The river bed, below gravel, is blue clay on north side and hardpan on south side. The depth of water at shore end of pipe on south side of river was then 4 feet at low water.

It is necessary that provision be made as soon as possible, for a temporary supply, as permanent repairs may not be possible until about midsummer, unless a stretch of cold weather occurs before that time, to stop water from back in the hills, where there is a considerable depth of snow.

Can a copy of the blue print of this school be supplied to this office, showing drainage and sanitary systems? It is often needed for reference, and there is not one available either in this office or at the school.

Your obedient servant,

Ed. E. Frost,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

In compliance with your request, I made an examination of the pipeline supplying the Alberni Indian School, on the 7th instant, which had been reported broken by Assistant Indian Commissioner Perry on the 5th instant and who had requested an examination. The following is a report of my investigation.

In company with Mr. Indian Agent Frost, I visited the school and interviewed the principal. An examination of the pipeline was made but I was unable to locate the point where the break occurred in the river bed. The Somass river is still very high after an abnormal flood and it would be difficult, if not impossible, to repair the break at the present time. The pipeline is reported to be buried a depth of 1.5 feet below the bed of the river which has an extreme depth at low water period of about four feet. The maximum depth of water at present would probably be from 12 to 15 feet with a velocity of 5 to 6 feet per second.

I am informed by local authorities that the river level may not materially lower before August or September.

I am unable to determine the exact cause of the break but it is possible that a large tree with roots attached carried down by the flood, came in contact with the pipe at some point where the

C.E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dom. Water Power & Hydrom. Bureau,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
cover was slight. As it is reported that the break occurred after the river level had fallen three or four feet my surmise is probably correct.

At the present time water is being supplied to the school by means of barrels hauled by team from Indian wells nearby and the river, requiring such service throughout the day. Requirements prior to the break were approximately 7500 gallons a day.

It is unlikely that the river level will drop sufficiently to permit of permanent replacement before the early fall. I would therefore suggest that a temporary service may be provided by holding a pipeline in the bed of the stream by means of a cable. It would be necessary to install the pipe in short lengths with rubber connections so as to be flexible and with sufficient weight to hold it close to the bottom. The cost of such installation would be approximately $375.00. The major portion of the material to be used temporarily could be salvaged for future use.

Regarding the construction of a permanent installation to replace that washed out, I would suggest that as the present pipe has been in place approximately 13 years it would be desirable to replace it with new pipe and to bury it to a depth of from 2½ to 3 feet, if possible. The cost of the permanent replacement would be about $750.00.

I should point out that the present pipe line when in use provided a service of only about 50 gallons per minute at 30 lbs. pressure for fire protection, whereas a 4-inch pipe line to the school
would provide a fire service of 100 gallons per minute at 45-lbs. pressure. While neither service is adequate for fire protection purpose it is the best which may be provided under existing conditions.

It is possible that the city of Alberni may in the near future find it necessary to renew the existing pipe from which the school receives its supply and it is probable that the city would, if requested, replace with 6" pipe in order to provide a desirable service to its best customer.

Such an installation would supply the school with a service of 225 gallons per minute at about 40-lbs. pressure. Considering future possibilities and the better fire service to be secured it would be desirable when permanent replacement is to be undertaken, to install a 4-inch pipe across the river and to the school distribution system, a total distance of about 950 feet, the total cost of which would be $1250. without allowance for materials salvaged from the present line.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to the Department's letter of January 10th, re the leak or seepage into the boiler room at the Alberni Indian Residential School, and note its contents.

I have to advise the Department that the seepage is through the wall of the building, which is composed of rough stone, concrete and bricks, and as the floor of the boiler room is about 8 feet below the outer ground surface and the existing drains, believed to be about the floor level, there is 8 feet of soil outside the boiler room walls through which it is believed this seepage occurs. Some change in the surface drains were made about 2 years ago, to take care of this seepage, but it is still occurring.

When the Dominion Public Works Engineer of the Waterworks Department was at Alberni School (Mr. Warren) on the 7th instant the matter was referred to him for suggestions for overcoming the trouble. He advised that a new system of surface drainage be installed to take care of surface and roof water, but could not give an estimate of the cost that would be thus incurred.

I will endeavor to obtain further data from the Department Engineers when they come to Alberni to repair the water system, and the Department will be further advised. A blue print of this school is necessary to be able to trace the present drainage system.

Sir:-

I have the honour to enclose herewith, a copy, of a letter, received in this office from the Reverend Principal of the Alberni Indian Residential School.

The letter, dealing with the water supply to that school is self explanatory.

Further dealing with the pressure, I have seen the hoses turned on and the water has not reached the roof (eaves) by approximately fifteen feet. As this school is situated near a standing forest and in event of a fire catching in the trees, it would be impossible to wet the roof of the building, except by buckets.

It is the opinion of this office that the pipe line should be enlarged and a storage tank installed with a pump for fire fighting purposes. The pump could be used both for filling the storage tank and for fire fighting. Approximate figures for this work will be obtained and submitted for the information of the Department at a later date.

If further work is to be done, this season, it would have to commence soon as with the fall rains the river would be too high for work in laying new pipe.

Dear Sir:

I beg to call your attention to the fact that when our water supply pipe for the Residential School was replaced last March after being torn out by the flood it was understood that the repairs were temporary owing to the high water and swift current.

The repairs consisted of about 300 ft. of 2" pipe—the pipe lengths being connected by rubber hose and wired to a cable laid on the surface of the river bed.

We get our water supply from the City of Alberni and pay by the cubic foot with the meter on the far side of the river. Twice since March these hose connections have slipped and caused a heavy leakage. So much so that the City generously discarded the meter and jumped the account.

It is now/time of low water and/work is to be done in the river it should be done soon.

I greatly fear that the present pipe will not stand the winter rains and consequent swift current. In this connection I wish also to call your attention to the fact that the school stands fully 75 ft. above the bed of the river. The building is about 50 ft. high. With a 2" pipe we do not get pressure enough to put water on the roof of the building.

Engineers Warren of Vancouver and Arnall of Victoria and Inspector Barry have reported the fire protection to be inadequate.

Would it be possible to have the Department look into this matter before permanently fixing the water supply pipe?

Yours sincerely,

"F. E. Pitts".

Sir:

I have the honor to refer to Departmental telegram dated March 7th, last, in which I was advised that the Dominion Water Power Branch was authorized to make temporary repairs to the water supply system serving the Alberni Indian Residential School, West Coast Agency, B.C. In this connection I beg to advise that Mr. Acting Agent Nightingale has furnished me with copy of his letter dated August 21st addressed to the Department, with which was enclosed copy of a letter dated August 19th received by him from Reverend Francis Pitts concerning the inadequacy of the temporary work which has been installed, more particularly as to the fire fighting purposes. I now beg to transmit copy of letter received from Mr. Nightingale dated August 21st, also copy of my reply dated August 24th.

These letters will be self-explanatory, except that it should be pointed out that the report of the Dominion Water Power Branch dated February 8th, 1935, makes no provision for or reference to a storage tank in connection with the proposed installation. This is, I believe, an idea of Mr. Nightingale's, and it is understood that the elevation of the school buildings is not such as to ensure sufficient pressure for fire fighting purposes to be obtained from the City of Alberni's water system, the elevation of which is undoubtedly to be not higher than the second storey of the residential School, and a suitable storage tank or other installation would have to be made in order to obtain fire protection for the entire institution. It would seem desirable that the Dominion Water Power Branch should be requested to consult also with the authorities of the City of Alberni as suggested in the report of Mr. W.C. Warren of February 9, 1935, so whatever work is authorized should be carried out with a view to the greatest possible efficiency as well as economy. In the letter of Mr. C.E. Webb, District Chief Engineer to his Director at Ottawa covering Mr. Warren's report he stated that if the Department wished he would be pleased to take up with the city of Alberni the question of the extension of their largest service main as far as the Indian service pipe. No information has been received as to this office as to the Department's intentions in this connection. In the meantime I felt it was safe to instruct Mr. Nightingale to confer with the Principal and the City authorities at Alberni in a preliminary way as the issue seems to be one of considerable importance as affecting the interests of the school.

Sir:

In accordance with instructions received from you on October 30th, I proceeded to Alberni on October 31, 1935, for the purpose of carrying out certain repairs to the Alberni Indian School water supply system as recommended by Mr. W.G.Warren in a report by him regarding this subject dated February 9, 1935, and in this connection would report to you as follows:

WORK CARRIED OUT

Repairs to the above water supply system consisted of the installation of 610 lineal feet of 4" diameter wood stave pipe and 340 lineal feet of 4" diameter galvanized wrot steel pipe across the Somass river to replace the old 2" diameter galvanized wrot iron water pipe formerly used, as follows:

1. The installation of 4" diameter wood stave pipe from a point on the Alberni-Central Lake highway near where the old 2" diameter school water pipe connects with the City of Alberni's 4" diameter water main, west for a distance of 110 feet to the east bank of the Somass river.

2. The installation of 340 lineal-feet of 4" diameter galvanized wrot steel pipe beneath the bed of the Somass river from a point on the east bank of the river to a point on the west bank.

3. The installation of 4" diameter wood stave

C.E.Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
Department of the Interior,
OTTAWA, ONT.
pipe from a point on the west bank of the Somass river west for a distance of 500 lineal-feet to connect with the school 2" diameter water main immediately outside the school buildings.

All of the above wood stave pipe was laid at a depth of three feet beneath the surface of the ground while the 4" diameter wrot steel pipe which extends across the Somass river was laid at a depth varying from three feet to five feet below the bed of the stream.

METHODS OF WORK AND MEN EMPLOYED

The excavation for and the installation of all wood stave pipe on this project was carried out by hand, local Indians being employed exclusively for this kind of labour. The excavation for and the installation of the 4" diameter wrot steel pipe beneath the bed of the Somass river was carried out by means of a gasoline driven donkey engine operating a 1/2 cubic yard capacity crescent bucket, and when the excavation for the above pipe line was finally completed the assembled pipe was pulled into place by the donkey engine from the east bank of the river. White operators were employed for the operation of the donkey engine, the local Indians being unable to supply experienced men for this type of work.

TESTING OF PIPE

Upon completion of the above work all 4" diameter wrot steel pipe laid beneath the bed of the Somass river was tested by air to a pressure of 125 lbs. per square inch, when all joints in same, which are of the Vitaulic type, were found
to be tight and in good order. This test pressure of 125 lbs. per square inch is 30 lbs. per square inch in excess of which the line will normally have to sustain, the normal working pressure in the line being 95 lbs. per square inch.

WAGES PAID

Standard wages were paid for all types of labour engaged on the above project, both to the Indians and white men employed, as follows:

| Labourers | 40 cents per hour |
| Donkey operator | 67½ " " |
| Riggers | 85 " " |

TIME OCCUPIED

Work on the above project, which was rendered somewhat difficult owing to weather conditions and the prevailing high tides, occupied a period of 19 days, commencing on November 4th and being finally completed on November 23, 1935.

CONNECTION TO CITY OF ALBERNI WATER MAIN

Upon completion of the above installation the new 4" diameter pipe was connected by the City of Alberni to their 4" diameter water main at the same point as the old 2" diameter pipe and a new 4" water meter was installed in the line by the City of Alberni immediately east of the Alberni-Central Lake Highway to replace the old 2" diameter meter formerly used.

COST

The cost of the above project, including the purchase of all material and installation of same, amounted to $1,427.46 against an estimated cost of $1430.00.
SALVAGE OF OLD 2" DIAMETER PIPE LINE

Upon completion of the installation of the new pipe line, the old pipe line across the Somass river consisting of 320 lineal feet of 2" diameter wrought iron pipe, together with 16 Brass hose type couplings, which is in a comparatively good state of repair, was salvaged from the river and is now stored at the Alberni Indian School ready for future use or for sale according to the instructions of the Department of Indian Affairs.

REMARKS

The above installation, when finally completed and inspected by me, was in good order and operating satisfactorily and should, in my opinion, continue to supply the Alberni Indian School with water for domestic purposes without any further trouble.

Your obedient servant,

E.H.Tredcroft

Sir:

In accordance with instructions received from you, I carried out an investigation having reference to improvements necessary to the fire protection system at the Alberni Indian School near Alberni, B.C., and in this regard would report to you as follows:

ALBERNI INDIAN SCHOOL

The Alberni Indian School which has accommodation for 125 children is a four-storey wooden structure, 52 feet in height, 100 feet in length by approximately 75 feet in depth. It has a net value of approximately $80,000 and is situated on the west bank of the Somass river, 3½ miles northwest of the City of Alberni, B.C.

PRESENT WATER SUPPLY

The Alberni Indian School obtains its water at the present time, for both domestic and fire protection purposes, from the 4" diameter City of Alberni water main which extends along the east side of the Alberni-Central Lake highway approximately 1,000 feet east of the Alberni Indian School, water being carried from this main by means of a 4" diameter wood-stave and steel pipe line recently installed by the Department of Indian Affairs, across the Somass river for a distance.

C.H. Webb, Esq., C.E.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dom. Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
of 950 lineal feet to connect with the school buildings on the opposite side of the river (see accompanying plan).

WATER PRESSURE

The static pressure in the City of Alberni's water main at the point where the Department of Indian Affairs 4" diameter pipe connects with same, is 95 pounds per square inch and the static pressure in the fire hydrants immediately in front of the school buildings, which are at an elevation of 38 feet above the City of Alberni's water main, is 78 pounds per square inch.

EXISTING OUTSIDE FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM

The Alberni Indian School is protected from fire at the present time by four 2" diameter stand-pipes connected to the old 2" diameter water main which surrounds the school building. This old 2" diameter water main has now been connected to the new 4" diameter water pipe recently installed across the Somass river and which, as previously stated, connects with the City of Alberni's 4" diameter water main situated on the opposite side of the river.

AMOUNT OF WATER AVAILABLE AT THE PRESENT TIME IN CASE OF FIRE

Owing to the restricted size of the City of Alberni's water main (4" diameter) the total amount of water which it would be possible to obtain at the Alberni Indian School in the event of fire would be approximately 100 U.S. gallons per minute at a working pressure of 30 lbs. per square inch and while this amount of water would be of help in extinguishing a small blaze.
it would be practically useless in the event of any serious outbreak of fire.

In addition to the above the old 2" diameter water main which surrounds the school building and to which two of the present standpipes are connected, is now so badly corroded in the inside that at certain places its effective internal diameter is not more than one-half its original size i.e. 1" diameter in place of 2" diameter, and the standpipe heads or valves, which are of an old type, are themselves in a poor state of repair. Out of four standpipes available for use, only three are actually equipped with standpipe heads and of these three standpipe heads, only two of same are equipped with 2" to 1½" reducers which are necessary to enable the 1½" diameter fire hose supplied to this school to be connected to them in the event of fire.

EXISTING INSIDE FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM

In so far as inside fire protection at the Alberni Indian School is concerned, except for the small amount of water at present available (100 U.S.G.F.M.) the installation is quite satisfactory. The building is well piped on the inside for fire protection purposes, with sufficient outlets on each floor to ensure a proper degree of safety in the event of fire. Moreover each outlet is properly equipped with a hose and nozzle attached to the outlet and stored on racks nearby, ready for instant use.
The building is also provided with an adequate number of chemical fire extinguishers for use in case of an emergency.

AMOUNT OF WATER NECESSARY FOR FIRE PROTECTION

The minimum amount of water necessary to safely take care of any serious outbreak of fire which may occur at the Alberni Indian School, is 500 U.S. G.P.M., i.e., two standard fire streams of 240 U.S. G.P.M. delivering water through 1-1/8" diameter nozzles and with water delivered in the main at a pressure of 60 lbs. per square inch when two hydrants are operating simultaneously.

In order to supply the above amount of water it will be necessary to increase the capacity of the present school water system very materially and owing to the fact that the City of Alberni's water system is of limited capacity, together with the fact that the City is in no way considering the renewal or enlargement of their existing 4" diameter water main along the Alberni-Central Lake highway, no improvement to the present supply can be expected from this source. For this reason, if any improvements are to be carried out it will be necessary to obtain water from the only other available supply, which is by pumping from the Somass river nearby.

PROPOSED FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM

In view of the above consideration and in view of the fact that the present supply of water (100 U.S. G.P.M.) is entirely inadequate for
fire protection purposes at the above institution,
I would hereby recommend that a complete new system
of fire protection be installed, water being obtained
from the Somass river by means of a gasoline oper-
ated fire pump and motor, delivering water to the
school fire mains through a separate system of
delivery pipes as outlined below and which would
require:

1. The installation of 1 - 500 U.S. G.P.M. Centrif-
ugal pump operated by 1 50-60 H.P. gasoline engine
situated on the west bank of the Somass river and
housed in a wooden pump house having concrete floor
and foundations and which would obtain water from
a concrete intake well connected to the Somass river
by means of a 14" diameter Vitrifical supply pipe.

2. The installation of 480 lineal feet of 6" diam-
eter wood stave delivery pipe to deliver water
from the proposed fire pump at the edge of the Somass
river to the school fire mains immediately surround-
ing the school buildings.

3. The installation of 200 lineal feet of 5" dia-
meter and 270 lineal feet of 4" diameter wood stave
fire main which would surround the school buildings
on three sides and to which the hydrants would be
connected (see accompanying plan).

4. The installation of four standard 2½" diameter
fire hydrants situated so that one hydrant would
be placed at approximately each corner of the school
buildings and at a distance of not less than 50 feet
from the nearest wall, these hydrants to be so
arranged that a fire in any part of the building
can be immediately covered by two standard fire
streams, two of these hydrants should be of the stand-
ard monitor type (i.e. having a swivel nozzle attached
permanently to the hydrant standard and operating from the hydrant without the use of fire hose) while the other two hydrants should be of the standard fire hose type each equipped with 150 lineal feet of 2½" diameter rubber lined fire hose. All four hydrants should be equipped with standard 1-1/8" diameter smooth nozzles.

The above fire hydrants should be placed around the school buildings alternately so that each side of the building can be covered if necessary by one monitor type and one standard fire hose type hydrant.

The use of monitor type hydrants as described above will allow a fire stream to be played upon any portion of the outside of the school buildings immediately a fire is discovered without the necessity of running out any fire hose, which in itself is of great advantage at an institution such as the above where it may be expected that a minimum of trained help will be available for work of that kind.

In addition to the above I would point out that whereas the proposed new fire pump is intended to supply water to the outside fire mains, while the existing 4" diameter pipe connected to the City of Alberni water main will continue to supply water to the inside fire hydrants, I would recommend that a connection between the two systems be made so that the outside fire mains may be kept full of water from the city main for immediate use in the event of fire until such time as the fire pumps can be started, and that a check valve be placed in this connection so that water from the fire pump cannot
pass from the outside fire main into the inside fire main with a subsequent possible contamination of the domestic supply.

COST

The cost of the proposed fire protection system including the purchase of both pump and motor, the construction of the pump house and well, the installation of all delivery pipe, fire mains etc. together with the installation of all hydrants, fire-hose, fire-hose houses, fittings etc. will amount to $3,600.00.

REMARKS

In view of conditions outlined in the above report and the fact that the Alberni Indian School, which houses approximately 120 children, is without an adequate supply of water at the present time for fire protection purposes, I would hereby recommend that the above proposed fire protection system be installed and that in order to ensure its proper maintenance and operation frequent fire-drills with this pump be carried out until such time as the personnel who will be required to operate same in the event of fire are thoroughly familiar with its use. In addition to the above I would recommend that all equipment relating to fire protection at the above institution be periodically inspected and tested by a responsible officer of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Your obedient servant,

E.H. Tredcroft

Sir,

With reference to my two letters of December 30th and January 4th regarding the work done by Mr. Tredcroft in supervising the repairs made to the water supply at Alberni Indian Residential School, I enclose herewith copy of a letter dated the 20th instant from Mr. Webb explaining the situation in regard to this matter.

From this letter it appears that the advance of $1,450.00 sent to Mr. Webb to cover this construction work was not sufficient to include Mr. Tredcroft's salary and that the amount of salary due Mr. Tredcroft amounts to $178.83 after allowing what has already been paid to him out of the balance of the advance of $1,450.00 and the amount taken from Indian General Funds. Mr. Webb gives a full explanation of the difficulties encountered in connection with this work and of the extra work included in preparing the report on fire protection and suggests two ways in which the salary payment might be adjusted. I should be glad to have your instructions in regard to this matter.

Enclosure.

January 20, 1936.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 15th instant with reference to the non-payment of Mr. Tredcroft's time during the month of November last, amounting to $145.23, it has not been our practice to include engineer's salaries in estimates of cost prepared for the Department of Indian Affairs, it being generally assumed that the engineer's salary will be paid from the general appropriation. It is only when an additional engineer is required such as in the case of Mr. Tredcroft, that this particular question may arise.

Your letter of August 15th, your file 2543A, quoting a letter from the Department of Indian Affairs authorizing Mr. Tredcroft's employment on the Nanaimo No. 185 Laying project, intimated that his salary was not to be paid from the appropriation but when his employment was subsequently continued for the Alberni job we took it the same contention would exist i.e., his salary would be paid from Ottawa and not from the appropriation of $1430.00 received here. In any event the work was carried out as expeditiously as possible and in a satisfactory manner and it is fortunate it was undertaken when it was as heavy rains occurred when the work was nearly finished and the Sushwap river rose considerably which would have caused considerable trouble had the work not been advanced as far as it was. As you know this work was rather precarious and called for the laying of a pipeline in the bed of the Sushwap river. Our estimate of cost was based on the assumption that the work would be done during the extremely low water stage. When the authorization for the work came this stage had passed for 1935. While the water level was not high it was considerably above its lowest stage prolonging the time required for the installation. Some years low water extends into November but this year such was not the case.

While installing the pipeline for the domestic water supply system to the school, at the request of the Indian Department officials I had Mr. Tredcroft make an investigation into the possibilities of improving the fire fighting facilities at the school which have been reported as unsatisfactory. This report, together with the report

J.T. Johnston, Esq.C.E.,
Director,
Dom. Water Power & Hydrom.Bureau,
OTTAWA.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6433, File 877-5, part 4)
on the completion of the domestic water supply improvements, has been forwarded to Ottawa for consideration. The preparation of this report naturally took several days.

The situation in respect to this matter is at present as follows:

Under £R.355 the sum of £1430. was received all of which has been expended. Tredcroft worked 33 days, one day in October, thirty days in November and two days in December. His time for the one day in October and twenty-nine days in November was sent, as customary, to Ottawa for payment, all other expenditures being charged against £R.3855. The total cost of the work exclusive of Tredcroft's salary amounted to £1427.46. With authorization to pay Tredcroft for the two additional days which he worked over the 30 days, was received, he was paid by cheque here, £2.54 being charged to £R.3855 closing out the account and the balance £12.57 taken from Indian General funds.

Tredcroft was paid by Departmental cheque No.27848 received with your letter of November 29th last, for one day's work in October on this job. He therefore had owing to him payment for 29 days in November, the sum of £178.83 which paylist was sent to you under date of December 4th (note: this paylist was in error reading £178.54 instead of the correct figure £178.83).

It was only when your letter of December 31st arrived enclosing only MacNaughton's cheque that we realized there might be some misunderstanding in regard to Tredcroft's salary payment.

So far as I can see there are two ways in which this salary payment might be adjusted.

1. In view of the fact that the improvements were carried out under unfavourable weather conditions and not during the period of lowest water in the Somass river, the expenditures were naturally greater and also in view of the fact that an investigation was, in addition made of the possible improvements to the fire fighting apparatus at the school and report prepared, the appropriation of £1430. should be increased by an amount of £178.83 in order that all payments under this heading may be met.

2. Our Indian General Fund has been set up to cover the cost of incidental investigations and emergency minor repairs. It was essential that this work be undertaken when it was, had it been necessary to delay its commencement awaiting authorization for Mr. Tredcroft's employment it could only have been carried out at an extremely high cost and possibly not at all until lower water conditions obtained next year. In the meantime the Indian school might have been without water had a break occurred in the temporary pipeline laid on the bed of the stream.
In view of these extraordinary circumstances it would appear there is ample justification to pay for this additional cost charge of $178.83 from the Indian General fund and if approved I will issue a cheque to Tredcroft from this fund.

I would ask you to bear in mind that no engineer's salary is included in any of our reports unless so specified.

Your obedient servant,

C.E. Webb
District Chief Engineer

February 28, 1936.

Sir:

I regret to inform you that since the Alberni School account was reported closed, another bill has come in from the B.C. Electric Railway Co., Victoria, dated January 29, 1936, for moving guy rope and installing transformers $20.97. Upon investigation I find that there is also an account outstanding with the Alberni Machine Shops for machinist work. This account has not been presented, although I have written for it. The amount is estimated at between $10.00 and $15.00.

Also, owing to an omission in posting from the Cash Book to the Ledger, a credit of $4.92 did not appear in the latter. In consequence when I reported a balance of $2.54 on hand and suggested paying Mr. Tredcroft for these extra days' service, from General Surveys funds, the balance in the Alberni Account should have been $24.46.

Then this correction was made the whole of Mr. Tredcroft's 3 days salary $18.11, was charged to Alberni School, which leaves a balance of $6.35 at credit of that account.

It still have to provide for the items mentioned in the first paragraph above amounting approximately $45.00.

The concluding paragraph of the Indian Affairs letter to you dated December 30, 1935, "W'A", reads:

"Work at the Alberni Indian Residential School being made from the Appropriation for Education and, consequently, the advance forwarded to Mr. Tredcroft distinctly show that the advance paid from Indian Affairs in order that we may make the adjustment in our books."

This would seem to indicate a certain degree of care in the Indian Department's accounts and wondering if, under the circumstances, the balance of those accounts (B.C. Electric and Machine Shop) not providable from the School account, could be...

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, in which you state that you consider it undesirable to use the present store room at the Alberni Indian Residential School as a dormitory. It is, also, noted that there has been a re-arrangement of the girls' dormitory which permits proper air space for each pupil. Under these circumstances, no further action need be taken regarding Inspector Barry's suggestion.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Fort Alberni, B. C.

PP/O'M.
Sir:

I have the honour to refer to your letter of April 8, 1936 re inspection of the Alberni Indian Residential School and to report that it would not be possible to use the present store room as a dormitory without making considerable structural alterations.

A re arrangement of the girl's dormitory has been suggested to the Reverend Principal and acted upon since receipt of your letter which will allow a cubic air space of 550 cubic feet per pupil.

This relieves the overcrowding and it is respectfully submitted that except in case of a material increase in number of girl pupils the expense of alteration to the building would not be warranted.

Your obedient servant,

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.
