Dear Sir:

The following is an extract from Inspector Barry's report regarding his visit to the Alberni Indian Residential School on the 20th ultimo:

"One of the girls' dormitories, that towards the front of the school building, was rather crowded. I hesitate to state that it was overcrowded. The Principal tells me that the windows are kept open. On the whole I think that a room now used as a store room, but which was once used as a dormitory, should be again used as such on the girls' side of the school. The corresponding room on the boys' side is so used as a dormitory for the small boys. This prevents overcrowding on their side of the school. I have, therefore, to recommend that the Indian Agent be asked for a report on the suggested overcrowding of the girls' dormitories and the possibility of again making use of the room above the dormitory on the girls' side as a dormitory without any structural alteration whatever."

The Department would appreciate your visiting the school and discussing the above matter with the Principal. You should then notify us if it is considered advisable to carry out Mr. Barry's suggestions.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

P. B. Ashbridge, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Alberni, B.C.

Ottawa, June 5, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department has received a communication from the Principal of the Alberni Indian Residential School, requesting authority to incur the expenditure required in painting the shingled roof of the school building and carrying out painting and other repairs.

In this connection I have to inform you that the following amounts have been provided in our Appropriation for the current fiscal year:

1. Painting roof, main building - $200.
2. Miscellaneous repairs and painting - $300.

I would request that you will advise the Department how it is proposed to have the work carried out. Would it be satisfactory for you to arrange for the purchase of the paint and materials required and have the work done by day labour? You should state, also, what part, if any, of the painting, etc., could be carried out by the staff of the school and if it would be satisfactory to employ Indian labour for any work that the school staff is unable to perform. It might be more satisfactory to employ a competent foreman-painter, or it is possible that the Principal could oversee the work. In any event, the Department could not authorize any expense in excess of the amounts stated above. When we have full particulars, as requested, you will be further advised. The Principal is being informed that this matter has been referred to you for a report.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Sir:

I have the honour to submit my report on the fire at the Alberni Residential School, which destroyed this building on February 21st, 1937:

Discovery of Fire.

The fire, which apparently started in the storeroom above the girl's dormitory, was first discovered by Miss Audrey Mills, teacher who was at that time in the girl's dormitory.

She reports hearing a roar, and on investigation saw smoke coming from the upper landing.

Miss Mills immediately rang in the alarm from the fire station, and went in search of the Principal.

Immediate Action.

Mr. Pitts states that he ran upstairs, and saw smoke issuing from under the locked door of the store room. He opened the door and found the smoke too dense to enter. He looked the door again, and went down for a chemical extinguisher, but was unable to do much good.

Fighting of Fire.

The Alberni Fire Department were notified, and responded, arriving about 20 minutes after the fire started.

The fire engine of the Alberni Pacific Lumber Company also arrived to assist, but were unable to do much good, owing to trouble with their engines.

Progress of Fire.

The fire was very soon out of control, chiefly owing to lack of water pressure. The supply for this purpose is drawn from the Alberni City reservoir, and supplied to the school by gravity flow.

By 10:30 A.M. the school was completely destroyed.

Evacuation of Building.

The Reverend Principal does not appear to have a very clear recollection as to how the children left the building, but, from what I can learn from the teachers, they simply walked out.

The girls each brought a blanket with them, and were subsequently taken care of by Mrs. Sainsbury.

The older boys assisted in removing furniture, etc., from the building, and dispersed to various parts of the nearby reserves.

- Notification
Notification of Fire.

I was notified of the fire at 12 noon, by a constable of the B.C. Provincial Police, and immediately proceeded to the scene.

I was not notified in any way by the Reverend Principal or by any member of his staff, although I have phones in both office and residence.

Action of Agent.

On arrival at scene of fire, I endeavoured to locate the children, and to care for any without shelter.

All the children were housed by 5 p.m. The following morning, the greater majority of those not resident in Alberni were sent home in care of their parents, or relatives.

Owing to fire occurring on Sunday, it was not possible to communicate with the Department by telegraph, but I phoned to Victoria and informed Mr. C. C. Perry, Assistant Commissioner, of the matter.

Fire Loss.

The main building of the school is completely destroyed, only the stone foundation being left.

The large chimney, which was still standing, was leaning at a dangerous angle, and this I had dropped, as it was a menace.

Practically all of the school equipment was destroyed, as was most of the clothing of both staff and children.

Salvage.

Some furniture was saved from the lower floor, chiefly property of Mr. Pitts, piano, sewing machines, desks, and bookcases, etc.

Remaining Buildings.

Buildings not damaged by fire were:

The large barn containing 33 head of cattle,
Agricultural Instructor's cottage,
Primary Classroom,
Small Cottage,
Old Barn,
Garage,
Wood Shed,
Implement Shed.

Investigation.

Capt. G. H. Barry, Inspector of Schools, arrived on Monday evening, February 22nd, and rendered valuable service in investigation of matters.

- Accompanied
Accompanied by myself, he visited the site of the school, and questioned members of the staff, as to the cause of the fire.

The answers were given very unsatisfactorily and contradictory, except those given by teachers, Miss Hows and Miss Mills, dealing with the discovery of the fire and alarm.

As to the cause, I have no reason to believe it was other than accidental, possibly from overheated chimney. Evasive answers were given by the kitchen staff as to the probable cause, but it was found that a pan of grease took fire in the oven about 7:45 A.M., the time of the fire.

Care of Children.

All school children, except those of the Cowichan Agency, have been sent to their homes, and these will be leaving on February 23rd.

Arrangements are being made to send some neglected and orphan children to Ahousaht School. These will be taken on the Department Launch. To date, no expense has been incurred in connection with the evacuation of the school children.

Care of Remaining Buildings and Stock.

The Reverend Principal and staff are remaining at the school, until final arrangements can be made, and will care for the stock, which consists of 33 head of cattle, together with the buildings before mentioned, and, of course, the farm.

General.

In the foregoing report, I have endeavoured to cover the subject as thoroughly as circumstances permit at this time.

Mr. Inspector Barry is forwarding his own report, with his views as to the cause of the fire, and with which I thoroughly agree.

Respectfully submitted,

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

P.B.A./A.M.

Sir:

I have the honour to report that the recreation hall at the Alberni Residential School collapsed during a wind storm on February 15th.

This building was 78 x 36, of frame construction on concrete foundations. Luckily it was not occupied, and no one was injured.

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Minister,

A telegram has just been received from Mr. J. B. Ashbridge, Indian Agent, Port Alberni, B.C., stating that the Alberni Indian Residential School was totally destroyed by fire. There were no casualties.

The Alberni Indian Residential School, conducted under the auspices of the United Church of Canada, is situated about two miles from the town of Alberni, B.C., Electoral District of Comox-Alberni. It was a frame building, erected by this Department in 1920, at a cost of approximately $75,000.

I am instructing the Indian Agent, by wire, to return to their homes those children whose parents are able to support them, as no other provision can be made for them at the present time. There is accommodation for about fifteen (15) or twenty (20) children in the Ahousaht Indian Residential School and the Indian Agent is being authorized to place in that school those pupils whose parents are dead or whose home conditions are unsuitable for their return.

Condition of Fire Escapes and Fire Fighting Appliances at Alberni Residential School October 26, 1936.

Fire Escapes. There are two fire escapes in the front of building, of iron construction, to which the children have access from all dormitories through the wash rooms. Wash rooms have concrete floors, and windows leading to escapes are kept on latch easily opened. Escapes are kept in good order. School was emptied under two minutes at inspection.

Pyrenes and Axes. There are 3 five gallon, and 6 small pyrenes placed at various parts of the building, also fire axes on each floor.

Fire Alarm. Large gong, electrically operated from box on each floor. In good working order, and sufficiently loud to arouse the whole school.

Stand Pipes and Hose. Stand pipe extends through the centre of the building, and hose connections with hose attached on each floor. There is also a hydrant outside of the building, with hose attached.

Water Pressure. The water pressure is about 80 lbs., and sufficient to throw a stream over the roof. Water is supplied from the City reservoir, by gravity. Due to small storage capacity, the pressure could not be relied upon for any great length of time.

Fire Drill. The children are well disciplined, and understand their stations in case of fire. The staff also have their appointed stations, and drills are well conducted.

General. This school is well equipped to meet emergencies, and fire escapes are placed in that part of the building least likely to suffer from fire. Pyrenes, hose, axes, and axes are placed at advantageous spots, and the staff and children educated in their use. With the addition of the watchman, it is considered that present facilities are sufficient and the school well protected. No further expenditure is recommended in fire appliances for this school. This opinion is also shared by the Reverend Principal.

Respectfully submitted,

Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I have to refer to my memorandum dated July 24th, last, requesting to be advised the name of the firm from whom to purchase paint, and also the foreman to be employed in the painting of the roof of the main building and other miscellaneous repairs and painting, at the Indian Residential School, Port Alberni, B.C. (Electoral District of Comox-Alberni).

You instructed that the paint be purchased from John Thomson, Alberni, B.C., and that Alexander J. Thomas, Fort Alberni, be employed as painter. The local Indian Agent was advised accordingly.

The accounts covering the cost of this work have been received. A certain portion of the paint was purchased from John Thomson, and Alexander J. Thomas was employed in carrying out part of the labour. Besides the above, considerable of the labour was performed by Walter Adams and J.W. Georgeson - both of Alberni; and, while the greater part of the paint was obtained from John Thomson, purchase was also made from Carter's General Store and A. McDonald & Sons - both of Fort Alberni, B.C.

The local Indian Agent was requested to state why the instructions given him, regarding the labour and the purchase of the paint, were not carried out. He now advises as follows:

"On receipt of official letter of July 29, 1926, I immediately informed Rev. E.F. Pitts as to

- the Department's Schools
the Department's instructions re labour and material, only to discover that he had already commenced the work and purchased some paint, etc., from A. McDonald and Sons and Carter's General Store. This, he did in anticipation of authority being granted and upon his own responsibility and not with my knowledge or instruction.

"Immediate steps were taken to rectify this but, unfortunately, due to my being up the Coast at the time the work had been started, the purchases mentioned had been made, and Walter Adams and J. W. Georgeson had already done considerable work. I understand that Mr. Pitts commenced the work as it was necessary to get the outside painting done during the dry weather."

The Principal of the School, Reverend F. E. Pitts, arranged for the purchase of the paint and for the labour without awaiting the necessary instructions.

I should be pleased to be advised if it will be in order to pay the accounts of those merchants who supplied paint and the labourers who were not included in the instructions to the Agent.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Owing to certain fire hazard at the Ahousaht, Alberni and Christie Indian Residential Schools, it has been decided to make an allowance, at the rate of $40.00 per month, towards the salary of a night watchman at each school for the period from November first, next, to April 30, 1937. This is the same rate and for the same period as we provide grants for this purpose at a number of other schools, where there is fire hazard.

You should immediately request each Principal to obtain the services of a reliable man to carry out the duties as night watchman. He should make hourly visits during the night throughout the building and especially pay attention to the furnace room or where there is any danger of fire. Should it be necessary to pay a watchman more salary than the grant we allow, the school authorities will be responsible for payment of same, from per capita allowances or other receipts of the school.

Sir:

I have the honour to submit my report on the fire at Alberni Residential School, which destroyed this building on February 21st, 1937.

Discovery of Fire.

The fire, which apparently started in the store room above the girl's dormitory, was first discovered by Miss Audrey Mills, teacher, who was at that time in the girl's dormitory.

She reports hearing a roar, and on investigation saw smoke coming from the upper landing.

Miss Mills immediately rang in the alarm from the fire station, and went in search of the Principal.

Immediate Action.

Mr. Pitts states that he ran upstairs, and saw smoke issuing from under the locked door of the store room. He opened the door and found the smoke too dense to enter. He locked the door again, and went down for a chemical extinguisher, but was unable to do much good.

ighting of Fire.

The Alberni Fire Department were notified, and responded, arriving about 20 minutes after the fire started.

The fire engine of the Alberni Pacific Lumber Company also arrived to assist, but were unable to do much good, owing to trouble with their engine.

Progress of Fire.

The fire was very soon out of control, chiefly owing to lack of water pressure. The supply for this purpose is drawn from the Alberni City reservoir, and supplied to the school by gravity flow.

By 10:30 A.M., the school was completely destroyed.
Report on fire at Alberni Residential School. (cont.)

Evacuation of Building.

The Reverend Principal does not appear to have a very clear recollection as to how the children left the building, but, from what I can learn from the teachers, they simply walked out.

The girls each brought a blanket with them, and were subsequently taken care of by Mrs. Sainsbury.

The older boys assisted in removing furniture, etc., from the building, and dispersed to various parts of the nearby reserves.

Notification of Fire.

I was notified of the fire at 12 noon, by a constable of the B.C. Provincial Police, and immediately proceeded to the scene.

I was not notified in any way by the Reverend Principal, or by any member of his staff, although I have phones in both office and residence.

Action of Agent.

On arrival at scene of fire, I endeavored to locate the children, and to care for any without shelter.

All the children were housed by 8 p.m. The following morning, the greater majority of those not resident in Alberni were sent home in care of their parents, or relatives.

Owing to fire occurring on Sunday, it was not possible to communicate with the Department by telegraph, but I phoned to Victoria and informed Mr. C. C. Perry, Assistant Commissioner, of the matter.

Fire Loss.

The main school building is completely destroyed, only the stone foundation being left.

The large chimney, which was still standing, was leaning at a dangerous angle, and this I had dropped, as it was a menace.

Practically all of the school equipment was destroyed, as was most of the clothing of both staff and children.
Report on fire at Alberni Residential School. (cont.)

Salvage.

Some furniture was saved from the lower floor, chiefly property of Mr. Pitts, piano, sewing machines, desks, and bookcases, etc.

Remaining Buildings.

Buildings not damaged by fire were:
- The large barn containing 35 head of cattle
- Agricultural Instructor's cottage
- Primary Classroom
- Small Cottage
- Old Barn
- Garage
- Wood Shed
- Implement Shed.

Investigation.

Capt. G. H. Barry, Inspector of Schools arrived on Monday evening, February 23rd, and rendered valuable assistance in investigating matters.

Accompanied by myself, he visited the site of the school, and questioned members of the staff, as to the cause of the fire.

The answers given were very unsatisfactory and contradictory, except those given by teachers, Miss Howe and Miss Mills, dealing with the discovery and alarm.

As to the cause, I have no reason to believe it was other than accidental, possibly from overheated chimney. Evasive answers were given by the kitchen staff as to the probable cause, but it was found that a pan of grease took fire in the oven about 7:45 A.M., the time of the fire.

Care of Children.

All school children, except those of the Cowichan Agency, have been sent to their homes, and these will be leaving on February 23rd.

Arrangements are being made to send some neglected and orphan children to Ahousaht School. These will be taken on the Department Launch. To date, no expense has been incurred in connection with the evacuation of the school children.
Report on fire at Alberni Residential School. (Cont.)

Care of Remaining Buildings and Stock.

The Reverend Principal and staff are remaining at the school, until final arrangements can be made, and will care for the stock, which consists of 35 head of cattle, together with the buildings before mentioned, and, of course, the farm.

General.

In the foregoing report, I have endeavored to cover the subject as thoroughly as circumstances permit at this time.

Mr. Inspector Barry is forwarding his own report, with his views as to the cause of the fire, and with which I thoroughly agree.

Respectfully Submitted,

Your obedient servant,

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

**ACTIONS TAKEN BY INDIAN AGENT:**

Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge will render his own report; but I should like to say that when I arrived in Port Alberni he had the situation well in hand.

I shall remain for a few days to render Mr Ashbridge any help in my power, and to carry out any investigation which the Indian Commissioner may wish, but in the absence of definite instructions to the contrary I propose to return to Victoria at the end of the week or not later than February 26th.

In addition to informing the Assistant Indian Commissioner in Victoria by telephone of the fire by 2 P.M. on the 21st Mr Ashbridge wired to the Indian Affairs Branch in Ottawa this morning as soon as the telegraph office was open. Mr Ashbridge also wired to the Principal of the Ahousaht Indian Residential School today and learned that the Principal, Mr A.E.Caldwell could accommodate up to twenty five children if he were given some extra beds and bedding.

**MOVEMENTS OF CHILDREN SINCE FIRE:**

At the time of my last inspection on December 10th 1936 there were 70 boys and 53 girls in the Alberni Indian Residential School.

Since the fire yesterday morning some 45 children from the local Indian Reserves have gone home to their parents. A number of children from more distant places are staying with relatives or friends on the local Reserves. Some 50 or more children have gone home to outside points with their parents in their own boats.

There remain to-night some twenty to thirty children whose parents have not come for them and who in fact for the most part live in different parts of the Cowichan Agency. Mr Indian Agent Ashbridge is arranging with Mr Indian Agent Graham to move the remaining children to Nanaimo with a suitable escort. From Nanaimo it is hoped that Mr Graham will be able to arrange the movements of children to their own homes or to those of friends in one or two special cases.

Mr Indian Agent Ashbridge and I are agreed that it is necessary to get the few children left on the school property home as soon as possible. Many of the children are only lately recovering from illness, and there is no proper accommodation now at the school for these children.

There is no need for the movement of these children to other Indian Residential Schools at the present time. Should such cases arise from special conditions no doubt the Indian Agents will communicate with the Department. I had thought that it would be necessary to move some at least of the children to Coqualeetza and to Ahousaht, but such children as will in the end have to be sent there are being looked after for the present in the homes of friends or relatives, if not in fact at home.

There are some 33 head of cattle on the farm attached to the school. A recommendation as to their disposal will be made in my next report. In the meantime there is a Farm Instructor to look after their needs.
HIGH SCHOOL PUPILS:

There are three boys attending the Alberni District High School. These boys are living on the local Indian Reserve and are continuing to attend the District High School under instructions from Mr. Pitts.

RECENT DEATHS OF PUPILS:

Mr. Ashbridge has brought to my notice the fact that on or about the 14th of the present month three girl pupils of this school died in hospital. They all died from T.B., Meningitis I am informed. The girls were:

MARY BOB Duncan
BERTHA FRED Alberni
VIOLET MCKAY Ucluelet

I also understand that some boys have been giving trouble at the school, but I have not had time to inquire into this yet.

CAUSE OF FIRE:

I wish to say at once that I am not as yet satisfied that the cause of the fire was accidental. There are features that lead me to think that this fire might possibly have been caused by a pupil.

WILLIAM and LOUE BOB Brothers of and GERTIE BOB Sister of the deceased Mary Bob should be I think investigated. The other dead children appear to have been without brothers or sisters at the school.

The previous school here was burned on the 3rd of June 1917.

NEW SCHOOL:

The Reverend Principal has suggested to me that the right course to follow would be for the Indian Affairs Branch to build a new Residential School to care for the children lately at the Alberni Residential School, and to absorb those now at Ahousaht, and the Uclulet Day School.

I would most earnestly and with the greatest respect submit that great caution be taken in making any promise to the United Church of Canada with regard to the rebuilding of this school.

I do not believe that the Alberni Indian Residential School is wanted as such, or that the expense in per capita grants here is justified. The Principal informed me to-night that he could not suggest any child who should go at once to another Residential School on the grounds of having poor home conditions. If this is so it is indeed hard to justify the presence of the children in any Residential School.

I do consider that a large Indian Day School should be located on one of the Indian Reserves near Alberni and I would strongly recommend that if not entirely too late, the sum of at least $5,000.00 be set aside in the Supplementary Estimates for the erection of such a school before next September.

Port Alberni, B.C.
February 23, 1937.

Gerald H. Barry
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my Preliminary Report on the destruction by fire of the Alberni Indian Residential School, West Coast Agency.

It is now after 2 A.M. on the 23rd and I have been at work on this report since Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge left me about 10 P.M. Under the special circumstances I believe that you will be glad to have some particulars of the burning of this school at the earliest possible moment; but I would ask you and the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch who may read the report to forgive mistakes and errors as I am very tired indeed after a most difficult journey and a number of interviews.

Mr. Ashbridge and I shall visit the Indian Residential School property at Alberni to-morrow or rather this morning, Tuesday the 23rd, and I shall prepare a further report on that visit and forward it without delay.

Very little help can be had from the Reverend Mr. Pitts. As I have reported several times Mr Pitts is a very poor organizer and he appears to have lost his head completely. Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge has excellent control of the situation. He is unhappy that he is unable to get a report off to you to-night, but trusts that the attached report of mine which he has read will be sufficient till he and I complete our investigations to-morrow.

May I most strongly urge in this confidential letter that the United Church of Canada be not given any promise with regard to the rebuilding of the Alberni Indian Residential School. An Indian Day School is required here with well trained teachers and not a badly managed Residential School such as the Alberni School has been for a number of years. I do not believe that the Residential Schools are worth the large sums spent on them, though some will have to be kept in operation for various reasons. The Alberni Residential School is not one of these, what the Church may urge to the contrary notwithstanding.

A copy of this letter and of my report is being addressed to you in care of the Indian Agent, Vancouver as you may have left Victoria before the original can reach you there. Please wire me any further instructions that may be necessary.

Yours sincerely,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Purpose of Report:

Acting on the instructions of the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, I left Victoria on Sunday, February 21st, spent that night in Nanaimo, and arrived in Port Alberni at 4:45 P.M. this afternoon February 22, 1937.

From 5 P.M. to 6 P.M. was spent in the office of Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge. The Indian Agent gave me a clear account of what he knew of the destruction by fire of the Alberni Indian Residential School on the morning of Sunday, February 21st 1937.

The Principal of the school, the Rev. F.E. Pitts, B.A., was good enough to meet the Indian Agent and myself at the Sans Souci Hotel from about 7:30 P.M. to 8:30 P.M. This Monday evening Mr Pitts was able to clear up a number of points with regard to which the Indian Agent had not been informed.

The purpose of this report is to inform the Indian Commissioner and the Indian Affairs Branch at the earliest possible moment of the facts so far brought to light with regard to the burning of the Alberni Indian Residential School. I have arranged to visit the school property with Mr. Ashbridge to-morrow but this Preliminary Report has to be prepared to-night to catch the mail leaving early in the morning.

A further report will be made when I have seen what is left of the school building, and interviewed some of the school staff, and such report will be mailed on the morning of the 24th.

DISCOVERY OF FIRE:

The Principal states that two teachers, Miss Audrey S. Mills, and Miss Kathleen How, who were not present at early prayers, and who reside on the second floor of the building, saw smoke about 8 A.M. They immediately rang the fire alarm.

The children were at the time at breakfast.

RESULT OF FIRE ALARM:

The Principal states that the children left the building by the side doors. Two that were ill in bed appear to have got up, and walked out of the building. The reverend Principal does not seem clear in his mind as to what did happen to the children. He tried to locate the actual fire, and found that there were flames and smoke around the locked door of the attic room on the girls' side of the school. He states that this attic was always kept locked and that only he and Mrs Pitts had keys of the Yale Lock on the door. He unlocked the door and found the attic in flames. He then ran down to the main floor and returned to the attic with a chair and fire extinguisher. He could not make much use of this as the smoke drove him away.

In the mean time Mr Shaw, the farm Instructor, had turned on the water of the stand pipe and had tried to put water on the fire through the hose. He too was driven away by smoke. Alberni Central Telephone Exchange was informed of the fire by telephone at this time.
ATTIC IN WHICH FIRE APPEARS TO HAVE STARTED:

This attic was intended to be used as a dormitory on the girls' side, but does not appear ever to have been used as such.

The corresponding attic room on the boys' side was used for some time as a dormitory.

The Principal states that the attic on the girls' side was used to store clothes and extra bedding. He denies that cleaning materials were kept there.

The Principal states that the main flues two, one being from the kitchen I understand, with two ventilation flues, one being from the kitchen, passed through this attic, and that there was a radiator in the ventilation flue. The latter in some way covered with board or boarding or some such material. He thinks that dust in the ventilating flue may have become ignited with sparks from the kitchen. This appears to me to be just a wild guess, but I shall make further investigation. The ventilation flues opened on each floor. I rather wonder if burning paper could have been placed in one of these on a lower floor, and I shall investigate this.

The above mentioned smoke and ventilation flues were some six feet from the door where the fire was first seen.

PROGRESS OF FIRE:

The fire appears to have spread quickly through the attics under the roof. The action of the Principal in opening the door of the attic on the girls' side when he discovered that room to be on fire of course increased the draft and spread the fire.

The school burned from the top downwards and took some hours to do so according to the Principal's statements. He is the only member of the staff that I have seen so far, and it is very clear to me that the Reverend Gentleman completely lost his head.

NOTIFICATION OF FIRE TO INDIAN AGENT:

It would not appear that the Principal telephoned to the Indian Agent.

Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge informs me that the first he heard of the fire was when the B.C. Police informed him by telephone at about Noon on the 21st FOUR HOURS AFTER THE OUTBREAK and when the school had been destroyed.
ACTUAL FIGHTING OF FIRE:

The Alberni City Fire Department arrived shortly after the outbreak, within perhaps the first half hour. No doubt the alarm to the Central Telephone Exchange caused the ringing of the town bell as the fire alarm. Some bell was rung.

Two lines of hose were taken up the iron fire escapes and water thrown on the fire.

Reference to my reports on this school will show that the pressure in normal times is only sufficient to throw water from one line of hose to the roof from the ground, but not over the roof. With two lines the water would not reach the roof, but in any case the hose were taken up the fire escapes.

The pressure fell as the fire was fought, and it is doubtful if there was sufficient water from the City supply.

The Alberni Pacific Lumber Co. fire pump was brought to the scene of the fire and an attempt made to draw water from the river. Time was wasted with more or less frozen hose lines and the fire pump would not function for some half hour through some defect, I am informed.

ACTIONS OF STAFF AND SOME OF THE PUPILS DURING FIRE:

It would appear that when the children first evacuated the building they just dispersed, and little attempt was made to preserve discipline. This will be investigated.

Some of the staff and some of the boys carried articles out of the building. The girls took a blanket each the Principal informs me, though how they got these I have still to discover. The boys do not appear to have taken blankets with them. Some furniture was removed INCLUDING A PIANO. The Principal states that classroom material and desks were not saved from the main building.

Indians helped to save articles, and the Indian Agent is issuing a Search Warrant as a result, as it is believed that articles were just stolen by the helpers.

The teachers would appear to have lost most of their clothes and belongings, and the children to have little but what they were wearing at the time.

In general from the little information in my possession so far it would appear that all the usual foolish mistakes were made and the wrong articles saved, including musical instruments, while children's clothes and blankets except on the girls' side were lost. I am informed two Singer Sewing Machines and the Principal's papers and records were saved.

BUILDINGS SAVED:

The Primary Classroom and the cottage at one time occupied by the Farm Instructor were not burned. Some boys are being housed in the former and some of the staff and girls are with the Principal's family in the latter.

The desks and material in the Primary Classroom were of course saved.

Traders, Police, Doctors Aeroplanes Help—Mortality Rate Low

TRAPPING IS LEAN

By R. W. LIPSETT

Ottawa, Feb. 16.—The Indian Affairs department has confirmed reports that influenza continues epidemic among Indians in all parts of the Dominion. It was officially stated that the mortality rate has been comparatively low; however, the number of known cases of pneumonia and scarlet fever is small and the cases have proportionately high. There have been many cases of influenza, but all reported have been mild in type.

The department said that the outbreak of the epidemic had been passed. It was stressed that the epidemic had swept across the Indian population from one end of the Dominion to the other.

400 CREEKS III.

Special to The Star

Kenora, Feb. 16.—More than 400 Indian school children and hundreds of other Indians have been affected by an epidemic of influenza which has spread through the Indian population of 2,700 in Kenora District this winter. Most of the sickness has been influenza, but there have been several cases of malaria and scarlet fever.

Despite the efforts of Frank Edwards, Indian agent, and the M.O.H.'s district surgeon, Dr. Donaldson, Dr. Mitchell of Sioux Lookout and Dr. A. D. Ferguson of Kenora have been unable to summon upon air companies to get to the scene of reported outbreaks in haste before the epidemic developing into a serious simultaneous outbreak.

Although mild, the epidemic is nevertheless making conditions exceedingly difficult for the Indians who have yet developed the resistance of the White against such sickness. In addition, trapping season has been very lean and some may be forced to go without food shortage. No deaths have been reported.

Word of outbreak has been brought to Hudson Bay Co. traders or police. Each Indian agent has obtained a doctor when necessary and has been able to send medical help or medicine to the scene.

INSPECTORS REPORT ON THE DESTRUCTION BY FIRE OF THE ALBERNI INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

United Church. West Coast Agency.

Date of investigation: February 23, 1937.

Visit to School Property: Accompanied by Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge I visited the Alberni Indian Residential School property this morning. Several members of the staff of the school were questioned to clear up points for this report. The answers of some of the staff were most unsatisfactory to me. It was fairly clear that some of the lady members of the staff were attempting to hide something which had occurred in the school kitchen on the morning of February 21st last.

Preliminary Report: The subject matter of my Preliminary Report forwarded to the Indian Commissioner, Victoria this morning would appear to be correct in broad outline. Corrections of minor points are made in the body of this subsequent report, which should of course be read in continuation of the former.

Discovery of Fire: Miss Audrey Mills, teacher of the Senior Division, was in her room on the second story. She heard, she states, a noise above her, and opening her door to see what was the matter, saw smoke coming from the attic. Miss How was not present as previously reported. Miss Mills broke the fire disc alarm, but as no one appeared for some time she went down stairs and there met the Principal, Mr Pitts, to whom she reported that the attic was on fire. She then returned to her room to finish dressing. The actual time of the alarm was 7:45 A.M., and not 8 A.M. as previously reported.

Result of Fire Alarm: This was in my opinion highly unsatisfactory, in that the children did not AT ONCE leave the building. They waited for orders from a badly disorganized staff. The girls were handed blankets by members of the staff who had obtained these from the lower dormitories. The boys did not get blankets, and I still am unable to find that they were properly looked after. The first that I can discover of the boys is that they were playing around the school. It was the Principal who made his way into one of the boys' dormitories and threw out some blankets through the window.

GERTRUDE BOB, a sister of the deceased, but a near relative of Mary Bob of whom I was in bed in the Junior Girls' Dormitory and three or four older girls were in the Senior Girls' Dormitory. These children were told to get up and dress by Mrs Sainsbury one of the staff on the girls' side of the school. Why they did not get up when they heard the fire alarm is a question for the Principal to answer. When a Fire Alarm sounds the children should obey in an automatic manner and certainly not wait for orders, sensible or foolish, from a staff that may have become disorganized. In the case of PRACTICE ALARMS children in bed ill should be first warned that there is to be a Drill and that they are to remain in bed.

The other matter in my Preliminary Report under this heading is correct in outline, except that Mr Pitts locked the door of the attic after he had first seen that it was on fire. Mrs Pitts also unlocked this door she states.
Attic in which Fire Started:

The ventilation flue from the kitchen had openings covered with gratings on each floor. It does not appear likely that any of the children placed burning paper in this ventilation pipe.

The canopy over the kitchen stove or range led through a pipe some fifteen to twenty feet long to the ventilation shaft.

Actual Fighting of Fire:

There would appear to have been a shortage of water from the Alberni City mains due to causes that the school had no control of, and the pressure does not appear to have been maintained in the fire hose. In any case the fire had too big a start when the Alberni City Fire Department arrived on the scene.

Action of Staff and Pupils during the Fire:

In addition to what has been reported under this heading and in partial correction of former statements, I may say that the GIRLS when taken from the burning building were housed in the Primary Classroom under the care of the two junior teachers, Miss K. Pitts, and Miss How.

The point of just how the blankets were distributed has been cleared up as described above.

In all some six Singer Sewing Machines were saved. Much of the Principal's furniture and that from Staff rooms was saved. Some of the children's clothes from the laundry were saved also. The teachers lost nearly everything. The teachers I may say in passing were the only members of the staff that could give me a reasonable account of what did happen. They would appear to have kept their heads better during the fire than the missionary members of the staff, and they certainly were far more straightforward in their answers to my questions today.

Buildings Saved:

The following buildings are standing:
- Primary Schoolroom
- Cottage near Primary Schoolroom
- Farm Instructor's Cottage
- Big Barn
- Small Barn
- Garage
- Woodshed with wood
- Implement shed

Action taken by Indian Agent:

Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge is, I understand, forwarding his own report on the fire by this mail. He has now arranged for the disposal of the remaining children on the school property. These are for the most part being sent home. Mr. Indian Agent Graham has been communicated with in regard to the children going to the Cowichan Agency.

There are several special cases, that is children from poor homes, are being dealt with under authority of a telegram from the Indian Affairs Branch, and several of these special children will be sent to Ahousaht Indian Residential School where there is plenty of room for a dozen or more.
Cause of Fire:

Though the discipline at this school has been very weak for years, and the control of the children unsatisfactory, I am quite satisfied that the present fire was not incendiary.

It appears that the regular cook, Miss McKinnon is away ill in Vancouver. Mrs Froates is acting as cook. This lady was not in the kitchen on the Sunday morning of the fire, and was in fact in bed.

The kitchen fire was started by Mr. Shaw, Farm Instructor. I am told that big fires are set to cook cereal for breakfast. This seems strange but such is my information.

On this particular Sunday morning a Miss J. Davidson was preparing breakfast in the school kitchen. Her answers to my simple questions with regard to any peculiar circumstances having occurred were more than evasive. She was in fact incoherent, but admitted that sparks had gone up. She was so obviously covering up something that I determined to question another member of the staff.

Mrs Sainsbury admitted that there had been an oven fire about half an hour before breakfast. A pan of grease had been left over night in the oven. When the stove became hot and it must have been very hot the grease caught fire and the pan was left on the top of the oven while the above mentioned Miss Davidson went to Mrs Pitts for advice. Mrs Pitts appears to have put salt on the burning grease.

It has been impossible to get these Missionary Supervisors to tell me plainly what did happen. They are trying to cover up the real facts in my opinion.

I suggest that some paper or cloth soaked in burning grease was drawn up the ventilator shaft and lodged against the light wooden covering of the ventilator system in the attic. The draft up this shaft from a hot kitchen range would be sufficient to draw up such a burning cloth. It is possible that a large sheet of newspaper was the item drawn up and not a cloth. It is just possible that the chimney caught fire near the top from the fact that there was too big a fire in the kitchen range, but it is hard to explain how the fire spread in such a case. The possible explanation of the burning cloth or paper in the ventilation system appears to me to be a very simple answer to the question of what caused the fire? I would particularly draw your attention to the actual times, the burning of the grease in the kitchen being some half hour before breakfast and the alarm of fire.

I am of the opinion that some of the Supervisors are attempting to suppress the facts of the occurrence in the kitchen, which seems to me the most likely cause of the subsequent fire, and burning of the school.

Port Alberni, B.C.

Dear Mrs. Levey:

Thanks for your prompt telegram expressing sympathy and consideration for us in our great loss of the school. I have delayed the report for a few days that I might better consider the details.

What we felt was the greatest loss was that after ten years of very close and strenuous work we could not leave it for someone else to carry forward on the foundation we had laid. We had all repairs and work in the best condition we have ever had them and to think that in one month, and that the most strenuous month we have ever had, things could go wrong in so many ways.

We have had the longest winter this country has experienced for a long time—over 9 weeks. On January 15, our kitchen matron was taken seriously sick and Mrs. Pitts had to take charge of the kitchen for nearly a month along with her own work; a few days later one of the senior boys walked in his sleep and jumped from a third story window and very fortunately got off with a compound fracture of one leg. One of the senior girls developed T.B. meningitis, was taken to the hospital and died three weeks ago today; seventy-five children got flu and many of them were seriously sick; two more developed T.B. meningitis, and died in the hospital two weeks ago today. That same night a heavy snow storm and rain and wind crushed in the roof of our recreation hall—a big building 38' by 56' and the other out-buildings were dangerously laden with snow. Part of the time the seamstress and laundress were very sick in bed with flu.

We just got all the children up and everything going nicely again, when for no apparent condition other than had been there all along, the school burned down a week ago. This surely seems like a chapter from the book of Job.

I write all this to impress upon you what it means to run an Indian school out in the country with 120 small children and to have the responsibility of every department.

There is always speculation as to the cause of a fire in any Indian school. Captain Barry came to investigate for the Department. He seemed to think that a very likely cause was that some of the children had died and according to old Indian custom some of the children had burned down the building (although they died in the town hospital.)

A second possible cause Captain Barry investigated was that I had called in the Indian agent about a month before to reprimand and advise two boys that who had stolen something and thought that in revenge they had set the fire.
I wish to state positively that I am as certain as is humanly possible that no child nor Indian had anything to do with it and state also that it was impossible for any of the children or Indians to get where the fire started even if they had wanted to do so.

My own theory of the origin of the fire is that it was due to a faulty construction of the building—a fault that any architect should have seen and if there are any other schools built on this same plan, as I believe a number are, the Indian Department should have a competent man inspect them at once, and the Church should see that they do.

Note: The school was a basement three story building with kitchen, dairy, bake shop, dining rooms and playrooms in the basement. The fire started on the top floor on the girls' side of the building in a room approximately 30 x 46 x 10 feet, finished for a dormitory but used to store summer clothing in the winter and winter clothing, bedding, etc., in the summer. It had hardwood floor, fir wainscoting, plastered walls and beaverboard ceiling.

The chimney and ventilating flues ran through this room about 3 feet from the door on the north side of the building. (The chimney of the heating plant and of hot water system did not go through this building.)

The chimney was built on concrete foundation and extended through the four floors and peak of the roof, approximately 60 feet high and had four flues. The outside flues were single brick walls with flues about 26" square, with ventilating grates on each floor. The one on the south side took a ventilating pipe from the canopy over the kitchen range. The pipe from the canopy was about 30 feet long and about 15 inches in diameter. The two middle flues of the chimney were smoke flues; the one on the north took the smoke from a small galvanized bake oven. The one on the south took the smoke pipe from the kitchen range. These smoke flues had an 8-inch wall at the sides and a 4-inch wall between the smoke flues and the ventilating flue.

In order to get a better circulation of air through the ventilating shaft a steam radiator of four sections 4 feet high was placed inside this ventilating flue on the top floor on both sides of the chimney. These radiators were heated, of course, from the steam boiler under the laundry building.

When these radiators were put in, an opening in the brick work about 4 feet by 13 inches was left in front of the radiator. The whole chimney, smoke and ventilating flues, was covered with light fir wainscoting and a door of the same material was placed over this opening in the brickwork in front of the radiator. All this woodwork in the room was varnished.

The door to the room was locked with a heavy spring Yale lock and Mrs. Pitts had the one key and I had the other. No one else went into that room unless with us or by use of our keys.

The teacher who discovered the fire was sleeping in Sunday morning while we were at breakfast. She was aroused by a slight explosion that shook the windows and made them rattle and immediately saw the smoke coming through the beaverboard ceiling. Just outside the door of her room was the fire alarm that rang all through the building. Before she was half way down the stairs, I met her and rushed to the door of this room. On opening it, I found the casing of the door on fire all way
round, also the back of the door, just 3 feet from this chimney. The fire was on the opposite side of the room 30 feet from the door but any man would have been a fool to have tried to reach it. I closed the door and ran down two floors for the 5-gallon chemical tank. When I returned the farm instructor had the hose from the floor below and we tried both the water and chemicals without effect as the smoke was so dense and strong from the varnish that we were driven out and we phoned for Alberni City Fire Brigade, also Port Alberni brigade and the Alberni Pacific Lumber Co. and Forestry Department engines; but we could not control the fire and could only save a few things.

I am convinced that the fire was caused either by the heat of the smoke flue setting fire to the fir wainscoting and varnish off if from the ventilating flue it was caused by spontaneous combustion of dust accumulated in this small radiator or a slight explosion of gas that blew open this little door in front of the radiator and set fire to the varnish near it.

I am sure the smoke flue was not burning out, for there was a little iron trap door at the bottom of this flue and I was past this door four times within half an hour before the fire occurred and could have heard and smelled it if the chimney had been burning out.

Had this fire occurred at night nothing could have prevented panic and no training in fire drill would have prevented loss of life. Had it occurred a week earlier, we had seventy-five children in bed with flu.

I have written this to warn all concerned to prevent a similar occurrence in any other school.

All our equipment and help worked like clock work but still we were helpless — our good fortune was that it happened when it did while we were in the basement.

Yours sincerely,

REPORT.

Re:- INDIAN MISSION SCHOOL. Destroyed by Fire.

I beg to report that a 6.00 A.M. Sunday February 21st 1937 a fire alarm was turned in from the Indian Mission and Residential School situated at the Sheshahlt Indian reservation, Alberni B.C.

Upon my arrival all the children were out of the building and I proceeded to the attic of the girls dormitory where the fire started. Owing to the intense heat a thorough check of the attic could not be made but it was noticed that the fire had started at the chimney or ventilator.

The chimney is a large affair with four flues. The two outer flues being ventilators and the center flue chimney flues. The outer walls of the chimney were built of two layers of brick with a single layer of brick between the chimneys and ventilators. Over the large kitchen range was a canopy connected to one of these ventilators by a fifteen inch pipe for the purpose of taking fumes from the cooking out of the kitchen.

It is my opinion that the fire was caused by a defective chimney when either excessive heat or flame from the chimney flue penetrated the ventilator igniting the grease which would have accumulated in the ventilator from the kitchen range, the fire escaping from the ventilator by the way of a wooden door opening into the attic from the ventilator.

During the morning of the fire and about fifteen minutes before the fire in the attic was noticed, there was a large fire in the kitchen range and fat was being rendered down in the oven. This fat became ignited but was noticed and extinguished. In my mind this had nothing to do with the fire, as the flame from the fat in the oven would not have reached as high as the ventilator.

The building was a wooden frame building on a stone foundation owned by the Department of Indian Affairs and valued at $60000.00 was a total loss, the contents of the building owned by the United Church of Canada was valued at $10000.00. Loss estimated at $8000.00 at present I have not been able to ascertain if insurance was carried by the United Church. Personal property belonging to Mr. Frank Edwin Pitts, Principal, was valued at $1600.00 was insured for $800.00 by the Queen Insurance Company of America. Policy #184927, Part of Mr. Pitts's belongings were saved.

The fire was attended both by the Alberni City Fire Department also the Port Alberni brigade. But lack of water pressure and hampered by heavy mesh screening on the windows little could be done to save the building.

Witnesses who can testify. Mr. Frank Edwin Pitts, Miss Audrey Mills, school teacher.
On my return to Alberni at about 11.30 A.M. I notified Mr. P. B. Ashbridge, Indian Agent who made arrangements to have the one hundred and twenty indian children who were residing at the school returned to their homes.

Dear Sir:

I am directed by the British Columbia Conference of the United Church of Canada to send you the following resolution which was duly passed at the recent meeting of the Conference in Victoria, B.C. -

"Whereas the Indian Residential School at Alberni, owned by the Dominion Government, and operated under the auspices and direction of the W.M.S. Board of the United Church of Canada, was recently destroyed by fire;
"And whereas for many years the School has been carried on with eminent success;
"And whereas the site is particularly suited for the carrying on of the work of such a Residential School;
"And whereas it is rumored that there is a proposal that this site be abandoned, and the School built at a point on Barclay Sound:
"Therefore, be it resolved that this British Columbia Conference of the United Church of Canada place on record its firm conviction that the School should be rebuilt on the former site; and that this be communicated to the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, with the urgent request that the building be replaced with as little delay as possible."

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Proposed New Indian Residential School, Alberni, British Columbia.

While a definite decision has not yet been made the Department is considering the erection of a new Indian residential school to replace the Alberni Indian residential school which was destroyed by fire on February 21, 1937. In the meantime I considered it advisable to bring the matter to your attention in order that a preliminary sketch might be made of the proposed building and other arrangements made in connection with it so that in the event of funds being provided there will be no unnecessary delay in commencing construction.

As a first step I would suggest that you arrange, at the earliest possible date, for a visit to Alberni by one of your engineers or an architect, if the services of the latter are available at the coast, with a view to examining the basement of the former school. Your representative should ascertain the size of the basement of the old school and all other information that would be of assistance in preparing plans.

In erecting a new residential school at this point provision will have to be made for 200 pupils and a staff of approximately 12 persons. The building should, of course, be fireproof.
I am under the impression that if a building with four class rooms with full basement accommodation were erected separate from the main building, it would involve less expense and at the same time provide other advantages. The building containing the class rooms would not necessarily have to be of fireproof construction. The class room building would contain a hall in the middle with two class rooms on each side. Sliding partitions should be placed between the two class rooms on either side of the building. This would enable these rooms to be opened into one room if necessary. As stated above full basement should be provided under this building for vocational training purposes.

If the suggestion made in the preceding paragraph were put into effect it is quite possible that the present basement would be sufficiently large to permit the erection of the main building which should be a building with full basement, two stories high with dormer roof and a residence for the Principal at one end.

As soon as your representative forwards his report it would be appreciated if you would submit it to me for consideration by the officials of this Branch.

Director.

Sir: Report on Site and Old Foundation Walls,
Alberni Indian Residential School,
Alberni, B.C.

In accordance with your instructions of recent date, I inspected the remains of the Alberni Indian Residential School on March 20th, and beg to report as follows:

SITE

The school site consists of a block of land on the north or right shore of the Somass river about one mile from Alberni and three miles from Port Alberni. Adjoining the site on the west is Tsahaheh Indian Reserve and on the east property owned by the United Church. The portion of the site adjacent to the river is low clay land suitable for garden purposes. At an elevation about 35 feet above this is a level bench of sandy gravel on which the old school was located. This flat bench area is about 500 feet by 350 feet and is a very suitable site for a school, with sufficient area for small playing fields. Back of this bench the land rises to the north edge of the property. The eastern part of this slope is cleared agricultural land on which is situated a large barn. The western edge is uncleared land with rock exposures at about same elevation as the bench on which school was located.

DRAINAGE

The old school had a basement floor two feet below the ground level and no trouble from water was reported. The heating plant floor was four feet below ground level and considerable trouble

C.E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water and Power Bureau,
Vancouver, B.C.
from water was experienced. With precipitation to be expected at this point (Port Alberni 70.65 inches per year) it will therefore be necessary to provide for proper drainage. With the lower land in front of the building construction of drains from the building site to this lower land is an easy problem.

OLD WALLS ETC.

The foundations of the old school are still standing but an examination of them indicates that the mortar and concrete is of very poor quality, either due to the fire or as a result of using poor mixtures during construction. These walls extend nine feet above ground level and consist of one course of brick with a five inch face of field stone and cement blocks. The bricks about windows, doors etc., are badly broken and the whole can be easily removed from position by hand or with a hammer. The mortar does not adhere to the bricks as it should and I would therefore suggest the whole of this masonry be removed. Some of the brick can be used again although it is generally of poor quality. The boiler room has a concrete lining inside the brick work to keep out seepage through the walls but this also is of very poor quality, it being possible to penetrate the concrete almost an inch with a pointed 1" bar about 8 inches long held in the hand. The chimney for the boiler is still standing but the mortar is so poor that it is probably not safe. This chimney is four feet by four feet at the base and about 50 feet or more high.
WATER SUPPLY

In December, 1935, this Bureau installed a new 4" water main from the City of Alberni's 4" main to the school where it connected to the school 2" system. This pipeline appears in good order and could be used for the domestic supply of the new school but is not suitable for fire fighting purposes owing to the limited supply of water available through the 4" mains of the City of Alberni which can supply 100 U.S. gallons per minute at 30-lbs. pressure.

Report of E.H.Tredcroft made December 5, 1935 (our number 407) on "Improvements to Fire Protection System at Alberni Indian School" goes into this phase of the water supply system at some length. This report suggests a 6" wood stave fire main be run from the Somass river to the school, water to be pumped by a 50-60 h.p. Gasoline engine housed in a wooden pump house near the river and above a concrete intake well connected to the river by means of a 14" Vitrified supply pipe. This system would supply 500 U.S. gallons per minute or enough to keep two fire streams of 240 U.S. gallons per minute in operation. The system of partial monitor hydrants and partial ordinary hydrants to which hose may be connected is worthy of consideration in connection with this project as the monitor type hydrants are available without delay and can thus be put in service before the hose lines can be run out. The estimated cost of this system as then proposed was $3600.00.

LIGHT SUPPLY

Electricity was previously supplied to the school by the National Utilities Corporation of Alberni who had a 2200 volt power line from their
transmission line along the Alberni-Great Central Lake road. This supply is considered to be more satisfactory than would be the construction and operation of a private system at the school. Charges for light are 9¢ for first 30 K.W. hours and 3¢ per K.W. hour for the balance with $1.50 per H.P. standby charge for any motors which may be installed. The charges at the old school ran from $5.50 to $40.00 per month and maximum consumption was 1321 K.W. hours. At the old school there was a 2 H.P. motor in the laundry.

HEATING SYSTEM

The old boiler and hot water tank at the school are still in place and it is probable that this boiler could be put in shape to handle the heating of the proposed school. It is an 84 H.P. Horizontal Return Tublar boiler 66" x 12'0" built in 1920 by Vulcan Iron Works of Vancouver and designed to operate at 100 lbs. pressure. The boiler normally worked at 10 lbs. and as it is brick encased it is probable that it would be suitable for the new school after overhaul.

A number of the old radiators are in the ruins but it is probable these are of little value except as scrap iron.

The fuel for the new building could be crude oil, coal, wood or sawdust (hog fuel). It is probable that a heating unit burning sawdust or hog fuel would be the most economical at the moment as there are two large sawmills at Port Alberni and others nearby from which fuel could be obtained at a reasonable cost at present. It is probable this type of fuel will be available at reasonable cost, if storage is provided, for a number of years to come.
SEWAGE SYSTEM

At the old school there is a sewage disposal system consisting of pipe lines to a septic tank with necessary filter beds. The filter beds located on the side hill washed out and after further consideration were not considered necessary and overflow from the tank was then carried direct to the Somass river by means of a 6" vitrified pipe installed in 1930. The tank is 12 feet by 4.5 feet by 4.5 feet and was designed for a school of 125 occupants. After the new outlet was installed in 1930 this tank gave entire satisfaction. It is believed that if the waste water from laundry and kitchen of the proposed school were carried by a separate pipe direct to the outlet pipe by-passing the septic tank, the present septic tank would meet the requirements of the new school. The presence of laundry and kitchen waste in a septic tank materially decreases its efficiency and it is not desirable to pass such waste through the tank if at all possible.

If the present system is used it might be found desirable to replace the pipe between the new school and the tank and in any case would require a new 4" pipe to convey laundry and kitchen waste from the school to the septic tank outlet pipe.

SALVAGE MATERIAL AT OLD SCHOOL

A considerable amount of brick could be salvaged from the old school site and while not of best quality could be used for certain purposes. There is also a considerable quantity of field stone and cement blocks in the walls and these look to be in fair condition and probably a good percentage could be used.
The window sash weights have been salvaged and are neatly piled near the wall of the boiler room. These are in good condition and can be re-used.

A good deal of scrap iron such as pipes, broken radiators, fire escapes etc. could be salvaged.

PROPOSED TYPE OF SCHOOL

Three possible types of schools might be considered for this site.

(1) School similar to that destroyed, with residence and class rooms under one roof.

(2) Separate school building and residence building.

(3) Separate school building with several cottage residences and administration building.

The apparent advantages and disadvantages of these are considered hereafter.

1. A building of this type would have to be fireproof throughout and unless of about three stories would cover a considerable area. Heating of such a building would be least costly and supervision would be easiest although such a building would of necessity have day students in it as well as residents, which is possibly a disadvantage.

2. Separate school and residence would permit of the school functions being entirely separate from the dormitory which is said to be an advantage. The heating of the two buildings would be probably more expensive than of one combined building although a central heating system could be installed. If this layout is desired it is suggested the new dormitory building be to the west and the school to the east so that sewage disposal can be readily handled. The school buildings might be slightly forward or south of the old site to leave more playground space to the back and north of the buildings. The boiler house
could be adjacent to the dormitory building making access easy at night to check over fires. Sketch shows suggested location of new buildings.

3. At the request of the Commissioner of Indian Affairs a visit was paid to the Fairbridge Farm School near Duncan and the system of cottage residences was looked into and very much impressed the writer. Here they have a large school building, 14 cottage residences, a main building with kitchen, dining hall and laundry as well as separate building for manual training, office, principal's residence, farm buildings etc. In each residence are housed 14 students of various ages under control of a matron. The most modern of these cottages are double buildings and each section contains small sitting room, bedroom and bathroom for matron, dormitory room, kitchen and small dining room on one floor with play room under dormitory, bathroom, locker room in basement with one hot air wood burning heating unit, drying room and fuel room for the two sections. Thirteen of these cottages are used as residences and the fourteenth as a hospital. Breakfast and dinner (noon) are obtained at the main dining hall and supper in the cottage. The Alberni site would be very suitable for such a school system as the cottages could be built on the side hill to the northwest of the old school site.

As the cottages are all small they need not be of fireproof construction and therefore would probably not be expensive to build, although due to having additional matrons it would probably make the cost of operation heavy as compared with a single dormitory building. If this type of school was decided on it might be considered each cottage should house more than 14 and to do this it is suggested only part of building have basement and the playroom as at Fairbridge.
school be built with floor above ground level and used as one dormitory with a second dormitory above.

GENERAL

The provision of adequate and suitable fire protection for the proposed buildings is desirable and it is also desirable that fire escape provision be of such a nature that they cannot be cut off from ease of access. It is probable that chutes would be most suitable as they do not permit of easy access to the upper stores which is an objection to the usual type of fire escape. The school itself should be so designed as to permit of more than one outlet in case of fire to each portion of the building.

The wash and bathrooms for the school should be adjacent to the dormitories themselves and on the same floor. Provision should also be made for toilets adjacent to the school rooms for use of day students as it is not desirable that they have access to the dormitory building or portion of the building.

The small building shown on plan as school room was formerly used as a manual training room and it could be converted into a shop to be used for boat building which it is understood is desirable at this school. If boat building is to be carried on in the basement of the school proper adjacent to the manual training shops provision should be made to permit the boat being removed when completed.

Reference reports on this school are:

Our No.237 Report on proposed repairs to Sewage Disposal System, Port Alberni Indian School by A.L.McNaughton, April 30, 1930.

Our No.269 Report on Installation of Septic Tank Outlet Drain at Alberni Indian Mission School by A.L.McNaughton, Aug.27, 1930

Our No. 410 Report re repairs to Domestic Water Supply, Alberni Indian School, Alberni, B.C., by E.H.Tredcroft, Dec. 4, 1935.

The several possible arrangements of school and residence in connection with this project have been covered in some detail as such information may be of value to the officials in charge of the educational phase of the Indian Affairs Branch activities, to enable them to decide on which type of school would be most suitable to meet the requirements of the Alberni locality.

Your obedient servant,

G.H.Whyte

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of the 3rd instant in which you request authority to sell a large quantity of scrap iron, piping etc. at present on the site of the Alberni residential school in order to pay the Indians for their labour in clearing the site. I agree with you that your suggestion would be a simple and convenient method of cleaning up the old site preparatory to the erection of the new building, but unfortunately, the procedure suggested would be contrary to the provisions of the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act. To dispose of the old material and use the proceeds would really be supplementing any parliamentary appropriation provided for the re-erection of the building. The proceeds of the sale should of course be deposited to actual revenue. At the same time, the Chief Treasury Officer would no doubt decline to pass the accounts for the labour involved. I am confident that we would be severely criticized by the Auditor General's Department and the Treasury Board if the circumstances became known that we were using the proceeds of material sold, to meet other expenditures.

Under the circumstances, I think that the only legitimate course open to us is to ask the Salvage Officer to dispose of the old scrap iron, piping etc., by tender in the usual way, crediting any proceeds to Casual Revenue of your Branch. The cost of clearing the debris would have to be borne by the appropriation for the re-erection of the building.

In view of the above you should not take any further action toward clearing the site of the Alberni school.

I. H. Ashbridge, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Alberni, B. C.
You might let me know the approximate quantities and kinds of scrap iron, piping etc. that is at present on the site and also advise if you consider it marketable and if it could be sold locally. Memorandum: DR. MCGILL
Indian Affairs Branch

Re: Alberni Indian Residential School, Alberni, B.C.

Your File 5159-21

I wish to acknowledge your memorandum of the 8th instant, in which you recommend that the Indian Agent be authorized to sell the large quantity of scrap iron, piping, etc., in the ruins of the old building, using the proceeds to pay the Indians engaged in clearing the site.

I agree with you that your suggestion would be a simple and convenient method of cleaning up the old site preparatory to the erection of the new building, but unfortunately, the procedure suggested would be contrary to the provisions of the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act. To dispose of the old material and use the proceeds would really be supplementing any parliamentary appropriation provided for the re-erection of the building. The proceeds of the sale should of course be deposited to actual revenue. At the same time, the Chief Treasury Officer would no doubt decline to pass the accounts for the labour involved. I am confident that we would be severely criticized by the Auditor General's Department and the Treasury Board if the circumstances became known that we were using the proceeds of material sold, to meet other expenditures.

Under the circumstances, I think that the only legitimate course open to us is to ask the Salvage Officer to dispose of the old scrap iron, piping, etc., by tender in the usual way, crediting any proceeds to Casual Revenue of your Branch. The cost of clearing the debris would have to be borne by the appropriation for the re-erection of the building.
If you wish me to proceed with the disposal of the old material please let me know to whom interested parties should apply and any necessary information which might now be submitted to the Salvage Officer.
