Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am sure you would be interested in getting a first hand account of the tragic loss of our Class Room building. I presume you will have received an official account, but it has been upon my heart for some time to write you, giving my own account. Needless to say, I have had little leisure for anything except the work of getting the classrooms under way again.

I am glad to say, in this regard, that the children were only eight days without classroom work. During that time they were given extra work along handicraft lines. The building was burned Tuesday night, Feb. 18th, and class rooms re-opened on Monday morning the 24th Feb. I cannot speak too highly of the work of our Boatbuilder, Mr. Huddleston in getting temporary desks, blackboards etc ready. By an ingenious arrangement we are able to use the regular Assembly Hall seats, and desks are attached which can be taken off for our Sunday services with little trouble.

Three ply screens divide the Assembly hall into two good class rooms and these screens form extra blackboard space. The Senior and Junior Divisions are accommodated here, and as they are in opposite ends of the hall, little trouble is made for either one by the lessons under way in the other.

We took one half of the Senior Girls Play room, and have made a good Primary Class Room. The Intermediates are housed in the old Day School building, which fortunately had not been taken down. We can carry on quite well for the rest of this school year, but I do hope it may be possible to renew the Class Room unit before the opening of another academic year.

The teachers and the boys and girls have reacted splendidly, and feel definite responsibility for the success of the work under the handicaps which for a time they must face.

But to return to the fire. I was in the Staff Sitting Room, just preliminary to going to the Residence. The Manual Training teacher passed the door and I called him in saying that I smelled something not unlike rubber burning. We at once inspected the standing electric reading lamp but there was no sign of any heat. The teacher went on to the boiler room, but kept on investigating. I went to the Sewing room to see if an electric machine had been left connected, or an iron, but all was right. There was no smell in the corridor outside the Staff Sitting room. But then, and this would be between twenty and twenty five minutes after ten P.M., Mr. Bothwell returned from the boiler room saying there was some smoke in it. I remarked, that I must have been wrong but that "you know a Principal is always smelling something". With that he went out to the stairway on the boys' side to go to his room. When he got to the first landing, he saw the flames beginning to come through the door, or just above the door, of the Class Room building and rushed back saying it was on fire. He ran out the boys' entrance, and I followed. He went downstairs to the door and it pulled open to the fire. Shutting it to keep the flames from spreading the faster he rushed around to the other side and went in through the girls' entrance to the Class Room building trying to get at the fire equipment. Meantime, after a glance, in which I saw the flames had...
begun to burst through the window above the door, I ran back into the main building to get a fire extinguisher. Simultaneously, my Office secretary appeared and I called her to phone the Fire Department. When I got to the door again, I saw that little glass was broken in the door and this was brought forcibly to my attention as the first stream of Pyrene fluid struck unbroken glass and I had to direct it carefully through a pane which was broken right next to the lock, and thence down toward what I thought to be the base of the fire.

The only significant difference, compared to the first time, was that it seemed possible that the fire had not been burning long enough to cause heat sufficient to break the glass in the doors. I told the Police this the next morning. Later, as I stood looking out one night about 1 A.M., that pane of glass seemed to stand out with a new significance, for I realized then, that it was right next to the lock, and if it were broken by anyone wishing to enter, the thing was easy.

I cannot prove anything, of course, but that is a fact which does not easily fade out of my mind.

The other men on the Staff were on hand almost as soon as I, and they all knew the same sensation, namely that there was no fire anywhere else except just on the landing inside the door. From there it went across toward the right and climbed up the wall by the side of the door on what seemed the opposite side of where the fire occurred.

There was no sign of fire in the paint locker on the right of the doorway, nor in the boys' lavatory on the left. Both windows remained dark until the fire was well under way throughout the building. In fact, the window of the paint locker was broken open in order to get in before the fire reached the paints located therein.

We had been doing some staining, setting aside for the Official Opening, but the fire had been there several only two of them as only one boy was doing that work, brought in and were placed on a thick bench under the instructions of the Manual Training teacher. They were quite loosely laid up. I told the Police and the Fire Marshal this, but there was no sign of fire anywhere near that spot, nor in fact anywhere in the M.T. room until it had broken down through from the Class Room above. If you study the enclosed snap shots this is evident.

During his investigations, the Fire Marshall dug up a waste paper basket from the ruins of the basement; it had been in the Boys' Lavatory to the left of the entrance. He said that there were remains of paper towels etc in it. He wanted to know if any of the boys had been smoking in the building. To the best of my knowledge, they had not.

The door of the Class Room building was always kept locked when no teachers were in it. It had been locked by the M.T. Teacher at 5:30 when he left, and again at 6:10 when the last teacher left. No boys were out of the building after supper, and certainly none were out late, for it would have been impossible for the supervisor to put the boys to bed the seniors at 8:30 and the younger ones earlier.

I went out at once after he told me and found the whole paper basket. In it was one of these paper towels, and it was hardly scorched. The Police nor the Fire Marshal, so far as anything they said to me would indicate, thought much of this basket as the source of the fire.

It seems unreasonable to think that a fire could start in a waste basket six hours—no, four hours—after the last teacher left the building, and burn up sufficiently, with a steel bottom resting on a cement floor, to burn partitions through, without burning all the paper in the waste basket in the process. None but paper towels were used in the class room building, and these only by the Primary class. The Primary teacher told me she had sent only one boy down with a towel that day.
Fortunately I had inspected that basement corridor just before noon that day to see if any litter had been allowed to gather near that stairway, and I found it clean. Nothing was there except the remains of two old class-room desks, cast iron frames and maple seats, and I took particular pains to see if anything else had been allowed to gather. It was clean, nothing underneath the stairs at all save these desk frames, and two or three pieces of iron pipe lying on the floor farther out.

The engineer went that afternoon to get a piece of pipe, and he too looked underneath and found it clean. The reason for such inspection in that particular place was that it was not far from the door into the Manual Training Room, and I had given orders that no lumber or litter from that room should be allowed there at all. I had told the Engineer weeks before about this.

That afternoon, at 4, the Manual Training teacher superintended the sweeping of the basement, and it was left clean.

I took particular notice too, when I first looked through the door at the fire, and while I was squinting the Pyrene in, that there was NO FIRE on the stems of this very ladder up to the class-room above. Hence it seemed to me that all leaders which might have established our blame for the school were eliminated.

While there are no indications that any Indian set the fire, there is plenty of conviction upon the part of members of staff, especially our engineer, that it was an incendiary fire. I think it is only fair to say too, that I was deeply hurt by the attitude of the Indians, many of them who were watching the fire. One woman in particular, had a hearing smile on her face, and a great deal of amusement seemed to see it as a stunt, and to quip the mention of Mr. Ashburne to this as we stood talking together while the fire was in progress.

All along there has seemed to be some indefinite, but very real opposition to the school, and in particular to me. I have felt it ought never have been thought to try to reason it out or to locate it. It seemed to me, at least, that the Indians ought to be proud of the new school, and to swing in behind it wholeheartedly. I felt there was some dissatisfaction because I would not allow the local children out for such an event for a long time. They had chickenpox in the school and were under observation. Then I had never been used to it at Cowichan where the parents of local children never made any request to have their children and seemed to understand.

I feel sure that it has been only a small number of the people here who have been really resentful, but they have been very active, as I now find. Two or three days before the fire, the Rev. Mr. MacLean, the local United Church Minister told me that he had been approached by Indians with a view to taking their grievances before the Board. I told him it was the last thing I could have had a good result to find. On Monday previous to the fire he told me that he had received a document setting forth their grievances, said that I was not interested in seeing it, but that I would answer them when they were presented to me.

He went to Victoria that day, and Tuesday night the school burned. That was the last straw, so I wired Mr. MacLean advising that Presbytery appoint a committee to investigate all charges. This was done and the committee came to listen on the Friday of that week.

Mr. Pitts came by me the morning of the day and seemed to feel that the Indians ought not to be allowed to attend the meeting etc. I said I felt they should. As the time for the meeting approached, Alex Thomas, whom I feel to be the ring leader, did not want to appear.
Alberni Residential School
United Church of Canada

Principal
REV. R. C. SCOTT, B.A.

R.A.M.

I am writing to inform you that the "people" had not been informed etc. I told him that he and the other two men who had signed the papers were here, and that he surely was willing to stand up to his signed word. As the chief who was one of the signers, was down at Sally's Point, five or six miles away, I told one of the staff to take the little truck and go for him. Thomas went along, but while he was there gave other Indians to understand that only the chief was wanted at the meeting. I have since found out that quite a group of people were not, and are not, favorable to the children being allowed out, and that they would have said so had they been allowed to attend the meetings.

To make a long story short, the grievances were such exaggerations and such untruths, that the committee had little difficulty in getting the people to see that they were unnecessarily alarmed, and that by coming to me all could be arranged amicably and that they ought to have done this on the start and not gone to others who were not concerned with the management of the school.

I have had to allow a certain amount of permission to parents to have their children for a few hours on Saturday afternoon, and we were from today, intend to throw the building open to the Indian people to have their meetings. I say this in hope it will do good. In the evening I shall ask Mr. Ashbridge to come, and after showing some movies of what we did at Coqualeetza, (without stressing the fact that it is Coqualeetza, of course) I shall try to get them to see what can be done here. The visit of the King and Queen, to which our pupils at Sardis were attendants, I mean in attendance, will lend interest I am sure.

I do hope that it may be possible to get a new Class Room block, if it is renewed as a frame building, of the sort we had in the one burned down, we could provide better fire protection OUTSIDE the block itself. Even if a booster pump were not given and a pipe line laid to the river, which would be the right thing to do, we could do effective work if we had the hose fittings and sufficient hose for the Alberni Fire Department hydrant. I presume if that Fuls Will proposition ever goes through, and there is talk locally of it again, we could get plenty of water in exchange for the right of way across the school property. However, a fire proof block would be best.

I am on duty this evening and have had a lot of interruptions which have not been at all good for the sequence of subjects dealt with in this letter. Our new boat shop is well under way, and it will be a credit to our Manual Training Teacher and the senior boys, in addition to all that it will mean to those who come after them. I would like to make our boatbuilding department a real factor in the restoration of these West Coast Indians. I think it can be done, but more of that later through the usual channels.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Major MacKay, although he is familiar with the contents after our conversations following the fire. By the way, Captain Barry was a great help to us in selecting the books which we needed to get under way, and in addition he donated about fifty dollars worth of his own books gathered here and there during his Inspectorship.

Regretting the loss which we and the Department have suffered in this unfortunate occurrence, and saying how much I appreciate the help we have had right along from the Department, I am,

Yours sincerely,

Ottawa, March 25, 1941.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 15th instant, in which you discuss very fully the destruction of the classroom building by fire.

I note that you have sent a copy of this report to Commissioner MacKay. Commissioner MacKay, I may state, is at present at Ottawa, and it is my intention to discuss the subject matter of this report with him during his stay here.

I regret to state that I am not in a position at the moment to say what provision, if any, can be made for the rebuilding of the classrooms in the estimates of this year. The destruction of the school by fire at this critical time, when we are putting forth every effort to conserve to the utmost extent possible the public funds at our disposal, has had a very depressing effect upon all of us. In addition to this, other schools destroyed by fire in recent years, such as the Anglican School in the Yukon Territory and the R.C. School at Albany, Ontario, have not been rebuilt, and it is going to be exceedingly difficult to seriously consider the rebuilding of the Alberni classrooms without giving due consideration to the rebuilding of the other schools. It is altogether likely, however, that this matter will be discussed and a decision reached at an early date.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Pratt:

I have a letter from the Principal of the Indian School at Alberni, the Reverend R. C. Scott, which reads in part as follows:

"I have before me the report of the Deputy Fire Marshall of Vancouver, under date of February 1st, and he has recommended that we should have at least two liquid chemical fire extinguishers on each floor, one at each end of the main corridor, including the basement. In the kitchen there should be one Soda and Acid and one C.T.C. extinguisher. I would be very glad indeed to have the Department comply with this suggestion. A Standard Fire Alarm system consisting of break fire alarm boxes and gates has been established in the main building. He recommends in addition, that no less than two hundred feet of 2" Fire Hose with two shut off nozzles for the same with 3" tips, be installed in a hose house within easy reach of the stand pipe of the Alberni Fire Department. He recommends that this stand pipe be moved back to about sixty feet of the wooden buildings. After our experience with that fire, I do not think it is necessary to move the stand pipe, as there was no wind at any time from heat. Of course the wind was away from it, and it might have been different had the wind been towards us. I do think that it is very important that two hundred feet of hose be supplied. We would be quite willing to build the hose house and to do any other work we could through our Manual Training Department, to assist in this installation. I would suggest too that this pipe which supplies the stand pipe be extended to reach the barn.

If we had only that hose, I feel sure we could have saved the building, for as I have already pointed out, the fire was only in its initial stages when we discovered it. The only blaze there was got up the wall and it was this fire that got away and could not be reached by our extinguishers".

It is not -
It is not quite clear to me whether he was writing me personally and had taken the matter up officially with the Indian Department or whether he wished me to do so. The suggestions of the Fire Marshall seem to be reasonable and I would suggest that the equipment be obtained at once.

I should also like to know what the prospects are of getting the school premises rebuilt this year.

Yours faithfully,

A. W. Neill

Dear Mr. Neill:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of May 10, containing certain recommendations with respect to fire equipment that may be necessary at the Alberni Residential School, received by you from the Reverend R. C. Scott.

The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch inform me that when the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia visited Ottawa a few weeks ago they fully discussed with him the destruction of the classroom building at Alberni by fire and the measures that might be adopted to prevent the recurrence of fires in these buildings.

The officials now have before them a report on the fire by the Principal, a report and certain recommendations by Inspector Barry and a summary of these reports, with certain comments, by Commissioner MacKay. At the time of his visit here, however, the Commissioner was anxious to have an opportunity to study still further the Fire Prevention Act of British Columbia, with the object of making a number of definite recommendations with respect to the rebuilding of the school and fire prevention measures that might prove to be the most effective.

The recommendations made by the Reverend R. C. Scott appear to be reasonable and should, no doubt, form part of the general prevention plan.

Dear Mr. Ashbridge:

With regard to our Boat Shop, I beg to say that in order to finish it properly, the following materials are necessary.

1. Brick: enough to build a chimney at least 24 feet high. A conservative estimate would be 500 bricks. Mr. Kneen of 901 Upper Crescent, Port Alberni, has some second-hand brick on hand at $60 per thousand. I believe the regular price of new brick laid down in Port Alberni is $30 per thousand. The building of this chimney would be a good project for our senior boys. Mr. Huddleston has built houses including the chimney and is thoroughly competent to undertake this work if the Department would supply these materials. There would of course, be a small quantity of lime and sand required.

2. Paint: There are 2500 square feet to be covered, and this would take, we estimate, in the neighbourhood of 10 gallons of paint to do a two coat job. We would recommend cream color, to correspond with the window trim of the main building. The former classroom building was cream colored. It would be necessary to have at least 1 gallon of green paint for the bottom of the walls from the water table to the ground.

3. Shingle Stain: There are 1500 square feet of roof to be covered, and at $50 a square feet to the gallon, this would take 6 gallons.

4. Electric Wiring: As this building has been put up at considerable expense to the Department for materials and as it is a fundamental unit in our educational programme, in order to safeguard it proper electric installation should be made. A local electrician whom I consulted, gives me an estimate of $75 being in the ratio of $50 for materials and $25 for labor. This would mean of course, not only proper wiring in the building itself, but wire for, and attachment to the power lines.

While we can not this year undertake the building of a large fishing boat, we could build a number of row boats which would be fine practice for these boys. Before we can do this we will need to have the wiring done. I am however, going to build at least two flat bottom skiffs such as the fishermen use as tenders for their fishing boats. While these can

Memorandum:

CHIEF ENGINEER,
SURVEYS & ENGINEERING BRANCH.

I enclose, for your information, copy of a letter received from Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., as well as a copy of a communication received from the Principal of the Alberni Indian Residential School.

Both these letters refer to the linoleum on the basement floor of the new school at Alberni, B. C. It would be appreciated if you would carefully consider these letters and take whatever action believed necessary.

Encl.

[Signature]

Acting Director,
Chief Engineer.
Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith a letter received from the Reverend Principal of Alberni Indian Residential School relative to linoleum on the basement floor of this institution.

On enquiry of Mr. Leigh of the Fred Beatty Company, I find that the basement dining room referred to was in their contract, but that at the time they had their crew over at the school they were unable to attend to this particular floor for the reason that the use of the dining room could not be discontinued, there being no other accommodation for the pupils owing to the fact that the rest of the basement floor was undergoing water-proofing at the same time. The absence of the pupils on vacation will now make this possible and is being undertaken within the next few days but will necessitate returning the Company's crew from Vancouver to Alberni, an item not anticipated in their original contract which was based on the entire basement being available. It is possible the Company may seek some adjustment in this connection amounting to approximately $50.00, but this is not certain.

It was found by the Company that the old linoleum taken up had been damaged to the extent of requiring an additional amount 35' x 6' for replacement, regarding which I wired you on the 29th ultimo, securing your approval on the same date. The cost is $68.97 F.O.B. the school.

The Company's representative informs me that when the hot water heating system was installed no provision was made for expansion or contraction, with the result that when it was closed down for the summer the contraction opened up some of the joints, causing a leakage which aggravated the damp floor condition.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

For D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

Re Linoleum in Student Dining Room:

I regret to advise you that the Linoleum in the Student Dining Room is going just the same as that which has been re-laid in the Play Rooms and Basement Corridors. This Lino was, or seemed to be, in so much better shape than that in the above areas that I thought it would be alright. It was not until the last couple of months that it seemed to go so badly. In place, I only found this week just before the Fred M. Beatty men came over. There was one long overlap along the seam under the tables on the North Side of the Dining Room which has only been saved from breaking by the fact that it is under the tables and does not have the traffic which is the case with the area along the aisle between the tables. Lately there has come a "bulge" right in the centre of the aisle leading in from the girls' side and this will likely break if not attended to.

The spot mentioned as being discovered last week, is just below the joint in the heating pipe running along the south wall. This leak is due doubtless to the fact that the hot water system is not needed for heating, and these particular joints may have been none too good at any time. But when the pipe has contracted it has caused a small "drip". This has got under the linoleum and the cement has rotted. While this particular spot is not large, and has only come during the last week, still it all adds on to the general condition.

The Linoleum in both kitchens seems to be standing up very well as there is a lot of heat in both areas.

As I have said above, this is not true of the Student Dining Room and I have to advise that if something is not done about it, the linoleum here will either perish or be broken. While funds are, I know, difficult to obtain, it would be money well spent to take care of this need as soon as possible.

I called the attention of Mr Leigh of the Fred M. Beatty Co. to the
Alberni Residential School
United Church of Canada

Principal
REV. R. C. SCOTT, B.A.

D.M.M. (2)

condition and he took measurements of the area concerned and ought to be able to give you a figure as to most were it possible to undertake the work.
If this is possible, it would be well to have the work done within the next two or three weeks to have everything in shape for the re-opening of School at the end of August.
I may say that the men who are damp proofing the play rooms and basement corridors seem to have done a good job. The linoleum will be relaid right away and I hope the job will be most satisfactory.
regretting to have to inform you as above, and trusting that it may be possible to have the work undertaken in the not too distant future, I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

P.S. As Mr Ashbridge is not in his office today, I am taking the liberty of sending this letter direct and am sending a copy to him. I feel sure that he would agree with the need for attending to the condition fast developing in the Student Dining Room.

Memorandum:

Mr. Phelan

Re: Indian Residential School, Alberni, B.C.

Your memorandum of the 7th instant, with enclosures from Captain Scott and Indian Commissioner McKay relative to the above, is acknowledged.

With reference to Captain Scott's report that linoleum covering the floor of the pupils' dining room had buckled, I may say that when the damp-proofing of linoleum covered areas in the basement of the school was authorized by the Indian Affairs Branch in March of this year, arrangements were made with the Fred M. Beatty Company of Vancouver to lift all the linoleum in the basement and supervise its storage. This constituted the first operation, which, with the supply of damp-proofing material to be applied later, was carried out at the end of the 1940-41 fiscal year at a cost of $526.00.

Captain Scott was advised of the arrangements made and was requested to certify that the work was carried out as called for.

The account from the Beatty people for the first operation, duly certified by Captain Scott and approved by Mr. Coleman, was received here on March 29th last, and payment was made on April 10th, 1941, from funds already transferred to this Service.

The agreement further provided that a second operation, consisting of the application of damp-proofing to all linoleum covered areas in the basement and relaying all linoleum in waterproof linoleum cement, was to be carried out when so directed by the Department, at a cost not to exceed $297.00.

As you are aware, funds for this purpose were recently provided, and on June 27th last the Beatty people were advised to proceed with the second operation as soon as arrangements convenient to Captain Scott could be made.

We also advised Captain Scott, under date of June 27th, regarding our action, and forwarded for his information a copy of our letter to the F. M. Beatty Company Ltd. This correspondence was acknowledged by Captain Scott under date of July 14th last.

As stated...........

P. N. L. Phelan, Esq.,
Chief,
Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6434, File 877-5, part 7)
As stated in his letter of July 23rd to Major McKay, Captain Scott authorized a departure by the contractor from their agreement with the Department, in allowing the linoleum to remain in position in three areas which he considered to be "all right", namely the pupils' dining room, the main kitchen and the domestic science kitchen.

Major McKay's letter of August 1st to the Secretary of the Indian Affairs Branch states that the floor and linoleum in the pupils' dining room will be treated as called for in the agreement with the F. W. Beatty Company, but advises that arrangements could be made whereby this basement area could be treated at the same time as the others. He makes no reference to the kitchens.

It was intended that all items in operation No. 2 were to have been carried out continuously; but since other instructions were issued by Captain Scott, necessitating a second trip to Alberni for the workmen, a further charge as mentioned in Major McKay's letter is quite justified. Account must be taken however, of any work omitted under authority of your western officers or the school Principal.

No account for the second operation has yet been submitted, but upon receipt of same the matter of any adjustment in cost which appears necessary will be considered.

Regarding the reported drip from the heating main passing through the pupil's dining room, I may say that the general contractors who built the school have several minor repairs to carry out at the school, which they advise us will be completed this month. They have been requested to investigate the drip from the heating main, and make whatever adjustments are necessary at that time.

Chief Engineer

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 3rd instant and also letters relating to the construction of a door at the Alberni Residential School received by you from Rev. R.C. Scott and Indian Agent Ashbridge.

The desirability of constructing a door such as the one suggested in this correspondence was discussed very fully with the architects of the Department a few months ago. The architects were not persuaded at that time, in view of the fireproof construction of the building, that a door was necessary. The officials of this Division are of the opinion that the construction of this door may lead to a number of disciplinary problems. We have had a number of scandals at Indian residential schools during the last few years and we certainly are not anxious to do anything to create another at Alberni. It would be interesting to know what kind of a lock it is proposed to put on this door, where the key is to be kept etc. Our experience has been that Indian boys and girls are sufficiently ingenious to be able to open almost any door.

However, in view of your recommendation we are prepared to authorize the construction of this door if you yourself are fully persuaded that the door is necessary and that the Principal of the school is prepared to accept full responsibility for the discipline of the pupils who may be affected. It

September 30, 1941.

Sir:

I have the honour to submit the regular Agency Letter, covering conditions within this Agency during month ending September 30, 1941.

Schools:

The Alberni Residential School was inspected and an improvement in the cleanliness was noted, with the exception of the boys' dormitory and storage closets, which were both dirty and untidy.

There were four girls and one boy confined to bed in the infirmary, the boy being suspected of tubercular meningitis and the girls with minor ailments.

The health of the school generally was good, although several were suffering from colds and one boy recovering from measles.

Dining room, kitchens, alleyways and storerooms were tidy and clean.

Dormitories (except the boys) were very tidy and clean, also bath and wash rooms.

Outhouses were in good order and tidy.

Pupils in classrooms were attentive and being well taught.

There is no boys supervisor, and the appearance of the boys leaves very much to be desired, as they were very untidy in dress and dirty in appearance, and also showed great lack of discipline and courtesy.

P.B. Ashbridge

Dear Major MacKay:

I think that the Deputy Fire Marshall when making his inspection of the main building early this year mentioned the fact that there is only one exit from the top three dormitories. If I am not mistaken, Captain Barry also mentioned it. I think we discussed it here in the school.

If there were a fire or a smoke panic which involved either side of the school so that exit could not be made down one of the stairways, the pupils on the middle floor could cross to the side not involved, and find exit, but those on the top floor would not be able to get out at all.

This does not seem right. I feel sure that a doorway could be cut through the linen closet on the boys' side, to open into the dormitory on the girls' side. This would mean going through a tile wall only. Having the closet between the two dormitories would ensure privacy, and yet a satisfactory exit would be possible quickly in case of need. The closet in question is wide and roomy, and any clothing supplies would be to one side on shelves leaving the middle clear and unobstructed.

If the doorway were put through a wall giving access at both sides I am sure there would be a disciplinary problem at once for the temptation to "tap" out messages would at once present itself to the boys and girls. They try it even as it is now, through the main dividing wall, but it is so unsatisfactory that the practice is not at all general.

The only alternative would be to provide fire escapes down from the windows to the top of the roof leading to the assembly hall, and then down to the ground. This would be complicated and unsightly, and would present a temptation to climb up in order to gain entrance to dormitories from the outside. The suggestion above, if approved, would make the present staircases available on each side.

Respectfully submitted:

RCS/

Sir,

I have the honour to submit the regular Agency letter, covering conditions within this Agency during month ending February 28th, 1945.

ALBERNI RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:
With the exception of boys' dormitory on the second floor and passageways, stairways and lockers on the boys' side the remainder of the school was clean, tidy and in good order. Health of the school generally was fairly good, there being ten pupils confined to bed with various minor ailments. Three of these had a skin rash resembling "German" measles, described by Dr. Jones as being of a very mild nature and not contagious. I requested however that they be isolated. The Dispensary was in charge of a young girl pupil, who had free access to medicines, including poisons. These matters were brought to the attention of the Reverend Principal, for correction.

Dear Mr Ashbridge:

Referring to our conversation of this morning, when it was brought to my attention that the Department would like definite undertaking in writing that I would be responsible for proper discipline in connection with the installation of an extra fire door on the upper floor of this school, I beg to say that I shall be glad to be responsible.

I can quite understand the fears of the Department on this point, and generally speaking they are upon good ground.

I would like, however, to point out several things in this connection and I feel that it may help to allay fears with regard to discipline:

1. The two dormitories concerned, are those in which the smallest girls and boys of the school are quartered. This, in itself means much less risk or difficulty with regard to discipline.

2. I do not propose to have any lock on this door, but two barrel bolts on the inside. As you know, this door will lead out of a clothes closet on the boys' side, so that there will be no direct access between the two dormitories. It will be no easier for boys and girls to communicate through this door than it is at present through the separating wall.

3. There will be only the one key to the lock on this clothes cupboard, and it will be in the hands of the Boys' Matron. The lock can, however, be opened by any master key. As the Boys' Overseer, and the Girls' Overseer, and myself, each have master keys, there ought to be no difficulty in having this door opened should occasion arise. In addition, there is an extra master key always kept in my office.

These bolts will make the door secure at all times, and no one is ever allowed in that clothes cupboard, except when the matron or myself are there in connection with the work of the dormitories or re clothing.

To make doubly secure, however, I could place this cupboard on the list of places to be patrolled by our nightly fire patrol. This would take away all possibility of danger, it seems to me.

While the building is fire proof, and this door may never be needed, still in the passing of the years, there is always the possibility that it might be necessary to direct traffic from one side to the other on the upper floor. As things are now, this would be impossible. With the door in access would be immediate and adequate.

I trust that this will be satisfactory to the Department, and that the door may be installed as soon as arrangements can be made.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

RCS/

Dear Mr. Ashbridge:

Dear Dr. McGill:

This will acknowledge receipt of your circular letter under date of February 19th, File:150-65, enclosing copy of a circular letter with reference to precautions against danger of fire.

I beg to say that this letter was read at the staff meeting the day after I received it, and it is now posted in a prominent place in my office.

Fire Drills are practised regularly both from the dormitories and from the classrooms, and a patrol is made at night with special attention to all rooms where there are electric outlets, stoves, irons, etc. Playrooms, classrooms and all areas occupied by pupils during the day, and of course kitchens and boiler room are all inspected. Our exits having crash handles, are always open from the inside. The extra fire door provided by the Department has been installed in the top floor so that there is access now to the stairway on either side should one of them become impassable because of smoke or fire.

Following the suggestion in the second last paragraph of the circular letter, I beg to state that we need a large fire extinguisher of the Guardene type for our Manual Training classroom which has been constructed in the old barn. There is a good cement floor in this barn, but the construction is of course, wood. I would also like a Pyrene Fire Extinguisher for the Junior Classroom which is the

Dear Mr Ashbridge:

I regret that owing to being away on holidays during the first part of July, and then having been alone in the office following my return, I neglected to write in for authority to purchase paints etc for repairs. These items were included in the estimates for this year.

As the only man I had to do the work was not back until the first of the month, this also seemed to delay matters until I found myself short of time for all the work which had to be done. Consequently, I must crave the indulgence of the Department in asking for consideration of these accounts, which I felt I had to incur if we were to get the work done before the return of the pupils at the end of the month.

There are other items which can wait, and I am attaching them, and they can come before the Department in the regular way. I refer to the painting of the front, at least, of the old Bay school building. You will remember this building was to have been taken down or removed. Fortunately nothing was done about it, and we have been using it since we lost our Class Room building, for a Class Room.

It is looking very drab and as we are likely to have to use it for some time, it really should be painted. The end is much worse than the sides. I am having the glass renewed in the front, and the two doors at the inner wall of the porch moved out to the outer wall so that only while school is in session will there be access to the porch or the cloak room behind it. I feel sure this will be beneficial in every way.

If the Department would be good enough to authorize the amount needed for paint, we shall do the work ourselves, if only the materials can be secured before the weather breaks.

Meantime, we shall keep on with what materials we have, and get the Playrooms, corridors etc ready for the re-opening of School at the end of this month.

I shall appreciate any recommendation you may feel free to make in connection with the above, and thank you in anticipation.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Ashbridge:

I beg to bring to your attention, the fact that one of our high tension wires is down today in the field just in front of the school.

The first time this wire broke, the foreman for the National Utilities repair gang, said that the break was due to the intermediate pole between the transformer pole on the top of the hill and the first pole inside of school property, being too short, and this had a tendency to put more strain on the wires.

As there are 2200 volts on this line it ought to be attended to. The National Utilities Corporation inform me that the cost of a new pole, setting up, rewiring and connecting same, would be $53.00 plus tax.

This gentleman also said that he had informed those in charge when the line was first connected to the new school, that this pole was too short and that it was badly rotted at the base, but that nothing was ever done more than to make the temporary connection.

I would appreciate it very much if this matter could be attended to by the Department, as I feel that it is hardly a right charge on the revenue of the school. I have to refer to your letter of October 13th in which you request information with respect to the following items included in the estimates submitted by Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge for the fiscal year 1944-45:

"Ground floor Lino or resurfacing $600.00
Waterproofing portion of outside wall $200.00"

These matters were looked into by me recently while at Alberni and I wish to advise as follows:

1. It is doubtful if the linoleum on the boys' side of the ground floor should be replaced for, despite the action taken to waterproof the cement floor and other protective measures, deterioration of the material continues. This is particularly marked on the side referred to and appears due to moisture coming through the cement floor and water which finds its way under the linoleum when the rooms are washed out, so that unless these causes can be definitely eliminated it would seem to be a waste of public money to replace the present floor covering with linoleum or similar material. Some type of moisture resisting surfacing should be laid on these floors.

2. Waterproofing the outside walls as suggested would not, in my opinion, eliminate the existing trouble. The white substance that appears on the outside face of the upper sections of the walls of the building probably comes from the mortar or brick, most likely the former as the brick used is regarded as being of good quality and resistant to moisture. It is not likely that any substantial increase of this substance on the walls will develop and what is there may in time drop off as part of it is hard and flaky and can be lifted from the surface easily.

(over)
What is much more serious is the condition of some of the walls of the dormitories on the top floor where moisture appears to be getting through from the brick wall to the plaster. I noticed that the top of the coping stone slopes inward towards the roof and my opinion is that much of the rain falling on this surface runs underneath this capping and down through the walls as the copper flashing, which I take is intended to prevent this, is loose in places and may not have been properly set in at the time of construction.

I should like to suggest that the Surveys and Engineering Division be requested to investigate these matters and advise with respect to a suitable surfacing for the section of the basement floor referred to and also the measures needed to deal effectively with the apparent leakage from the coping stone into the walls of the building. In order to provide for the probable costs involved, I would recommend that the items in question be allowed to stand in the estimates.

Memorandum:

Re: Indian Residential School, Alberni, B.C.

With reference to your notation on Dr. McGill's memorandum of November 16th, 1943, with which was forwarded data from the Indian Affairs Branch in connection with ceiling leakages and dampness under basement floor coverings at the above, this Service requested Mr. Webb to arrange for an inspection, and to submit a complete report.

We are now in receipt of a report covering two visits to the institution carried out by Mr. Warren on January 6th and January 26th, 1944 which may be summarized as follows:

(1) Ceiling Leakages

Our officer was taken by the Principal through Girls' Dormitories 3, 4 and 5 on the top floor of the building where intermittent leaks occur during heavy rainstorms. The leakage in Dormitory 3 is apparently active during rains from the south, that in Dormitory 4 during rains from the north, while in Dormitory 5, one leak is active during rains from the north, and another during rainstorms from any direction.

Mr. Warren made a careful examination of the felt and gravel roof covering, the felt roof flashings, the copper parapet flashings and the stone coping. He reports that there is no evidence of leakages in the felt and gravel roof covering, and while the copper parapet flashings have not been installed according to detail, they have been located by expansion and contraction in the parapet, they do not appear to be admitting water except at the flagpole over Dormitory No. 5. He suggests the flagpole should be removed.

Mr. Warren has advanced the opinion that the stone in the copings is absorbent, that due to the very heavy precipitation it has become saturated, and is transmitting water to the walls below. He states that while the brickwork at Alberni is of better quality and better laid than at a number of other British Columbia residential schools, some absorption is taking place in the walls themselves. Mr. Warren considers that all leakages, except under the flagpole, originate in the coping and upper walls, and that some of the water is being expelled at the upper ceilings.

Percolation of dampness from above and a certain amount of absorption of surface water in the lower walls, is causing discoloration and efflorescence on the exterior brickwork in both the school and Principal's residence. While Mr. Warren saw no actual moisture on the inside of exterior walls the painted wall finish is damaged, and efflorescence is visible.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6434, File 877-5, part 7)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
To eliminate absorption, Mr. Warren considers that after cleaning off efflorescence, all exterior brickwork should be treated with a colourless waterproofing, similar to the Tremco, or Minwax product. To prevent infiltration through copings he suggests covering the coping stone with a copper flashing. As an alternative, in view of restrictions on the use of copper, he suggests that a plastic compound might be applied to the coping stones by spray gun, to a thickness of 1/8". Mr. Warren states that the majority of brick buildings in Vancouver have suffered from water infiltration and have been satisfactorily treated by the method he suggests.

Mr. Warren estimates that to waterproof the brickwork, cover the coping with copper flashing, repair existing flashings, apply caulking at window frames, and to provide for engineering expenses, an expenditure of approximately $1000.00 would be required. If plastic compound were applied to copings, and copper omitted, the cost would be $700.00 less, or a total of $4400.00.

In view of the cost involved, and since in his opinion most of the trouble originates in the coping stones and penthouse wells, Mr. Warren recommends immediate consideration be given to completely waterproofing the penthouse walls, covering all copings either with copper or plastic compound, removing the flagpole, and covering over the recesses which it stands. He states that the work should be carried out in midsummer when the walls have had a chance to dry out. His estimate of cost for this work is $2200.00, or $1500.00 if plastic compound is used on the copings instead of copper. He considers the remainder of the work could wait until results were observed, and additional funds were available.

(2) Basement Dampness

Mr. Warren inspected the basement accommodation where moisture is reported to be causing damage to the linoleum floor covering and reports that trouble is occurring in the Boys' Locker and Recreation Rooms, the Pupils' Dining Room and Bathrooms. In spite of waterproofing treatment applied three years ago to these areas, moisture is apparent when the linoleum covering is lifted. Where the cement floor finish has not been covered and where linoleum has been removed the cement gives no evidence of dampness. Mr. Warren is of the opinion that water is finding its way under the basement slab from sloping higher ground to the north and west of the building, but states he can give no assurance that conditions can be improved.

He suggests however that an intercepting ditch be dug and revetted at the toe of the slope, and that four catch basins connected to the existing drainage system be constructed north of the school to provide surface drainage. These works with attendant grading and landscaping will cost Mr. Warren estimates will cost approximately $930.00. He states that if this work was undertaken tests to establish the necessity of sub-soil drainage could be carried out at the same time.

Regarding floor finish for rooms affected by dampness Mr. Warren has investigated and supplied costs for a number of products. He suggests however that no decision be made in this connection until exterior surface drainage has been carried out and results observed. Meantime he suggests the linoleum be removed and stored for possible future use. The floors cleaned and left bare. Mr. Warren estimates that to clean the floors, it would cost 2½ cents per square foot plus $50.00 for moving furniture, amounting in all to approximately $162.00.
On the basis of the foregoing, the minimum total estimated cost for operations that Mr. Warren recommends should be carried out this summer would be:

(a) Application of waterproofing to penthouse walls, repairs to existing flashings and treatment of copings with copper covering.................. $200.00

(b) Surface drainage works............................. $50.00

(c) Removing linoleum, cleaning floors etc., in basement.............................................. $168.00

(d) Engineer's expenses and contingencies.............. $300.00

Total $3498.00

If a plastic compound were used on copings the total estimated cost would be $700.00 less, or...... $2792.00

Mr. Webb has concurred in Mr. Warren's suggestions and recommendations.

Upon consideration of Mr. Warren's report, we may say that it confirms our opinion that water is being admitted at the top of the walls, and that in all coastal areas copings should be of copper in the future.

Regarding the damp areas in the basement, it is possible that installation of surface drainage works would improve conditions; but in view of the cost involved without assurance of satisfaction, the expenditure is not considered justifiable. It is felt that until the results of leaving the cement finish exposed have been observed, this portion of the work should be deferred.

In view of all the circumstances, it is felt that during the coming summer, when the walls have thoroughly dried out work covering items (a), (c) and (d) in the above list of operations should be carried out omitting item (b).

It is felt that if resculking of window and door frames is necessary, it should be included in work carried out this summer. Mr. Warren's estimate for this item is $220.00

On this basis the total cost including supervision, would be approximately $2828.00, and it is considered advisable that this amount be made available to this Service by the Indian Affairs Branch. If wartime restrictions prevent the use of copper in the work the actual expenditure would be approximately $2200.00

If work is to be carried out, we should be authorized to purchase materials and engage labour to the best advantage locally.

Chief Engineer.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

In response to a request received by the Superintendent of Welfare and Training from the Chief Executive Assistant, I am sending forward herewith copies of memoranda relating to certain repairs which appear to be urgently needed at the Alberni Indian Residential School.

Dr. Dorey, in a letter dated April 20, 1944, expressed a desire to discuss with the Minister ways and means of dealing with the deficit that has accumulated at this school. Mr. W. R. Butchart, in his last audit report on this school, states that the net overdraft at the bank at that time amounted to $3,633.56 and that, in addition, there were other liabilities, including unpaid salaries for December, making a total of $5,351.74. The authorized enrolment at the Alberni School is 225 and per capita grant is at the rate of $170.00.

I have reviewed, somewhat hurriedly, the audit reports on a number of our residential schools. I am disposed to think that a substantial number of our schools do not differ to any appreciable extent, so far as deficits are concerned, from the Alberni institution. In this connection may I refer to my memorandum to you dated November 25, 1943, and particularly to a letter received by the Chief of the Training Division from the Principal of the St. Mary's Indian Residential School, Mission, British Columbia, sent forward therewith.

The Principal of the St. George's Residential School, Lytton, B. C., where a per capita grant of $180.00
is paid, stated in a letter dated December 26, 1942:

"I feel sure the Department realize that the present financial assistance we receive is quite inadequate to meet the needs of present day demands. The only way I know of to make that financial assistance suffice is to cut down on the food and clothing received by the pupils and put more boys to work instead of hiring extra labour. But we should not do these things; at least I would rather leave than do them. The 50¢ a day which we receive as our per capita allowance seems altogether too small, compared with $2.00 per day or more allowed at hospitals."

Mr. W. R. Butchart, in his last audit report on the Sandy Bay Residential School, dated October 25, 1942, states:

"The cost of operation per pupil per year works out at $206.35, an increase of $26.03 over the operating costs for the preceding year. The rate of increase is even larger than this figure would indicate, as the average pupilage of 98.8 is up 9.2. The only apparent liabilities, other than August accounts, were arrears in salaries. At the end of August $1,250 was owing to the Oblate Fathers on account of the principal's and assistant principal's salaries. There was also an amount of $440 owing to the Sisters."

The per capita grant at this school is $165.

In his report on the Peigan R.C. Residential School, dated May 7, 1942, Mr. Butchart states:

"The cost of operation per day was up $4.38. The cost of operation per pupil per year was quite high at $224.50, an increase of $28.56. This increase may be traced to increased farm costs, clothing, etc. Per capita grant allowed at this school is $165."

There has been a substantial increase in the cost of providing food, clothing, education and shelter for Indian pupils at residential schools during the last couple of years. A rough estimate would place this cost at approximately $20.00 per pupil. I should point out that these deficits have been accruing despite the fact
that an additional $10.00 per pupil has been paid during the last two years. The records indicate that the Department has never at any time during the last 30 years assumed responsibility for a deficit at a residential school, and I am not at all sure that we should accept responsibility in the case of Alberni. It is just possible that the churches may be able to reduce these deficits somewhat when they receive the $15.00 per pupil cost-of-living bonus during the present calendar year. However, repairs are urgently needed at a number of our schools. The non-Catholic schools have experienced difficulty in securing the staff necessary to carry on. A very disturbing feature of our residential school work is the number of principals that have recently resigned: Rev. Father M. de Bretagne, Qu'Appelle School, Lebret, Sask.; Rev. Father J. P. Mackey, Shubenacadie Residential School, Nova Scotia; Rev. C. N. Middleton, Elkhorn Residential School, Elkhorn, Manitoba; Rev. R. T. Chapin, Brandon Residential School, Brandon, Manitoba; and Rev. R. C. Scott, Alberni Residential School, Alberni, British Columbia.

The suggestion has been made from time to time and emphasized in a memorandum dated May 31, 1940, prepared by the Superintendent of Welfare and Training, that an attempt should be made to maintain a number of residential schools where these schools are most urgently needed, even though we had to close a number of the older and more dilapidated schools in order to do so. This is a matter that might well be discussed with representatives of the churches at a conference called for this purpose.

In respect to conditions at Alberni, we have not, as you are no doubt aware, an inspector of Indian schools in British Columbia at this time. In view of all the circumstances, however, it might be advisable to have Mr. F. E. Anfield, Indian Agent at Bella Coola, who has had years of experience as a teacher and as principal of a residential school, make a thorough investigation of the school, in association with Indian Commissioner MacKay. Such investigation should undoubtedly be made and certain recommendations, with respect to the future, considered before a final decision is reached with respect to the best ways of dealing with the deficit.

Director.

Memorandum:

Re: Roof Repairs, Indian Residential School, Alberni, British Columbia

As you are aware, work is now being carried out at the above, to prevent water infiltration through the copings and parapet walls. When operations connected with resetting of copper flashings were started under the supervision of Mr. Warren, it was discovered that decomposition had begun in several areas of the wooden roof deck. Mr. Webb reported this matter, and was authorized by this office to carry out repairs to the roof deck to an amount of $185.00 which was possible from funds transferred to us for the project by Indian Affairs. He was requested to advise this office if this amount would be sufficient.

When the known areas were opened up, Mr. Warren was able to inspect the underside of the whole roof deck, and found that extensive deterioration has occurred, adjacent to the parapets and pent house. Evidence of dampness is visible in other areas; but Mr. Warren is taking measures to prevent decay of the deck in these places by the installation of roof vents. While the felt and gravel roof was reported to be sound, repairs to the deck have necessitated lifting a considerable amount of the covering. Most of the needed replacement of deck tiles has already been carried out, and the felt and gravel roof remains otherwise unaffected. On the 29th ultimo, one area had still to be investigated. To cover the cost of all repairs required, Mr. Webb estimates an additional amount of $800.00 will be necessary.

It is recommended that this amount be made available by the Indian Affairs Branch for the work.

We expect to be advised shortly that all work on the roof and copings at the school has been completed.

Chief Engineer.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
October 19th, 1944.

Dr. McGill

Re: Roof Repairs, Indian Residential School, Alberni, British Columbia

I enclose herewith a memorandum from Mr. Mills in regard to the above work and from which you will note that when certain sections of the roof deck were opened up, it was found that extensive decay had set in and that to replace the wooden sections affected, a further expenditure of $800 was required. In view of the conditions found our Engineer, Mr. Warren, had no choice but to make the necessary repairs and replacements.

In a discussion with Mr. Mills this morning he advises me that further details have now been received and that an additional amount of $600 will be sufficient to pay for the extra work. It will be appreciated, therefore, if this additional amount could be made available which would bring the total for roof repairs to $3,993.50.

Mr. Mills states that the construction details of the roof coping have been fully discussed with our Architect, Mr. Buck, and in future metal flashing work will be extended to prevent any similar occurrence. Our Architect feels that the original construction details were sound if first-class workmanship is obtained, but at the present time there is always the possibility of some defect in the stone coping work that may result in leaks and damages later on.

There has recently been considerable correspondence between this Office, Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge and the Rev. A. E. Caldwell, Principal of the Alberni Indian Residential School, regarding requirements in the way of desks, beds, and mattresses at the School.

From information received, it would appear that the authorized pupilage at the School is 225 and the present enrollment is 228. Beds in good order at the School number 201 and additional desks required total 24.

Mr. Ashbridge's letter of September 19th in this connection is attached hereto and, although it is stated that 23 mattresses are required for replacements, Mr. Caldwell recently informed me that it will be possible to do without these for another year. It will be noted that these requirements are based on a probable increase in the authorized pupilage but, aside from this, it would appear that there are not sufficient beds at the School to provide sleeping accommodation for the present enrollment.

Quotations on beds and mattresses from Simmons Ltd. and the Restmore Manufacturing Co. are attached hereto, together with a quotation from the Clarke & Stuart Co. Ltd. on desks. The Globe Manufacturing Co. are unable to quote on the latter item. The requirements as listed in Mr. Ashbridge's letter have been revised somewhat, and may now be itemized, as follows:

- 35 Beds, complete with mattresses, 30 x 72.
- 24 Desk Units, No. 3.
Based on the Restmore Manufacturing Co. quotation, the cost of the beds will be $618.75 (mattresses in ACB ticking) and on Simmons Ltd. quotation the cost would be $577.50 (Croydon Mattress) but, judging from the illustrations attached the Restmore Mfg. Co. Ltd. bed is somewhat better quality. The 24 desk units will cost $194.64, making a minimum cost of $772.14, f.o.b. Vancouver, for all requirements.

Although no provision was made in the Estimates for this expenditure, I would recommend that some, if not all, of the above listed items be purchased, subject to the Department's attitude towards increasing the authorized pupilage at the School and providing funds are available.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Dr. Dorey:

The Invoices and Statements, with cheques showing payment, which are going forward today are the ones which make up the $2315.52 spent on Building and Repairs from March 1st, 1941 to Feb. 28th, 1943, and the $217.90 spent under the same heading from March 1st, 1943 to January 31st, 1944. Though you suggested we send invoices and receipts for building and repairs for the rest of this year, we cannot do this unless we secure duplicates from the firms, as we need the originals and the cheques for the Auditor. We shall be digging into them to see just what the expenditures were for a little later.

As Mr. Caldwell has mentioned in his letter, we have deducted some amounts as not really Building and Repair expenditures. This is particularly so with our accounts with hardware companies, and we have deducted such things as electric light bulbs. Also, the expenditures on the "Dawn" have been deducted, in so far as we could locate them. In other instances we have charged to Building and Repairs amounts which were put under Household Equipment on these invoices. This was partly necessary because an invoice would be marked a certain amount for B.& R. with no check marks showing which came into the amount. We have therefore marked what we now think is chargeable, and it has often made a larger figure, and often a smaller one. Therefore, though the Cash Book entries for this period (March 1st, 1941 - Jan. 31st, 1944) total $2551.42, the revised total is $2214.63. These deductions have all been indicated on the covering page for each invoice.

We have extracted from the cash book the name of the firm; the amount for Building and Repairs; and the House Equipment Manual Training and other expense if all paid by the same cheque and on the same invoice; and put the cheque number, its full amount, and the date it was issued. This is being sent in quadruplicate, and is an accurate statement of all expenses for B. & R. as checked by the Auditor. Because there were two audits, the extracts are in two sections.

We could have left all the invoices in this order, i.e. as in the extracts. But it would have scattered the invoices for each firm all over the place. Mr. Scott felt it would be better to do the final job with each firm's invoices together, and it has proven the best system. May I say here that Mr. Scott did a great deal to nail down invoices to particular jobs, and remark invoices where the B.& R. amounts were indefinite.

I trust that these invoices are now in shape for the Department to consider a claim for a refund. Should there be other information required, I shall do all I can to supply it.

Sincerely,

(sgd.) Clyde Woollard.

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, enclosing account covering the cost of paint and materials purchased for repairs at the Alberni Residential School during the summer of 1944. I discussed this account with Mr. Hoey and it has been decided to return it, unpaid. It appears from the correspondence that no authority was given for this expenditure, and, as you are aware, it is simply impossible for us to control our appropriation if principals of residential schools assume authority for making expenditures that have not been authorized.

For your information, I may say that the Reverend Dr. Dorey, Associate Secretary of the United Church Home Mission Board, recently visited the Department, and it was decided to pay amounts covering expenditure incurred for repairs and improvements at this school during the period March 1, 1941, to January 31, 1944. These total $2,814.53. However, it was also distinctly understood that in paying these accounts it would not be a precedent for the payment of future accounts incurred without authority. I therefore return the accounts which you forwarded with your letter.

I have yours of February 8th, which, in spite of any desire which I might have to argue with you or with the Treasury Board, I must say is reasonable.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

Re: Repairs and Equipment - Alberni Residential School.

May I refer to your letter dated October 13, 1944, addressed by you to Mr. C. W. Jackson.

You may remember that itemized statements of expenditures made by the Principal of the Alberni School during the years 1941-42-43, were sent forward with that letter.

In view of the difficulty we have experienced since the receipt of that letter in obtaining the authority necessary before payments could be made, I have been wondering if you would care to emphasize when writing to the Principals of your Residential Schools the desirability of having all vouchers for expenditures at their schools submitted prior to March 31st in each fiscal year. The representative of the Treasury Board with whom I have discussed this matter expressed the hope that all such expenditures would, in future, be paid in full during the fiscal year in which they were actually incurred. He pointed out that it was exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, to disburse Parliamentary appropriations at all equitably if the practice which appears to have been adopted during the last two or three years at Alberni became at all common.

In this connection, I pointed out to the official that conditions at Alberni have been somewhat unusual and that the

Re: Water Supply - Alberni Indian Residential School

Dear Dr. Dorey:

I am enclosing copies of four letters regarding the water supply to the school. As you will see, we were paying a flat rate of $27.50 per month. The Town of Alberni, our source of supply, apparently passed a bye-law basing the rate on meter reading. Mr. Warren, from the Engineering Branch, spent a great deal of time here last fall trying to locate a water supply for the school and the adjacent reserve. It is apparent that the change in rate was known to him then, yet nothing whatever was said to me about it. The account for January, amounting to $100.40, was the first intimation I received of the advance.

If this matter is entirely in the hands of the Engineering Branch...that is, the matter of water supply for the school, is it reasonable for this Branch to obligate the school to such an item of expenditure without at least notifying us, or even to so obligate us with notification? Further, if the water supply for the school is one of the functions of this Branch, and if it alone is responsible to the Department of Indian Affairs for such supply, (as appears from the fact that the school was ignored in any negotiation) why was not a definite agreement made by this Branch with the source of supply at the time the school was built? Mr. Warren advises me that he knows of no such agreement. This places us at the complete mercy of our source of supply as to both the supply of water and the expense of such supply, and also places the school under the necessity of assuming, out of revenue funds, any obligation the Engineering Branch sees fit to burden us with. The whole thing looks "screwy" to me.

The local engineer for the Town water supply told me today that Mr. Warren told him that his investigations last fall into a separate source of water supply for the school and the reserve showed it would cost about $32,000.00 to put one in. Who was going to stand this expense? Certainly not the school. If, therefore, it was the intention of the Government to assume such expense to provide us with a water supply, why should not the Government assume the cost of the present water supply, at least over and above a reasonable cost which the school can afford to pay?

(Signed) A. E. Caldwell
Indian Residential School, Alberni.

Dear Mr. Warren:

I wonder if you have any record of any agreement entered into between the school and the Town of Alberni regarding water rates. We have apparently been paying a flat rate of $27.50 per month. Without notifying us (until they sent the January account) apparently a bye-law was passed establishing a charge by meter reading which puts our charge up to $100.40 for the month of January. Probably our summer consumption would be higher than the present, but we can figure on an expense of $1200.00 a year for water alone. This would be prohibitive to school finances.

I scarcely think that the Department would make a definite hook-up to any utility without some agreement as to continuity and cost of supply, otherwise we are completely at the mercy of the vendor.

Will you please advise me re this and whether it comes within the scope of your Department?

With kindest regards,

Yours sincerely,

(sgd.) A.E. Caldwell
Principal.
Dear Sir:

Regarding the new water rates of the Town of Alberni, we had some correspondence with the town a few months ago in which they advised us that there would be a new rate structure commencing the first of January this year. From that we gathered that your rate would be somewhat higher than you were paying last year. However, it was not realised that the increase now in effect would be as high as the account you have enclosed shows.

We have no information as to any agreement in effect between the Town and the Indian Affairs Branch. If there is such an agreement, most likely the Indian Agent or the Indian Commissioner would be in possession of a copy. I understand the school has been taking water from the Town of Alberni for at least 25 years so that any agreement would have been entered into prior to that time. Possibly if you would take up the matter direct with the Council, you might secure some alleviation owing to the fact that you convey the water from their pipeline to your property.

The consumption of water amounts to about 20,000 gallons per day or approximately 100 gallons per head. This would appear to be rather a high rate for a single building. Possibly it would be desirable to investigate the pipelines at the institution in order to determine if this high rate is due to leaks. A very small leak would run away with several thousand gallons per day and in the soil around the school such a leak would not be in evidence on the surface.

Yours very truly,

C.E. Webb
District Chief Engineer.

per W.C. Warren.

Mr. W.C. Warren,
Engineering Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Mr. Warren:

Re File 33615-1 Water Supply

I have your letter of Feb. 6th, replying to my advice to you re the enormous increase in the water rates of the school in January - from $27.50 flat rate monthly to $100.40 meter rate for the month of January. I have been trying to get in touch with some responsible party in connection with the water supply from the Town of Alberni and just today succeeded in talking to Mr. McGillivray, who appears to be in charge of the water system.

Mr. McGillivray tells me that your computation of 20,000 galls a day, which seemed to me to be impossible (and which you said was "rather high") is not an excessive rate of consumption. In fact, he tells that the minimum consumption allowed on the system is 60 galls per day per capita. The consumption runs from that rate up to 500 galls per capita. Our rate is about 77 galls per capita, not including the farm stock.

Mr. McGillivray also tells me that he has been reading the meter attached just off the Town main pipe line, leading to the school, for the past six months, and that he had discussed the school water consumption with you. In your letter you say that there has been correspondence between your Department and the Town regarding the new rate structure commencing the last of January. As the school is apparently expected to discharge the expense of water supply out of the maintenance revenue, I cannot understand why we were not advised about the change, and the probable enormous increase in cost, until we received the January rate account.

It is the opinion of the town engineer that there is no pipe leak on school property and that the water consumption is not excessive. We may reasonably expect a somewhat larger consumption during the summer months. Therefore we can estimate a water expense of from $1200.00 to $1400.00 per year. With our present revenue this expense is prohibitive. If no agreement was entered into between your Department and the Town of Alberni when this present school was built and connected to the town water supply the school can have no guarantee of a continuous supply or a sustained rate. I do not know what department would have the function of establishing a utility agreement, but it seems to me that when we have a known and set income for maintenance purposes, we should also have a known and set rate on utilities.

I mentioned the matter of some possible alleviation to Mr. McGillivray, as you suggested, by reason of the fact that we convey the water from the Town pipeline to our property, a fact of which I was not aware and which further obligates the school to the upkeep of this intake line, and responsibility for any leakages therein, but he said the rate
struck was by the Utilities Commission and approved by the W.P.T. Board. How this increase in rate can be reconciled with the war-time principle of the stabilization of prices, I do not know.

I would be glad to have any suggestions you may be able to offer re the whole situation.

Yours very truly,

(sgd.) A. E. Caldwell
Principal.

P.S. - It has further been brought to my attention that some of the Indian people resident on the Sheehaht Reserve, adjacent to the school, take their water from the school pipe line having outlet at the barn. While we were on a flat rate this was a matter of little importance.

A.E.C.
