November 9, 1945.

Re: Classroom Building,
Indian Residential School, Alberni, B.C.

With reference to the memorandum of the 12th ultimo from the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch bearing your notation of the 16th ultimo in regard to the re-construction of the above building, the original plans prepared by this Service have been studied by our architects and comment is made as follows:

The cloak rooms were placed between the Hall and Classrooms, but where a similar plan was proposed for use for Indian Day Schools in the Maritime Provinces, we were requested by Indian Affairs to change the position of the cloak rooms to the opposite ends of the classrooms. It is considered that a similar change would be desirable in the Alberni School Classroom Building. It is not thought that any other changes are necessary.

The original drawings can be used therefore, with only the small revisions in plans and elevations necessitated in the changed position of the cloak rooms.

The specifications however, must be re-written, as the original specifications cover the combined construction of both the Residential Building and Classroom Building.

In connection with the decision by Indian Affairs to proceed with work on the building this year, we may say that very little progress will have been made by March 31st next, and it is a certainty that practically all funds made available will have to be re-voted next year.

However, unless instructed to the contrary, this Service will request Mr. Webb in Vancouver to have the site examined and a report prepared for the purpose of establishing whether the existing foundations, basement floor slab, or any of the subsurface drainage can be re-used in new work.

A re-draft of the specification is now being written, subject to modifications that may be necessary upon receipt of our officer's report.

If our suggested action is approved, we will submit a list of newspapers serving the area, through which tenders for the project might be invited.

Dear Mr. Gibson:

I am in receipt of your letter of January 19, with reference to the classroom building that it is proposed to erect at the Alberni Residential School, to replace the one destroyed by fire.

I have discussed your suggestion with the departmental officials and they recommend that the same type of building be constructed as previously. This building is only intended for classroom purposes and I am informed that many schools throughout British Columbia are not of fireproof construction. The proposed new building will have asbestos siding and will be heated from the main building. Consequently the likelihood of fire is greatly reduced.

My officials also point out that if any radical change were made at the present time, it would involve new plans and specifications and there would be a considerable delay in the completion of the building.

However, I am requesting the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch to send a copy of your letter to the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, in order that the matter may be again reviewed before construction commences.

I, too, regret that we did not meet on my recent Coast trip but I enjoyed the visit and the weather was up to the Coast's best, for Christmas.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Classroom Building, Indian Residential School, Alberni, B.C.

Following your instructions of January 4, an inspection was made of the residential school building and the remaining foundations of the classroom building at the above mentioned school on January 7 to January 10.

Mr. J. D. Nicol, Chief Engineer of the Marwell Construction Company Limited, and Mr. W. Watt, President of the Acme Plumbing and Heating Service, were also at the inspection and their reports are submitted as appendices to this memorandum.

Classroom Building - Indian Residential School, Alberni, B.C.

This building was erected in 1939-1940 by the Marwell Construction Company Limited of Vancouver, at the same time as the Residential School on the reserve which lies along the river approximately three miles from Alberni, as shown on Plan No. 1. The classroom building of frame construction was completely destroyed by fire in 1941, shortly after it had been completed. The only remaining parts of the building are the concrete walls, concrete basement floor and concrete footings.

This report will answer the questions asked in the letter from Mr. Mills, dated November 23, 1945.

a. "Will it be possible to re-use any of the existing concrete walls or footings with safety?"

Concrete Walls

The walls were constructed 12 inches thick without any reinforcement being used. From the ground level to the top of the walls they are very badly cracked, especially
near the corners of the building, where some have opened up to one-half inch in places. In one place between window openings, the wall has crumbled so badly that it has completely disappeared.

Below the sill level of the windows to the level of the floor numerous cracks can be seen in the walls and they have been very badly pitted in large areas from the excessive heat of the fire to a maximum depth of four and one-quarter inches.

From the above I have come to the conclusion the walls should be cut off at floor level, which is approximately two and one-half feet below ground level.

Attached, as Appendix I, is the report of Mr. Nicol of the Marwell Construction Company, which agrees with the above conclusion.

Footings

The concrete footings have not been harmed in any way by the fire; therefore, if the same type of frame building is to be reconstructed, they may be used with safety as before.

Concrete Floor

The half of the floor which is nearest to the residential building is in quite good shape. The surface of the other half has spalled badly in quite large areas. It is believed that a new floor surface should be laid over the entire original floor.

b. "What demolition work, removal of debris, etc. will be necessary?"

The basement has already been completely cleared of debris under the direction of the School authorities. The only work necessary now is the removal of the concrete walls as mentioned in Paragraph "a" above.
c. "Could new openings in concrete walls be cut with safety if required, for additional double doors in end walls?"

Since it is suggested that the present existing walls should not be used again, this question has not been dealt with.

d. "If, upon examination, existing concrete walls appear fit for re-use, report on what treatment would be required (if any) for re-surfacing."

As previously suggested, a new floor surface should be placed over the existing basement floor. No additional work is required on the footings. The balance of the concrete work should be removed.

Conclusions on Concrete

1. Concrete walls to be cut off at the present basement floor level.

2. New walls poured on top of cut-off, doweled to footing to increase strength.

3. Present basement floor to be well cleaned with water and wire brush before new covering poured. Suggest a two-inch floor surface which would cover the new cold water supply pipes, which may be laid over existing concrete floor.

The existing floor could be grooved to hold these pipes. It is believed that it would be quicker to lay new pipes than to test and repair the ones now buried in the existing floor.

4. Some water-proofing material should be placed on top of present floor and around the bottom of the new walls.

5. New floor surface to be placed forming a water-tight joint around walls.

e. "Have any of the buried drainage lines been damaged, or become blocked?"

During the inspection of the classroom building it was raining especially hard and all drains were working with
the exception of one. It is believed this one, which is
the floor drain nearest the residential school, could be
cleared very easily with a proper clean-out rod. It was
tried by using a piece of pipe, but the block must be past
the first turn as the pipe wouldn't reach it.

It is believed all the soil drains do work as the
surface of the ground around the building was kept
comparatively dry, although there was quite a downpour at
the time.

All the toilet sewers are completely open and work
well.

f. "Provide a detailed sketch of the flow and return piping at
the boilers and circulating pumps in the Residential
Building, showing all valves, air vents and piping sizes."

Shown on attached Plan No. 2.

g. "Make a careful examination of all existing cast-iron
radiators. If any of these appear fit for re-use, prepare
a list showing the number of columns, number of sections
and their height. This will be necessary in replacing any
old units in new positions."

At the time of the inspection the radiators had
been removed from the site of the classroom building and
had been stored under a shelter in a field approximately
300 yards distant. This fact made it very difficult to test
them as they had to be carried to a water line by hand. Mr.
Watt of the Home Plumbing and Heating Service suggested
testing one of them with 30 lbs. water pressure and then
having the rest tested by a man on the site who was familiar
with boiler work.

The above was done. The radiator which was tested
on the day of the inspection was found to be in good con-
dition. A few of the radiators were found to have broken
or cracked columns caused probably when the classroom
building collapsed.
5.

Attached at Appendix II is a report from Mr. A. E. Caldwell, Principal of the Indian Residential School, indicating the results of the tests on the radiators.

Those radiators, which are to be used again in the proposed new building, will require a complete scrubbing with wire brushes and sprayed with paint. At the present time they are in a very rusty condition.

h. "Provide a detailed sketch of the boxed trench or conduit through which supply and return hot water heating lines were carried to the Classroom Building. Give sizes, and type of insulation as used in construction, and state what amount of the boxed trench can be re-used, also state what additional piping, such as hot and cold water, electrical conduit, etc., was installed therein."

The conduit which contains the pipes running from the residential building to the classroom building is of a concrete box construction with 4-inch walls and floor, and with a 2-inch cedar plank cover. The attached Plan No. 3 shows the construction of this conduit. The only insulation used in the construction appears to be a lining of ½-inch boards with a bituminous paper between them and the concrete. This information was furnished by the Marwell Construction Company, and it is borne out by inspection of either end of the trench.

The conduit appears to be in good condition, except for the six feet of it adjoining the remains of the classroom building. The lining of the trench for this six-foot distance has been charred badly from the heat of the fire, also the insulation on the pipes for some six feet requires replacement.

1. "Obtain pipe sizes for hot and cold water lines carried to Classroom Building, and show by sketch where they have been disconnected from system."

As shown on the attached Plan No. 4.

The following pipes are in the conduit:-
1. One - ½-inch hot water supply to classroom building, insulated with 3-ply asbestos air cell covering. This supply is shut off by a valve situated over the hot water boiler in the residential building.

2. Two - 2½-inch return and supply for radiators in the classroom building. These two pipes are also insulated with 3-ply asbestos air cell covering. Both these pipes are shut off by valves in the boiler room of the residential school and are shown on the attached plan.

3. One - 1½ inch cold water supply to classroom building. This pipe is turned off by means of a valve situated at end of conduit in the basement floor of classroom building.

4. One - 2 inch cold water supply which it is reported by the contractors was the fire protection supply for the building and is at maximum town pressure. This pipe also supplies water to the barn on the property, and is connected to the 2 inch main at some point between the two school buildings. There is a valve which can shut off this supply at the entrance of the conduit in the residential building, but it is left open so that water may be supplied to the barn. At the present time the 2 inch pipe has been "plugged" at the classroom end of the conduit, which allows a water supply to the barn to be maintained.

Neither of the cold water pipes have any insulation on them through the length of the conduit. They are buried about one and one-half feet which gives sufficient frost protection in this district.
j. "Obtain from a reliable source, what boiler water temperatures should be carried under cold weather conditions, and upon what bases the heating piping sizes were determined, so that a proper balance may be established between the two buildings in the re-design of work for the new Classroom Building."

The attached letter from Mr. William Watt of the Acme Plumbing and Heating Service as Appendix III answers this question.

Further Information on Boilers

The hot water heating system is supplied by two "Supreme Two Pass Steel Tubular Type Boilers", size 42 inches by 84 inches by 57 inches, Nos. 3960 and 3961. Each has a horsepower rating of 31. These boilers are authorized for a pressure of 20 lbs. per square inch.

The engineer in charge of the boiler room at the school reports that the highest temperature at which the boilers were ever kept was 145 degrees during one very cold week.

Generally the boilers are kept at temperatures of 130 degrees in winter and 125 degrees during summer.

The hot water supply for the building is a steam boiler No. 44912, size 36 inches by 10 feet by 58 inches, with a horsepower rating of 35.5.

Re: Basement water leakage

Dear Sir,

Reporting further on the telephone conversation with you recently relative to a cold water pipe leakage under the cement floor of the school basement and kitchens, I wish to advise that repairs have now been completed by L.A. Hanna, Plumber, Port Alberni.

On Monday, Feb. 11th, a leakage appeared from the cement wall of the students' kitchen, behind a built-in cupboard. The cupboard was removed and water leakage discovered from broken hollow bricks forming part of the side wall. This was traced to the cold water lead-in to the kitchen sink. A 3/4" galvanized pipe evidently led from the water main and was laid about one foot under the cement floor. No plans were obtainable showing the cold water system. Mr. Ashbridge, the Indian Agent, was notified and he came to examine the leak on Tuesday afternoon. In the meantime a plumber had been called in, at Mr. Ashbridge's suggestion, to investigate the leak. The water appeared to be coming from under the floor and Mr. Ashbridge instructed that, if the leak was not found on Tuesday, no further work was to be done until instructions were received from the Engineer's Branch.

No instructions were received and the Commissioner's office was communicated with by phone, and instructions received to proceed with the repairs, pending search for plans of the water system.

The kitchen floor was dug up and the 3/4 inch galvanized pipe uncovered. Several leads were found; the pipe in question, about 15 feet in extent to the main, was found to be completely corroded from the outside, with a number of holes through which there was considerable leakage under pressure. The opinion of the plumber was that the nature of the ground which the leaking pipe traversed was responsible for the corrosion, although a similar pipe, leading from the main to the staff kitchen in the opposite
direction (about one foot of which was uncovered) did not appear to be similarly corroded.

A copper pipe was installed to replace the one corroded and leaking, and the trench across the kitchen floor re-filled with cement.

In the absence of a blue-print of the cold water system, the following appears to be the operating of the system, as far as the pipes laid under the floor is concerned: The intake from the main supply comes through the outer wall in front of the school and then proceeds overhead into the boiler room. From there the main, a 2" cast pipe, returns under the floor to the kitchens, with (as far as the kitchens are concerned) four 3/4" galvanized lead-off pipes... one to the student's kitchen sink (the one repaired), one to the staff kitchen, one to the bake-room and one to the vegetable room. The latter three run in the opposite direction to the one just repaired.

The question arises, first of all, as to why these pipes were installed under the ground when there appears to be no necessity for so doing, and also, if it is the nature of the ground that has corroded the galvanized pipe just removed, the other similar pipes mentioned above will inevitably give trouble until replaced with copper piping.

I may say, in explanation as to why the leakage first showed through the wall of the building, that the leaking water was apparently forced along the floor under the cement and found this outlet through several hollow bricks that had evidently been broken when built into the wall.

To remove the water from the floor of the basement, the kitchens and the distill room, it was necessary to dig down outside the wall to the tile drain, remove one tile, then put a hole through the wall to allow the water to escape.

Yours very truly,

"H. H. Caldwell"

Principal.

Re: Alberni Indian Residential School

I have your letter of January 30th, 1946, regarding the construction of a classroom block at the above noted school to replace the building destroyed by fire in 1941.

Although I should like to see the new classroom building of fireproof construction, principally because of the added security we would have against a repetition of what occurred in 1941, I should say that what is really necessary is more classroom accommodation than was provided in the old structure.

If we are to provide for full school day instruction, which I should say is desirable, instead of the half-day system now in operation, the new building should have six or seven classrooms. In discussing this point with Dr. Morrison, Provincial School Inspector for the Alberni District, following his inspection of the existing setup in the spring of last year, he expressed himself very definitely in favour of a seven classroom block or wing, suggesting the division of the grades as follows:

- Grade IA - 1 teacher
- Grade IB - 1 teacher
- Grade II - 1 teacher
- Grade III - 1 teacher
- Grade IV - 1 teacher
- Grades V & VI - 1 teacher
- Grades VII & VIII - 1 teacher
In order to give a modern school program, permitting full school days, it is difficult to see how we could get along with less than six classrooms with a total enrolment of 225 such as we have at Alberni. Should a seventh classroom be required, the space necessary for this could no doubt be provided from existing accommodation in the main building. In addition to classroom requirements, gymnasium and manual training accommodation should also be provided. These two latter divisions should probably be housed in a separate building well away from the classrooms in order to avoid interference with the work there.

I enclose herewith a copy of a letter received from Principal Caldwell regarding the proposed new classroom block at Alberni.

It is most unfortunate that this Province continues to be deprived of the services of a School Inspector, especially at a time when consideration is being given to the important matter immediately before us and in view of the pressing need for school surveys in various Agencies preliminary to the construction of new schools, and other related matters. Without these services our teachers are not receiving the guidance so essential to their work and this office cannot have proper administrative contact with the schools, and the whole Indian education setup here is suffering as a consequence. The long drawn out delay in making this important appointment is indeed difficult to understand.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

Re: Proposed Classroom Construction, Alberni

Mr. J. L. Gibson, M.P. has shown me a letter he received from the Hon. J. A. Glen in reply to an enquiry from Mr. Gibson as to the construction of the new class-rooms at the Alberni School. The Hon. Minister states that it is proposed to build the new class-rooms on the same plan and of the same construction as the former class-rooms, which were destroyed by fire in 1941.

We have laboured under great difficulties due to our lack of class-room space and we appreciate very much the intention of the Government to rebuild the class-rooms and to expedite the reconstruction.

However, there are some phases of the matter that I respectfully suggest should be brought to the attention of the Government.

Dr. Morrison, the Provincial Inspector of Schools, when requested to make a survey of Alberni School conditions, which he did a year ago, expressed to me his opinion that the new class-rooms should be of fireproof construction similar to the main building, and that the needs of the school required that more class-room space than formerly should be made available.

The Hon. Minister states that the proposed new building would be heated from the main building and, consequently, the likelihood of fire would be greatly reduced. May I point out that the former class-room building was also heated from the main building. While we certainly do not anticipate a repetition of the fire of 1941, and while, under the circumstances, double precaution will be taken to prevent such repetition, would it not be economy and good insurance to reconstruct the proposed building with fireproof material, if
such is available?

In the matter of the enlarging of the class-room space by increasing the number of class-rooms to six or seven, may I say that such enlargement will have a vital effect on the functioning of the Alberni School in its educational service to the Indians of British Columbia and in reflecting credit on the Government by the better facilities provided and the worthwhile results obtained.

With four class-rooms only provided, our pupilage of 225 could not possibly be given class-room instruction except on the half-day system which we are at present maintaining. My own Indian school experience indicates definitely that only the full day class-room instruction for the junior grades, one to three or four, provides sufficient grounding to carry the pupils through grades five to seven or eight, in which grades the half-day class-room, half-day vocational instruction, should be operative.

Indian parents, themselves graduates of the Residential Schools, are becoming increasingly conscious of the advantages of High School instruction, and are requesting same with the expressed view of fitting the pupils for competition with the "Whites" in industry pertaining to reserve locality and also in occupations removed from the Reserves.

Alberni school is at present conducting, under great handicap, grades nine and ten, and it has been anticipated that, eventually, full High School instruction could be made available. For several reasons, such as the inaccessibility of Public High School facilities to the reserve homes of the pupils, and the proven undesirability of Indian pupils boarding out in a City or Town Centre to attend Public High School, it would appear that affording High School facilities in the Residential School is the only satisfactory way to make these facilities available to promising and ambitious Indian pupils.

Obviously, the Indian High School student must compete in examination with similar Public School students and therefore must be afforded full-time class-room instruction.
Confining our class-room space to four rooms as formerly would effectively bar the Alberni School for providing the High School tuition the parents are requesting, and which has a promising future, as instanced by the fact that not one of our grades eight and nine pupils failed to pass last term.

I fully appreciate the desire for economy and expedition in the rebuilding of the class-rooms and the advantage of such expedition to our work at Alberni School, but may I earnestly request that the Government take cognizance of the immediate needs and the future possibilities and demands of Indian education in British Columbia, as here outlined.

Yours very truly,

"A. E. Caldwell"
Principal.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I should like to put in writing some of the facts which I discussed with you last week.

On January 19th, 1945, the Town of Alberni put the School on a meter. Up to that time they had been paying a flat rate of $27.50 per month. When the Principal received the bill for January, he found that he was asked to pay $100.40. On February 30th, he communicated with Mr. Warren, 744 W. Hastings Street, Vancouver, of the Surveys and Engineering Branch of your Department, asking if he had any record of any agreement entered into between the School and the Town of Alberni regarding water rates; so that he certainly exercised due diligence in advising your Department about this matter after getting his bill. Mr. C.E. Webb, District Engineer, replied, stating:

"Regarding the new water rates of the town of Alberni, we had some correspondence with the town a few months ago in which they advised us that there would be a new rate structure commencing the first of January this year. From that we gathered that your rate would be somewhat higher than you were paying last year. However, it was not realized that the increase now in effect would be as high as the account you have enclosed shows."

"The consumption of water amounts to about 20,000 gallons per day or approximately 100 gallons per head. This would appear to be rather a high rate of consumption for a single building. Possibly it would be desirable to investigate the pipelines at the institution in order to determine if this high rate of consumption is due to leaks. A very small leak would run away with several thousand gallons per day and in the soil around the school such a leak would not be in evidence on the surface."

My first observation is that it seems a strange way of proceeding that the Town of Alberni should have discussed with the Department the
the setting up of a new rate structure, which the Engineer could see would mean an increased cost to the School, without the School being in any way notified. It would seem to me that we might expect that your Department would refund the difference between the $27.50 which they had been paying and the rate which the Department agreed to pay—or agreed that the Town of Alberni should charge. It is the Department which made the agreement with the Town, and consequently I cannot see why the School should be asked to pay. I think it is high time that such a method of proceeding should be stopped. Either the Department is going to assume the responsibility which it incurred by making arrangements, by which the School is supposed to abide, or the Department should confer with the School before it makes such arrangements.

In any case, the Department's Engineer was not nearly as much exercised as the Principal—which was natural. They had agreed lightheartedly that the School should be charged more, but they did not have to pay it, so why should they worry?

Mr. Caldwell wrote on February 14th to the Engineer and to Major MacKay. In his letter to the Engineer, Mr. Caldwell said that it was the opinion of the Town Engineer that there was no pipe leakage on the school property and that the water consumption was not excessive. I enclose copy of the letter which Mr. Caldwell wrote to Major MacKay and a copy of Major MacKay's reply, written in March.

On the 1st May, Mr. Webb of the Surveys and Engineering Branch wrote to Mr. Caldwell, suggesting that a check over a period of three months would be desirable and asking him to furnish copies of the accounts for the past four months—which was done. On May 14th, Mr. Webb wrote to Mr. Caldwell, asking that he be kept informed in connection with tracing down a probable leak, and it was found at that time that they had a leakage of approximately a cubic foot a minute—or to be exact ten cubic feet each nine and a half minutes. I understand that the leak has been found and the matter corrected.

May I point out that the water is conveyed from the town pipe line to the school by a pipe which has been put in at the expense of the Department, and consequently the town is not responsible for this. In the second place, may I point out that the Church cannot be held responsible for keeping this pipe in good repair—that is one of the obligations of the Department.

Thirdly, it follows that the pipe, not having been in good repair and the Principal having advised the Department immediately he found that he was using an excessive amount of water, and the Department not having exercised very much diligence in the matter, we have a right to expect that we shall get a refund of a certain amount, to which I
Indian Affairs Branch-

I shall refer later.

Finally, I want again to point out that the Department, through its Surveys and Engineering Branch, made the agreement with the Town of Alberni for the new rates, without any consultation with the Principal of the School.

Re: Leak in Basement Floor,

On receipt of your memorandum of February 15th, immediate inquiries were made in regard to any plans that might exist showing cold water pipes under the basement floor.

Mr. Mills, Chief Engineer of the Engineering and Construction Service, advised that no plans showing any mains under the basement slab were ever prepared, since it was not the intention of this Service that water lines should be so located. However, to confirm this opinion, contact was made with Mr. C.R. Cornish, who was Resident Engineer when the new building was erected.

Attached hereto is a copy of a memorandum from Mr. Mills, dated February 28th, which indicates that in the absence of cold water pipes under the basement slab, the leakage must be from sub-surface water under the basement. If this is the case, it would be necessary to install the drainage system for the site suggested by Mr. Warren about a year ago.

Before making a definite recommendation in this respect, however, Mr. Mills is getting a further opinion from Mr. Webb, District Chief Engineer at Vancouver.

Memorandum:

Re: Indian Residential School,
Alberni, British Columbia.

In accordance with your verbal instructions to Mr. Buck, confirmed by your notation of the 22nd instant on our memorandum of February 20th, regarding a reported water main leakage under the basement floor slab at the above school, Mr. Walker was requested by wire to contact Mr. Cornish and establish, if possible, whether or not water mains were laid under the basement floor slab of the residential building.

In a night lettergram, dated February 27th, Mr. Walker forwarded information on the matter. From the message the following is quoted:

"Mr. Cornish has no recollection of any water supply lines laid under basement floor slabs stop. Anti-sweat covering used on cold water main through basement so this line and branches definitely on ceiling stop No reason for taking any run under slab nor of any deviation from approved layout."

The water service at the school was in existence prior to the destruction of the original building by fire and the approved layout to which Mr. Walker makes reference, is one prepared by Mr. Cornish showing the recommended position outside the building for the wood stave branch line to which we have always assumed connection to the main building was made.

Under the circumstances we can offer no explanation of Commissioner MacKay's statement that a "leak in the cold water system has developed under the floor."

We have plans which show cast iron drainage lines below the floor slab, but it is improbable that these are the cause of trouble. It is much more likely that subsurface water is finding its way beneath the basement slab, as mentioned in our memorandum to you dated April 3rd, 1944, summarizing a report from Mr. Warren, at which he suggested carrying out site drainage operations at an estimated cost of $930.00.

It is considered desirable to obtain an opinion from Mr. Webb on the matter before any action is taken by the Indian Affairs Branch.

Chief Engineer.

Memorandum:

Re: Indian Residential School,
Alberni, British Columbia.

Further to our memorandum of February 28th last regarding water penetration in the basement of the above school, which the principal thought was resulting from corroded water lines laid under the basement slab, additional information is supplied as follows.

Under date of the 5th instant, Mr. Webb was requested to arrange an inspection and obtain data which would establish whether, contrary to our opinion, water lines had been installed below the basement floor slab, or if the trouble was being caused by a seepage of sub-surface water. Mr. Webb was requested to supply an estimate for the work he considered necessary to rectify the condition.

However, before Mr. Webb received our letter we were advised by the Indian Affairs Branch that under cover of a letter to them dated February 23rd, Commissioner Mackay had forwarded a report from the school Principal stating that repairs had been carried out. From the Principal's report the following is quoted:

"On Monday Feb. 11th, a leakage appeared from the cement wall of the students' kitchen, behind a built-in cupboard. The cupboard was removed and water leakage discovered from broken hollow bricks forming part of the side wall. This was traced to the cold water lead-in to the kitchen sink. A 1" galvanized pipe evidently led from the water main and was laid about one foot under the cement floor. No plans were obtainable showing the cold water system. Mr. Ashbridge, the Indian Agent, was notified and he came to examine the leak on Tuesday afternoon. In the meantime a plumber had been called in, at Mr. Ashbridge's suggestion, to investigate the leak. The water appeared to be coming from under the floor and Mr. Ashbridge instructed, that if the leak was not found on Tuesday, no further work was to be done until instructions were received from the Engineer's Branch.

The kitchen floor was dug up and the 1" inch Galvanized pipe uncovered. Several leaks were found; the pipe in question, about 15 feet in extent to the main, was found to be completely corroded from the outside, with a number of holes through which there was considerable leakage under pressure. The opinion of the plumber was that the nature of the ground which the leaking pipe traversed was responsible for the corrosion, although a similar pipe, leading from the main to the staff kitchen in the opposite direction (about one foot of which was uncovered) did not appear to be similarly corroded.

A copper pipe was installed to replace the one corroded and leaking, and the trench across the kitchen floor re-filled with cement."

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys & Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

QUARTERLY AGENCY REPORT FOR PERIOD ENDING JUNE 30, 1946.

SCHOOLS

Alberni Res. School was inspected (with Mr. Inspector Coleman on April 4th, when conditions were found to be good, except for poor conditions of walls on all Northern sides of the building, and the Principal's quarters. The School was also inspected on June 24th, the day after the earthquake which caused considerable damage in the vicinity. The building of the school itself appeared to have suffered no ill effects, except for one crack in the ceiling of the junior girls' dormitory, which I believe was noticeable before, but a small amount of dust was shaken out of this and possibly enlarged to a slight extent; also dust was shaken out of other cracks which were previously noticed. The quarters of the Principal suffered several large cracks in most of the rooms, and also over doorways. The chimneys and machinery in both dwellings and school do not appear to be damaged.

The condition of the School on this last inspection was the same as on April 4th, still troubled with plaster falling off and decaying on all northern walls.

Re: Alberni Residential School

I went over this school on the 4th ult. with the Principal and Acting Agent Garrard and would report that:

Floors - A considerable portion of the basement concrete floor was without covering, the linoleum having been taken up as it had lifted in many places owing to the presence of moisture. I have seen this floor several times since the school was constructed and am fully convinced, contrary opinion notwithstanding, that the moisture found its way underneath the covering from the surface and not from underneath the concrete floor and foundation, this also being the opinion of the Principal, staff and former Agent.

Under these conditions I do not consider replacement or relaying the linoleum will be any more satisfactory than in the past, but that consideration should be given to an impervious covering applied and bonded direct to the concrete, the least expensive of which would probably be a Mulsomatic surfacing or the more expensive composition, "tiles" set in asphalt.

Walls - Considerable damage has been done to the surface of the inside east walls, the south wall of the Principal's office where the plaster and undercoat have spilled off the wall over a considerable area, and also in the Principal's residence on the south wall, from moisture penetrating from the outside. In the upper floors this is due either to the recently installed copper flashing over the porous artificial stone coping, failing to reach to the outside lower edge of the coping by about 1", consequently shedding the rain on this unprotected strip, or at the imperfect brick mortar joints, pointing on both, or a combination of these.
The inexpensive remedy would be waterproofing the exposed strip of coping and caulking its exposed joints. Pointing the brickwork will be a job of some magnitude and could perhaps be deferred until we are able to determine the results of treatment of the coping, or alternatively point only over the trouble spots, in addition to the coping treatment. The trouble in the Principal's quarters is also, in my opinion, due to the porosity of the artificial stone window sills and lintels and requires waterproofing with a suitable material such as Tremco No. 121 Waterproofing, and joints caulked with their compound or similar. As the inside plaster affected has considerable efflorescence, despite frequent brushing off, it may be found necessary to apply a seal-coat, a variety of which is also put out by the Tremco people, after the walls dry out and before refinishing. Sufficient of these materials, outside of pointing the brick joints, should not be expensive.

The spalling of the plaster in the Principal's office, as elsewhere, can only be remedied, in my opinion, by removal of the loose material and refinishing after ensuring a proper key for the undercoat.

Drainage

While in Alberni on this occasion Chief Shewish of Sheeshant reserve, whose village adjoins the school, complained vigorously against the drainage of the school's untreated sewage into an open drain through the village, creating at times an intolerable nuisance and a quagmire dangerous to small children, apart from the health aspects.

I examined this with the Principal and Agent and found the Chief was fully justified in his complaint and it is hard to understand why this drain was located in its present position in the first place and why the former Indian Agent, as Health Officer for the reserve did not order its removal. Apparently the sewage is mostly scapy water but it is certain that it has been very offensive. The Principal stated that he sank almost to the waist on the reserve in ground softened by this discharge. There was absolutely no need to carry the drain to the edge of the village in the first place as it could have been taken in a direct line towards the river. Needless to say, this is a matter that should be remedied without delay regardless of cost.

J. Coleman,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Mr. P.B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

Repairs to school building.

The following repairs are urgently required:

1. BASEMENT FLOORS, including kitchens and students' dining room, also boys' playrooms.

The linoleum on the above mentioned floors had deteriorated due to dampness, and was removed in 1944. Estimates had been submitted for the re-covering of the floors in the summer of 1944 and again in the summer of 1945. It was decided by the Power and Water Bureau to delay the recovering until 1945 to determine whether the moisture which had spoilt the linoleum was caused by seepage up through the floor.

To date it has not appeared that any moisture is seeping through the floor. It would appear that the prime cause of the deterioration was the faulty cementing of the linoleum to the cement floor, permitting water to get under the linoleum when the floor is being scrubbed or when leakage occurred in water pipes. It is requested that the floors be recovered, preferably with some mastic substance, during the vacation months of July or August of this year, for the following reasons:

(a) The amount of labour involved in keeping the cement floors clean in the kitchens and dining room.
(b) The unsuitability of cement floors for the indoor playing of children, the playrooms requiring to be used extensively during the wet winter period.
(c) The continual complaint of staff members who must work on these floors as to the tiring, and general bad effect on the feet and legs, so much so that it is difficult to find permanent staff for the work.

2. RESIDENCE: Cracks in walls, and seepage of moisture through walls.

Due either to the settling of the building, or to the vibration in the building caused by heavy logging trains passing just below the building, cracks are showing in the wall, in the dining room.

All along the outside walls, above the baseboard on the ground floor, moisture has seeped in, in some places taking the plaster completely off the walls. This is undoubtedly due to absorption of moisture either by the brick or stone structure of the walls or by absorption through the pressed coping stone running along the wall about three feet from the ground.

3. MOISTURE through walls of Dormitories on top floors:

This condition was to a great extent remedied in the fall of 1945 by the covering of the roof coping with sheet copper. As no further moisture appeared the inside walls of the dormitories were painted last summer. When the present wet winter season was well advanced, however, moisture again appeared inside all walls with a North exposure (on the top floor only) and a white "fluff" formed on the plaster. It may be that moisture seeps through the brick wall.

May I request that these matters be investigated with a view to repair and remedy during the summer vacation.

Yours very truly, A.E. Caldwell - Principal

Alberni, B.C.

Dear Mr. MacKay-

This will acknowledge your letter of September 19 re question of installing a three burning oil unit for the Alberni Indian Residential School:

Recently Mrs. Unsworth of this staff was at the above mentioned school and noted the following:

1. The two building heating units are Supreme 2 pass boilers of 31 H.P. rating used as hot water heating units at 20 lbs. per sq. in. pressure.

Each is fired with a size 2 Iron Fireman Stoker.

2. The domestic hot water is heated with steam circulating in a coil in the 1,000 gallon hot water storage tank. The steam is supplied by a Horizontal Return Tubular Eclipse Type Boiler rated at 35.5 H.P. and run at a pressure of 95 lbs. per sq. in. This boiler is hand fired with lump coal costing $12.40 per ton at the school.

3. The kitchen stove is fired by an Iron Fireman DL.20 using stoker coal.

4. That apparently there are at least four laundry days per week.

It is presumed that the reason for considering changing from coal to oil fuel is to attempt to lessen the fuel costs. In this regard the following will be of interest.

Stoker coal costs $9.45 per ton delivered at the school. The heat value of this coal is 11,500 B.T.U.'s per lb. or 24,300 B.T.U.'s cost 1 cent. Efficiency of coal for heating using stokers is estimated at 70% or 17,000 B.T.U.'s of useful heat for 1 cent.

Furnace oil suitable for automatic burners such as would be needed in this school is quoted as 10.7 cents per gallon at the school. The heat value of this oil is 18,500 B.T.U.'s per lb. or 13,800 B.T.U.'s cost 1 cent. Efficiency of oil for heating is about 75% or 10,370 B.T.U.'s of useful heat for 1 cent. Therefore, cost of oil heating at the school will be 17,000 x 100% = 164% of coal heating.
From the foregoing, it will be observed the cost of stoker coal would have to be $15.50 per ton to equal in useful heat value the cost of fuel oil at 10.7 cents per gallon.

Automatic fuel oil burners require less attention than coal stokers but with either type of fuel one attendant is necessary to look after the boiler room at this school. Therefore, there would not appear to be saving in labour in this case. Full hoppers on the coal stokers will run overnight except in the coldest weather.

At other schools it appears to be the practice to run the laundry only two days per week, and if this could be done at Alberni it would cut fuel costs as on other days the pressure in the Eclipse Boiler could then be kept down to 12 lbs. per sq. in. which is sufficient to heat the domestic hot water.

Another method of lessening the cost of heating the domestic hot water which might be considered is to install a separate hot water heater of the cast type (18 series) fired with an automatic coal stoker similar to Iron Fireman D.L.30. This stoker to be controlled by a thermostat in the hot water storage tank. A rough estimate of such a unit is $1175.00 installed in school. Such a unit would not, however, take care of the demand on laundry days and on those days it will be necessary to run the Eclipse boiler hand fired. However, for this method to be economical the Eclipse boiler should not be run more than an average of two days a week.

One other point in favour of coal is that the present coal stokers are in place and working, and have an installed value. If removed the sale value is less at least by the installing cost.

While oil may be a little more convenient it is not more economical than coal when a boiler room attendant is needed for both as in this case.

If this information is not sufficient for your purposes, I will be pleased to arrange for a further investigation as soon as an engineer can be made available.

Yours very truly,

D. M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70
Vancouver, B.C.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Floor Covering in Dining Room
and Kitchen of Alberni Indian Residential School, Alberni, B.C.

Introduction

In accordance with your instructions of August 8, 1946, file 35615-1, I visited the Alberni Indian residential School, 3 miles north-west of Alberni, B.C., on August 9th and inspected the dining room and kitchen floors, and other sections of the basement floor with the object of covering them with a suitable surface.

There are some 220 children and staff at this school. The dining room and kitchen are in the basement.

Original Floor Coverings

At the time the school was built (1940) the basement floors were covered with linoleum and by October 1944 much of this linoleum was removed because of deterioration of the bond and linoleum. This was due to leaks which developed in water mains under the floor and also to the inherent characteristic of concrete to pass a very slight amount of moisture when laid on the ground.

Sketch 1, taken from Mr. Warren's Memorandum to Mr. Webb, re "Repairs carried out at Alberni Indian Residential School and report on Inspections" shows the condition of floor coverings in October, 1944.

Sketch 2 shows the condition of the floor coverings August 1946. Though the linoleum in the
staff dining room is still in place, it is bulged, torn and rotten and should be removed. The linoleum in the girls' recreation room is still fairly good and needs only re-cementing in a few places.

A layer of linoleum cement is still on much of the floor in particular as indicated in sketch 2.

The uncovered floor in the boys' lavatory is very uneven and does not slope toward drains. The concrete floor in the boys' play room is slightly worn and tends to be very dusty.

Recommendations

It is recommended that:

1. The linoleum in the girls' recreation room be left intact and re-cemented where required. This re-cementing can be done by school maintenance. Estimated cost of linoleum cement 1 gal. @ $2.50.

2. The linoleum be removed from staff dining room. Labor being supplied by school.

3. A floor surface be laid of 4" thick red quarry tile in 6" squares, over cleaned concrete in the kitchens and boys' lavatory. The boys' lavatory floor is very uneven and does not drain toward floor drains. It will be necessary to chip this floor and regrade with respect to drainage before laying tile. (See sketch 3)

Memorandum

Re: Residential Building, Alberni
Residential School, British Columbia

Several items of long standing have been the subject of correspondence between the Indian Affairs Branch and ourselves which might be listed as follows:

(a) The existence of water supply mains below the basement floor slab, which through deterioration had caused seepage into the basement.

(b) The absence of control valves on branches supplying plumbing fixtures from the domestic water system.

(c) Requests from Indian Affairs Branch officers in Vancouver, for recommendations regarding the purchase of floor coverings for basement areas.

(d) Moisture infiltration into Principal's residence (attached to Residential Building.)

In response to Mr. Hoey's request in his memorandum of February 21st last, for a report on our action in connection with the above matters you are advised as follows:

(a & b) Interim repairs to corroded piping below the basement floor slab, were carried out in our report to you on the matter under date of March 21st, 1946. The immediate trouble was rectified but was considered only temporary relief. Our proposed action in having buried piping replaced by overhead piping was approved in your memorandum of March 29th, 1946 and it was our intention to have our supervising officer on the new classroom building obtain estimates while that building was under construction. However September had arrived before we had an officer at Alberni, and in letters dated September 25th and September 30th, 1946 from Indian Agent Gerrard and Commissioner MacKenzie respectively, copies of which accompanied Mr. Hoey's memorandum to you dated October 8th last, both officers stated their opinion that the work, which would interrupt school routine, should not be undertaken until the summer holidays of 1947.

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
As it was known that our engineer Mr. Hargreaves would have to carry out an inspection in the West, as soon as arrangements could be made, no instructions regarding the matter were issued to our field officers. Mr. Hargreaves will obtain data on how much work will be involved, and will include an estimate of cost in his report. Recommendations will be forwarded and if approved, the necessary drawings can be prepared, and tenders invited. If funds can be made available, and the tenders received are satisfactory, work can be undertaken during the vacation period. Meanwhile, except for the inconvenience of shutting off the whole water supply system while minor repairs to taps etcetera are being made, no trouble is being occasioned.

(c) Certain areas carrying heavy traffic, were originally covered with battleship linoleum. Evidences of decay and poor adhesion of the linoleum, led to the conviction that moisture was present below the slab. Some of the linoleum was taken up, following which evidence of dampness disappeared. The dampness in the slab may have been caused by leakage from buried piping, (not in accordance with specifications) or surface water finding its way under the slab. In any event it is not considered advisable to take any action on re-covering the concrete floors with any new type of finish until the sub-slab water lines have been replaced by overhead piping, and the result observed. We can suggest no date, at present when, under the circumstances, the floors should be recovered, since observation of results obtained by the removal of buried piping will take considerable time.

In this connection we are forwarding herewith a copy of Mr. Unsworth's report of September 19th, 1946, to which Mr. Hoey makes reference. Since Mr. Webb's covering letter states that copies were forwarded to Commissioner MacKay it is likely that other copies have reached the Indian Affairs Branch.

(d) Water infiltration to the Principal's Residence, which has affected plaster and paintwork, is a matter that must be viewed and reported on by a waterproofing specialist. The most recent comment on this item was contained in a letter from Inspector Coleman to Commissioner MacKay dated May 9th, 1946, a copy of which accompanied Mr. Hoey's memorandum to you dated June 25th, 1946.

It is obvious that buildings of masonry construction built in coastal areas, where extremely heavy and violent rainstorms cause as great horizontal precipitation as vertical, special consideration must be given to waterproofing of exterior walls no matter what additional cost is involved. The residential schools at both Alert Bay in British Columbia, and Shubenacadie in Nova Scotia are examples of what can happen when such precautions are not observed. At Alberni where some precautions were taken, they were evidently not sufficient to prevent surface absorption finding its way through the bricks, or salt action from causing deterioration to brick and stone jointing.
It is our recommendation regarding future action at Alberni that:

(1) Following Mr. Hargreaves return, and when drawings and specifications have been prepared, funds be provided to carry out the necessary modifications to the water supply and plumbing system which have already been approved, as well as any other repairs in that system which have become evident after six years of service.

(2) Upon completion of (1), a reasonable period (probably a year) be allowed during which it can be determined whether buried piping has been responsible for dampness in the basement areas formerly covered by linoleum, or whether other causes become evident. During the observation period, funds should be made available for re-covering such areas, as have never been subject to dampness, with quarry tile, asphalt tile or other covering as approved. Use should be made of the interval, to make sure all evidence of dirt, grease, or old linoleum adhesive is removed from the cement floors. Not until such areas as were formerly affected by dampness, have been satisfactorily treated should they be covered by any type of material.

(3) It will not be possible to defer the repairs to plaster and paintwork, made necessary by damp walls, until the cause of trouble is remedied. Even at the risk of having to repeat such repairs it is not reasonable to subject the school principal to the conditions reported.

Investigation of a means of protecting all exterior walls from continued infiltration of moisture will be undertaken as soon as possible, but as previously stated, the investigation and, if funds are made available, rectification of the condition will be a lengthy and probably expensive procedure.

An estimate based upon data secured at the building, and from drawings which will be prepared by Mr. Hargreaves will be forwarded to you, in connection with the water supply system as soon as it can be prepared.

It must be pointed out again however, that the volume of work which faces our inadequate Architectural staff, and which includes the Indian Affairs and National Parks 1947-48 programme, must be borne in mind when considering the time factor.

Chief Engineer.

CENTRAL VANCOUVER ISLAND HEALTH UNIT

April 29th, 1947

Mr. N. W. Garrard
Indian Agent
Alberni, B.C.

Dear Mr. Garrard:

The Sanitary Inspector has drawn my attention to the fact that the sewage effluent from the septic tank at the Indian Residential school is being poured into the river at a point where it is used as a public swimming hole.

This condition does not seem to be in the public interest and we would like to suggest that the effluent from the tank be disposed of in tile drainage beds on the school property. Mr. Benham, Sanitary Inspector, informs me that there is plenty of good gravelly soil for sufficient disposal which could be utilized. He would be willing to meet with you or the school officials to lay out a proper drainage system which would meet our requirements.

We would appreciate your early attention to this matter as with warm weather approaching, the swimming season will soon be upon us.

Yours sincerely,

J.A. TAYLOR, M.D., D.P.H.,
Director.

Memorandum

Re: Alberni Indian Residential School
Vancouver Island, B.C.

In accordance with our memorandum of February 4th, 1947 to Mr. Walker, our Mr. Hargreaves visited the above school and carried out an inspection of the mechanical services on March 13th and 15th inclusive. The following summary outlines the result of these investigations:

The main drain from the building, excepting the sanitary line to the septic tank, at present discharges into a slough on an adjacent Indian reserve. The proposed diversion, outlined by Mr. Walker was studied at the job and found to be practical. Following approval by the Indian Affairs Branch, on recommendation by this Service, instructions have been issued to have this work carried out by the Contractor building the new Classroom building, thus taking advantage of Mr. Brown's favourable price of $1000, as well as to have the additional advantage of Mr. Gurney's supervision.

Regarding the plumbing at the school, that part of the cold water main, serving the various fixture groups, was found to be buried in cinder fill under the concrete slab. Portions of this line have given trouble, due to rapid corrosion occasioned by the sulphuric content in the cinder fill attacking the water lines. These temporary repairs have caused great inconvenience to all concerned and this condition of rapid deterioration will become progressively worse.

Most of the hot and cold water risers to the fixture groups were found, after much difficulty, buried in masonry partitions; and in only a few cases were valved.

Complaints were received regarding the lack of hot water. The storage tank was found to be ample in size but the coil capacity was found to be entirely inadequate. While it was not possible to remove the coil for minute inspection, it can be conservatively assumed that it can heat water at the rate not in excess of 200 gallons per hour. INTRODUCTION

Alberni Residential School is situated on the south bank of the Somass River about 1 1/2 miles west of main business section of the City of Alberni. The corporation limits of the City of Alberni extend along the north bank of the river to a point about 300 yards west of the Residential School. During the past few years residences have been constructed along the north bank to the Alberni City Limits. A children's playground and swimming beach has been opened just inside the city limits and a short distance up stream from the Residential School sewerage outlet. Residents of houses built along the north bank have been observed bathing in the river in front of their property almost the whole distance to the main section of Alberni.

The Opetchisht Indian Reserve adjoins the grounds of the Residential School to the west and the children from the Reserve often swim in the river about 200 yards to the west. A dairy farm occupies the property to the east of the School and from what can be learned no swimming is allowed in the river along this section of the south bank.

GENERAL SANITARY CONDITIONS

From careful observation and from inquiries it is learned that all houses adjoining the Somass River from Port Alberni to the western limits of Alberni are either equipped with outside latrines or septic tanks. Almost without exception the effluent from the septic tanks is discharged into the Somass River without any other treatment. Several houses built on floats are anchored along the north bank and these float-houses are served with outside latrines which empty directly into the Somass River.

The District Health Department Sanitary Officer has been interviewed and the existence of these latrines and effluent outlets were pointed out to this officer. It was further pointed out that while these sources of contamination were allowed to exist it seemed useless to construct the expensive treatment beds suggested by this officer.

The existence of these other sources of contamination were admitted. From my conversation with the inspector it was gathered that the sewage disposal problem in both Alberni and Port Alberni was deplorable. It was admitted that his Department were not making much progress in cleaning up such nuisances in Alberni. It was gathered that when the Health District was organized, the City of Alberni made a stipulation that the City would not be required to make any monetary outlay to assist in remedial measures. It would seem that authority in this matter is limited to interviewing householders in an attempt to have these parties agree to correct the nuisances voluntarily.

PROVINCIAL REQUIREMENTS

The Sanitary Inspector was of the opinion that the Indian Affairs Branch should construct a tile disposal field patterned after the sketches attached. It was brought to the Inspectors' notice that certain features of this type of disposal would be difficult to overcome and an endeavour was made to get additional information on alternative systems which would be acceptable to his
acceptable to his Department and which would be the cheapest and most satisfactory to this Department. No information on this subject could be obtained but the Inspector promised to write to the Sanitary Engineer of his Department and obtain his opinion. At time of writing this report this information has not been received.

DISPOSAL BED.

An investigation was made into the possibility of constructing a disposal bed as recommended by the Provincial Board of Health B.C. on property at the Alberni Residential School.

The only ground available for a bed of the size required lies between the school building and the Somass River. This land is shown in red on the map attached. The Board of Health requires 70' of tile per five persons. Figured on this basis it will require 3500 feet of tile and laid out in runs of 100' which is the longest run possible will require an area 200' x 175'. The ground available comprises the choicest piece of garden land on the school property and is under constant cultivation as a kitchen garden.

This land lies about 7' above high tide level and during the spring floods and winter rains is frequently flooded. The sub-soil consists mainly of fine sand. The black top soil is about one foot deep.

The main objections to construction of a disposal bed are as follows:

(a) The possibility of the surplus sand excavated spoiling the land for garden purposes.
(b) The periods of high water and floods which would cause the system to be inoperable.
(c) Fine sand filtering into and plugging up tiles with result that the bed will become useless.

DISCUSSION.

It is thought that the discharge of effluent into the Somass River by the School sewage system presents a far smaller menace to Public Health conditions in the district than other pollution entering the river closer to those places frequented by swimmers.

It is considered very unlikely that if it was agreed to construct such a system that labour and material could be secured in the district for the purpose. From experience here this past few months it will be understood that labour and materials are practically non-existent. This disposal bed would require all hand labour and labour willing to perform this type of work is not available. It is estimated that construction of this bed would cost $3600.00 if labour was available.

RECOMMENDATION.

From the information received and investigation made it is recommended that construction of the disposal bed be held over for at least one year. It is thought that some method of disinfecting the effluent with chlorine or some other method of treating the effluent could be recommended which would be not only cheaper but less liable to failure.

It is believed that if this matter discussed with the Department of Public Health at a higher level no objections would be made to the foregoing proposal.

Ottawa, November 24, 1947.

Mr. Hoey

RE: Alberni Indian Residential School

Reference is made to the contract that was let to Mr. W. O. Brown in the matter of the construction of the above noted school. Our file record in this transaction is as follows:

(1) Under date of the 29th August, 1947, the Canadian Western Woodworkers Limited of Victoria advised Indian Affairs that they had supplied the contractor with millwork, etc., to the amount of $3,463 and to date had been unable to receive payment.

(2) The Surveys and Engineering Branch discussed the matter with Mr. K. R. Daly on September 25th who advised that the Department had no strictly legal responsibility.

(3) That the Surveys and Engineering Branch requested their local representative to investigate and suggest to the unpaid sub-contractors that they get together and submit a statement giving the status of their accounts.

We discussed this matter over the telephone with Mr. C. H. Buck, Chief Architect, on the 21st instant who informed us that the creditors have been organized and appointed a Receiver and that Mr. W. O. Brown is to be declared "in bankruptcy". We also understand that Senior Departmental Solicitor, Mr. K. R. Daly, is dealing with the matter on behalf of the Department.

If any further action is required by the Engineering and Construction Division, please let me know.

Director.

Re: Alberni Residential School
Your file 159-1-5 (WT 1)

With reference to Mr. Hoey's letter of December 12th and telephone communication from Mr. J.L. Gibson, M.P., with respect to repairs to the floors and walls at the Alberni Residential School, this matter has been the subject of frequent correspondence with the school Principal and the Department during the past three years. The question of replacing the linoleum on certain sections of basement floors apparently was taken out of the hands of the local officers of the Survey and Engineering branch but was investigated by an official of that branch from Ottawa early this year, reference Mr. Neary's letter of March 3rd last. As a result of the investigation by an official of the Engineering branch, Ottawa, it apparently was decided that a period of about one year should be allowed to elapse following changes to the plumbing under the cement floor slab to determine whether the buried pipe, now disconnected, was responsible for dampness in the basement areas formerly covered by linoleum or whether other causes would become evident.

With regard to the question of waterproofing the outside walls of the building, this matter was brought to your attention in my letter of July 7th in response to which Mr. Neary advised that no arrangements had been made for waterproofing the outside walls this year.

Mr. Caldwell, the Principal of the school is greatly
concerned regarding the condition of the basement floors and the effect on his kitchen and dining room staff, his most recent letter of November 17th in this connection being enclosed for your information, together with a copy of my letter of December 5th to him. You will note that the matter has been taken up with the local office of the Survey and Engineering Branch who have agreed to carry out as soon as possible a further examination with a view to determining whether or not it would be advisable to lay new linoleum at the present time and also to investigate and report with respect to waterproofing the outside walls to prevent seepage.

Mr. Gibson has not yet been in communication with this office but should an opportunity offer I will advise him of the steps being taken to remedy the conditions complained of at the Alberni School.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Caldwell:

Re: Kitchen, Dining Room and Playroom Floors

Replying to your letter of November 17th, the Surveys and Engineering Branch will carry out as soon as possible a further examination of the Alberni School buildings with a view to determining whether or not it would be advisable to lay new linoleum on the above mentioned floors. The problem of seepage through the walls will also be looked into at that time.

With regard to the memorandum dated March 20th last wherein it was recommended that on completion of changes to the plumbing installation a period of one year be allowed during which it could be determined whether the buried piping was responsible for dampness in the basement areas formerly covered by linoleum, this recommendation did not originate in the local office of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau but apparently in the Ottawa office of that Branch. As a matter of fact Mr. Webb's office had no knowledge of the memorandum until I wrote to them under date of November 25th last. The most recent recommendation from Mr. Webb's office is contained in a report by Mr. Unsworth dated Sept. 13th, 1946, to the effect that certain floor coverings be laid. Since that time the matter has apparently been entirely out of the hands of the local Dominion Water and Power Bureau office who, as far as I can see, have done everything possible to
secure suitable floor coverings and any delay in not looking into the matter further cannot be attributed to any lack of action on their part.

Mr. Webb has requested me to assure you that he fully appreciates your difficulties and is anxious to do what he can to assist in having the necessary repairs and improvements attended to.

Yours faithfully,

With reference to the enclosed account from E. G. Thompson for $46.00 for breaking down wall, and grading in fill in front of the Residential School.

When the Day School was removed from its original location in front of the Residential School the cement wall of the basement which was left was found to be in such a poor condition that it was considered unsafe for the children; also, it was detrimental to the appearance of the Residential School. Re: Repairs to Basement Floors,
Alberni Indian Residential School

With reference to the memorandum of the 29th ultimo signed by Mr. D.J. Allan, with which was enclosed a copy of correspondence from Mr. A.E. Caldwell, School Principal, and Indian Commissioner MacKay, on the subject of the above; our Chief Architect states as follows:

"It has not yet been definitely determined, notwithstanding the contrary opinion of laymen, whether the leakage of sub-floor water supply lines at the Alberni Residential School, which has now been stopped, was the sole cause of the dampness that appeared in the concrete basement floor slabs.

It is therefore recommended that no action be taken to permanently finish the floors, from which linoleum was removed, until the spring run-off has shown conclusively whether or not any moisture is liable to penetrate beneath the floor slabs through or under the concrete footings of the external walls.

If upon examination during that period no dampness is apparent in the concrete floor slabs, it is proposed that the slabs be prepared to receive flexible asbestos-asphalt floor tile laid in accordance with a specification which will be furnished by our Architectural Section.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Booth Building, 165 Sparks St.,
Ottawa, Ont.
If, on the other hand, it is found during the spring run-off that the floor slabs are again showing signs of moisture, it will be evident that there is an infiltration of water from the outside of the building and precautions would have to be taken to prevent such ingress before work in connection with the re-surfacing of basement floors is undertaken.

It is our intention to request Mr. Webb of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau, Vancouver, to keep himself informed in regard to the condition of the basement floor area and to assign one of his engineers to make inspections as necessary during the coming spring and to report to this office in order that we may issue instructions for whatever action is indicated to be carried out as soon as possible thereafter."

Director.

In accordance with our instructions, Mr. Gurney has investigated the question of covering basement floors of this building with linoleum, after applying "Aquella". In our opinion, Mr. Gurney's estimate of $3000 is low and we anticipate that the same trouble would recur if great care is not taken.

On the foregoing basis it is recommended that authority be obtained to have this work put in hand under Mr. Gurney at a cost of about $3,800.

Dear Sir:

Re: Classroom Building,
Indian Residential School,
Alberni, British Columbia.

Your letter dated May 26th last, which you wrote to the Department has been forwarded to this Division for reply and you are accordingly advised as follows:

Following receipt of your letter dated August 29, 1947, wherein you point out that W.O. Brown, of Port Alberni, British Columbia, the General Contractor on the job, had made no payment to you on your account for millwork, our Superintendent on the work was instructed to investigate the contractor's standing with all subcontractors and supply firms. It was established that while the contractor had received payment for all work completed up to that time, he had failed to use the funds in meeting his obligations on outstanding accounts to a number of firms for materials and supplies under the contracts.

Further payments by the Crown to the contractor were withheld until the creditors advised the Department that they had appointed a receiver to act in their behalf, and in a letter dated October 23, 1947, bearing the signatures of all known creditors including your own, the Department was advised that Mr. H.O.K. Housser, 108-Fourth Avenue South, Port Alberni, had been appointed to act in that capacity.

You are doubtless aware that the Crown recognizes the General Contractor only, on a project, and that subcontractors or supply houses are responsible for protecting their own interests, insofar as their financial relations with the General Contractor are concerned. However, the prerogative held by the Department to pay funds due a General Contractor who has defaulted in his payment to creditors, directly to those creditors, through a receiver agreeable to the creditors, was followed, and following Mr. Housser's appointment with Power of Attorney for the creditors, all funds due Mr. Brown still under our control were paid directly to Mr. Housser for distribution, proportionate to the amount of the creditors' claims.

Under date of March 10, 1948, Mr. Housser advised this office that all funds had been distributed.

It is realized that under the circumstances, creditors were not paid in full, but Mr. Brown having been paid the greater proportion of his contract price directly, and the balance of the total contract price having been distributed to the creditors through their appointed receiver, the connection of the Department with the contract is now terminated. Any further recovery of funds by the creditors is dependent upon either mutually agreeable arrangements with Mr. Brown or by legal action against him.

Yours faithfully,

E.E. Burst, Esq.,
Canadian Western Woodworkers Limited,
Garibaldi Road,
Victoria, British Columbia.

T.S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

Voucher No. 484 Date 29 July 1948
A contract was let to Messrs. Irvine and Reeves of Port Alberni, B.C., early in March of this year for plumbing and heating repairs, Alberni Indian Residential School. Efforts to secure a firm price contract were unsuccessful due to the fact that in repair jobs of this nature it is difficult to determine, beforehand, the exact amount of work necessary. There were two bids on a cost plus basis, and upon the advice of our engineer, Mr. Gurney, it was decided to let the contract to Irvine and Reeves on the basis of cost plus ten percent (10%). On February 19th of this year, a wire was received from our engineer, Mr. Gurney, stating that Irvine and Reeves estimated the cost would be $4,500.00 and the contract was drawn up on the basis of that amount.

Section 3, Clause (a) of the Contract reads as follows:

"To pay the Contractor the cost of the work as defined in Schedule A hereto attached, which cost as so defined is hereinafter referred to as the cost of the work, but unless authorized by the Minister not to exceed the sum of $4,500.00, which sum is hereinafter referred to as the estimated cost of the work".

We now have final accounts from the Contractor showing that work performed by Irvine and Reeves will total $5,906.90. The increased cost is due to factors outside the control of either the Contractor or this Division. There was a sharp rise in tradesmen's wage rates, and in the cost of material subsequent to awarding the contract, as well as additional items which could not be anticipated but which became evident as the work progressed.

We will therefore require approval for the amount of the increased cost ($1,406.90) over the original estimated cost of $4,500.00 before final payment can be made on the Contract.

Chief Engineer.
