TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

That in the 1947-48 estimates of the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, funds were provided for carrying out repairs and replacements to the plumbing and domestic water systems in the Indian Residential School at Alberni, British Columbia;

That drawings and specifications were prepared by the Department, and calls for tenders were issued, as a result of which two tenders were received, both quoting a price of cost plus ten per cent (10%) for materials and labour. It was recognized that due to the character of the work, the total cost would not be known until operations were underway;

That upon analysis, it was considered to be in the best public interest to accept the tender submitted by Messrs. Irvine and Reeves of Port Alberni, British Columbia, whose approximate total cost of the work was Four Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($4,500.00);

That approval of the acceptance of the said tender was issued by the predecessor of the undersigned, and a contract was awarded to Messrs. Irvine and Reeves limiting the cost of the work to the approximate estimate of Four Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($4,500.00) plus a fee of ten per cent (10%);

That as the work progressed, additional essential repair items became necessary which together with increases in the cost of labour and materials, and including the Contractor's fee of ten per cent (10%) has increased the cost of repairs to the school to Five Thousand, Nine Hundred and Six Dollars and Ninety Cents ($5,906.90) which, after making provision for supervision, will involve a total expenditure to the Department of Six Thousand Three Hundred Dollars ($6,300.00);

The undersigned, therefore, has the honour to recommend that the work having been completed by the contractor, and accepted as satisfactory by the Departmental supervising officer, that authority be granted for payment of the additional cost not exceeding One Thousand Three Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($1,350.00), the approximate amount by which the total cost exceeded the expenditure originally approved by the then Minister of Mines and Resources, the said additional expenditure to be met from the appropriate vote of the Indian Affairs Branch 1948-49 estimates (Vote 772, Indian Education) Department of Mines and Resources.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Dear Col. Neary:

Re: Equipment of Alberni Indian Residential School

Upon leaving the Alberni school, Miss McCready wrote and asked if it would be possible for an increase grant to be given to this school to cover the salary of a second cook in the main kitchen, as one cook is doing the cooking for 240 children and finds it difficult to keep the necessary food records needed in the survey because of lack of time. It is almost impossible for one cook to prepare the food for this number of people without any extra duties.

There is a bread slicer in the school but it is antiquated and unsatisfactory; thus it is not used and the bread is sliced by hand. The slices are not uniform in size and therefore it is difficult to keep proper records of size of serving of bread eaten.

An electric mixer for a school this size is very desirable for mixing cakes, cookies, mashing vegetables, etc. It is impossible for women or children to mix or beat the quantity of food that is required for 240 children.

I believe Miss Lock spoke to you about these requirements on the telephone last week. No doubt you have given them consideration and will be writing us regarding them shortly.

Yours sincerely,

Two Years—Two Scholarships

By LYN HARRINGTON

She's done it again!

For the second year, Judith Phyllis Morgan of Kitwanga has won the $150 scholarship presented through the B.C. Indian Arts and Welfare Society of Victoria by the University Women's Club. Judith submitted the required four paintings from the Alberni Residential School where she lives.

The scholarship is presented as a memorial "to honor the Indians who had given their lives for Canada in the Second World War, and to assist native craftsmen to maintain high standards and to build up a thriving industry for their people." The scholarship carries with it two weeks of study at the Provincial Museum under trained anthropologists.

The fairy tale atmosphere about it is that Judith never had an art lesson until the beginning of last year. And then to win a scholarship is enough to make anyone believe in happy endings. But she did it twice—twice proof if any is needed that her talent is no mere flash in the pan.

Even if she hadn't won it, Judith would have gone on with the art work in which she has been engaged for years. Her paintings are taken en masse from the stories of the West Coast natives, and chiefly of the Tsimsian tribe. The masks and headdresses worn by her subjects are the ceremonies she saw as a youngster home is famous as the village of totem poles. There Emily Carr painted and used to play with the children she came to know and love. She wrote about in her book," said Judith. There are 13 boys and girls in the Morgan family, the eldest who is a veteran of World War II.

One delightful thing about Judith Morgan is that she is completely composed as before a daughter of the totem house. Taking her with the first ladies of the province and prominent and outstanding Canadian painters such as Lawren Harris, Judith maintains that quiet dignity displayed in an 18-year-old schoolgirl.

Her paintings are taken en masse from the stories of the West Coast natives, and chiefly of the Tsimsian tribe. The masks and headdresses worn by her subjects are the ceremonies she saw as a youngster.

Judith Phyllis Morgan is a coming artist of her race.

Re: Gymnasium - Alberni Residential School

I am enclosing a letter dated April 18th, from Mr. A.E. Caldwell, wherein he makes representations for conversion of the barn which is not now used, into a gymnasium.

Although we were at first inclined to reject this proposal on the grounds that funds for new construction were extremely limited, subsequent investigation by School Inspector Levey revealed that space in the main school building formerly used for recreational activities had been converted for classroom use, leaving absolutely no recreational space. You will recall that although we had contemplated the erection of a four-classroom block at Alberni this year, it was decided to defer construction for another year in order that the funds appropriated could be transferred for other more urgent school construction projects. Under the circumstances, as the school has relinquished for classroom use space previously used for recreational purposes and as there is no prospect of additional classroom space being provided this year, I am of the opinion that Mr. Caldwell's request for conversion of the barn is reasonable.

The total cost of converting the building should not exceed $5,000.00. I would recommend that the Department favourably consider an expenditure of this amount from the classroom block appropriation. If this recommendation is approved, further details will be secured with regard to the material and labour necessary and the proposed arrangement for having the work carried out.

[Signature]
W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re Conversion of Barn to Gym.

Dear Mr. Arneil,

I have had an estimate made by a good carpenter, a man who was for a time our Manual Instructor, John Loewen, on the renovation required to convert the barn which we are not now using into a Gymnasium. I do not need to dwell on the urgent necessity for such playing accommodation at this school. The present very small space provided within the school building is altogether inadequate, especially during the wet winter months.

The building is 34 feet by 80 feet. The roofing requires renewing and the roof struts strengthening. The loft floor will be removed and a floor rebuilt on the cement ground floor. The present cement floor will require to be levelled by wood floor joists.

The carpenter has estimated the material to be required and is charging daily carpenter wages for himself and one helper. His estimate of the time necessary for labour seems to me very reasonable. The total cost would be $4516.15.

I am enclosing a list of labour and material which Mr. Loewen has submitted. I would be pleased if this work could be done during the summer.

Re: Gymnasium - Alberni Residential School

In a letter dated June 1st Indian Commissioner Arneil recommended that the barn at the above school be converted into a gymnasium. In reply to that communication we advised him that consideration of the matter would have to be delayed.

Mr. Arneil has again written under cover of a letter dated September 12th. You will note that he recommends that funds not required at the Fort Babine Day School be transferred for the purpose of converting the barn at the Alberni School into a gymnasium.

We have received a separate letter from Mr. Arneil pointing out that it is too late in the year to erect the Fort Babine School, but it is our intention to erect this school early next year. Mr. Arneil has suggested that the prefabricated building be purchased and paid for, and held in storage until next spring. By accepting Mr. Arneil's suggestion, there will be sufficient funds in our appropriation to transfer from the allotment provided for the Fort Babine School, the sum of $6,000.00.

We would appreciate it if you would approve our transferring the amount mentioned.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

- Remove and level concrete feed troughs, 15" high.
- Make concrete dwarf wall for floor joist support.
- Make concrete footings 18" x 24" x 24" for buttresses.
- Lay floor joists, 2 x 12".
- Remove existing partitions and beams.

- Lay sub-floor, using sheeting removed from loft floor.

- Build furnace room.
- Remove ramp.

- Repair roof in preparation for shingling.
- 12 buttresses anchored with 3/4" by 6" dowels.

Oct. 22nd 1949.

Mr. W. S. Arneil,
Commissioner for Indian Affairs,
VANCOUVER, B.C. Re. Gymnasium.

Dear Mr. Arneil,

I have yours of the 20th Inst re the manner in which the work of renovation of the barn for the purpose of providing a gymnasium can be carried out.

I have discussed this matter with Mr. John Loewen, who, I may say, is a first class man and takes a great interest in the school, and he says that, in our own interest, it would be better to have the work done by contract as he estimated, as that would ensure the work being done as quickly as possible.

I went over his figures with him when he made the estimate (which you have with the plans) and, in my own opinion, his estimate of the cost of labour was a bare minimum of the time necessary to do both the breaking down of the floors, etc., and the rebuilding.

However, if you think it is preferable to have the work done by day labour, with the materials supplied, it should not make much difference, except that there is the prospect that the estimate made may not cover the job.

You will recall that the extra $500.00 placed in the estimates is for a furnace and lighting, not included in Mr. Loewen's estimate.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Gymnasium - Alberni Residential School

Your File 877-5 (E1)

Following receipt of Mr. Phelan's Army Signals Message of October 13th, I discussed at some length with Mr. Caldwell his proposal for converting the Alberni School barn into a gymnasium. In his letter of April 16th, a copy of which was forwarded to you, he outlines the proposal in some detail and has now provided a plan which is being forwarded to you under separate cover which indicates further the amount of work necessary.

Mr. Caldwell has available to do the work a Mr. John Loewen, formerly an employee of the School, and although we consider that it might be easier to secure approval of the proposal if the work was done on a day labour basis, he is of the opinion that this would increase the cost over $5,000.00, with which opinion I concur. Mr. Loewen is prepared to complete the conversion on a firm contract basis for $4,510.15, which amount includes both labour and material, apart from the necessary heating and wiring installations. Mr. Caldwell is of the opinion that these facilities can be installed separately for less than $500.00 which will keep the total cost below the $5,000.00 approved.

Mr. Caldwell's letter of October 22nd and another copy of Mr. Loewen's estimate are enclosed and I would ask you to please advise if an arrangement for carrying out of the work on a firm contract basis by Mr. Loewen can be approved and if any additional information is required.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
November 10th, 1949.

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Alberni Indian Residential School,
West Coast Indian Agency, Province
of British Columbia, Electoral
District of Comox-Alberni

The above is a government-owned school which
is conducted under the auspices of the United Church
in Canada. Recently the Principal requested that the
Department approve the conversion of the barn into a
gymnasium. This barn is not used, and we are assured
by Indian Commissioner Arneil that it will not be
required as such in future, and that accommodation to
replace it will not be necessary. Mr. Arneil considers
that the conversion of the barn to a gymnasium is very
necessary so as to provide recreation space for the
pupils attending this school, which has an authorized
pupilage of 235.

Mr. John Loewen, Alberni, B.C., has submitted
a quotation of $4,516.15 for material and labour for
converting the barn. Both the Principal and Mr. Arneil
consider Mr. Loewen a competent man, and I would
appreciate it if the Minister would approve acceptance
of his tender for this particular work. Funds for the
purpose were provided in the Supplementary Estimates.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Hostel, Alberni Residential School

I have recently had an opportunity to discuss with Mr. Caldwell the type of hostel which should be constructed to serve the high school population now in residence at the Alberni Residential School. There are now 14 pupils in residence at the school who are attending the Provincial High School. It is expected that there will be 24 attending next year. This allows for at least five dropping out before going to high school, and the indications are that this number will continue to increase rapidly for the next four years. It would appear that we should plan a building that will accommodate 50 children, which number will be reached in five years or less.

The preferred type of building is one which would provide bedrooms to accommodate two students. Since this building will house both sexes it is required that the sleeping accommodation for each group be separated so that each of the two sections will accommodate approximately half of the enrolment.
In addition to the sleeping accommodation, there will be required a common dining hall, preferably one equipped with tables for four, a common kitchen and a common sitting room and study hall. It is suggested that the basement, or part of it, might be fitted as a large rumpus room.

Since the heating unit at the Residential School will have to be increased to provide for the new class-room block it is suggested that the new boiler be sufficiently large to provide heat for the hostel as well.

In addition to housing the pupilage, the building should also provide accommodation for a small staff of one cook, two supervisors and one general assistant. It would be desirable also to have two spare bedrooms provided.

It is believed that the general construction should be a one story frame building. I do not feel that anything in the nature of a fire-proof building should be used as this type of construction is both expensive and inflexible for a scheme which is experimental.

This information is being supplied at this time so that draft sketches may be prepared in order to have the final set of plans completed for the beginning of the 1951-52 fiscal year.

R.F. Davey,
Inspector of Schools.

Alberni, B.C.
Feb. 3, 1947

Mr. N.W. Gerrard, Indian Agent
Alberni, B.C.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith account and vouchers for travelling expense of pupils during the year 1946, amounting to $462.62.

It has been the practice of the Department during the past two years to remit us one-half of this account, which accounts has remained consistently at approximately the amount submitted herewith. An estimate for $500.00 for travelling expense of pupils to and from the school to their homes for the vacation, was placed in this year's estimates, and a request that this grant be allowed.

With the exception of the small Girls' Home at Fort Simpson, this is, of course, the only United Church residential School in the Province and therefore pupils come from widely scattered points. An appreciable number are from the inner B.C. Coast as far north as the Nass River, and these must be escorted.

In view of the difficult conditions of financing we are now increasingly experiencing, may I request that the full amount of the account here submitted be granted.

Yours very truly,

"A. E. Caldwell"

UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA

ALBERNI, B.C.

July 19th 1947.

Re: School Vacation.

Dear Mr. Garrard,

I have your letter of recent date containing an extract from a letter from Mr. Phillip Phelin, wherein he enquires re an irregularity in the vacation leave for a number of pupils of this school. May I request that you report the following circumstance to Mr. Phelin.

Some 70 of our pupils are from points on the Northern coast of the B.C. mainland from Bella Bella to Prince Rupert. Both from the Alberni School, and earlier, from the Coqualeetza School, transportation for these pupils to and from their homes has been provided for many years by the Union Steamships Company of Vancouver, the only company to call at some of the points to which the pupils must be conveyed. Reservations have always been kept by this company between the 25th and 30th June, on the homeward journey, and between the 25th and the 31st of August on the return journey.

This year, however, unknown to me, not only had the company made a change in their schedules, but the Passenger Agent at their Vancouver office had been changed. When I visited Vancouver the first week in May to arrange for the usual transportation, I found that the usual accommodation had not been reserved for the Alberni School. The Alert Bay School had just completed arrangements to have their pupils transported northward on June 26th. The tourist traffic had booked up accommodation from June 15th throughout the season, and extra accommodation had to be found for Cannery employees leaving Vancouver at the latter end of June.

I tried to book passages on the Canadian Pacific Steamships of the dates required, but they were also fully booked. The only date that could accommodate the pupils for Butedale, the Skeena River, and the Hazelton district was June 11th, and for the Bella Bella and the Bella Coola pupils on two boats leaving June 30th. The only alternative to accepting these dates was to send the pupils a half-dozen at a time through the month of July and into August, and
Each group would, of course, require to be escorted. I do not see what other alternative was open except to take advantage of the earlier dates open.

We had had a recent school inspection by Mr. Davey, and I immediately arranged to have all class-room tests completed by June 10th, and this was satisfactorily done.

I do not think the suggestion that the pupils could have been returned by August 15th would have met with any appreciable response from the parents, as many of the older pupils work at fishing and at the canneries until it is time from them to return to school at the end of August. The travelling distances in respect to the Northern group of pupils is so great that it is expedient for all the pupils to return together under escort sent from the school.

I may say that the evacuation of the other pupils proceeded normally, with the exception that the same difficulty of transportation to the Northern coast of Vancouver Island was experienced. The C.P.R. Steamships are only operating one boat on the summer schedule instead of the usual two, and the only date available for pupils was June 13th. Also, some of the local pupils were on their annual trek to the berry farms of the States, and the children of these parents were permitted to accompany the parents when requested. The request was made in only a few instances. Other pupils whose parents had gone to the States arranged to meet the pupils who were later escorted to Victoria, en-route to the States.

I may say that I have been assured by the Union Steamships that such circumstance will not occur again, and I trust that the present circumstance, which was undoubtedly beyond my control, will be overlooked.

Just yesterday I met Rev. Father Mulvihill, of the Kekawis School, and he enquired as to the above matter of vacation dates. He said that some of the parents of his pupils had complained that the Alberni pupils were given longer vacations this year. He thought that it might be possible for his school to close earlier as a regular routine. He expressed himself as perfectly satisfied with the explanation (as above) which I gave him.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

Dear Mr. Neary,

It is a very long time since I wrote to you. I had not anything very particular to trouble you about, but I yearned to tell you what I thought about the Indian affairs of the spring.... Fancy Guy Williams, whom I know personally very well, who is a clever boy, but not a good boy and who knows no more about religion of any sort that the man in the moon, standing up to represent the 'unattached Indians of BC', so many of whom are real Catholics....nothing could be more cynical.....

As for the 'Native Brotherhood' and their brief, it was just a hole and corner affair managed very well by Mr. Kelly.....most of the officers did not know what was in it until it appeared.....nothing could be more 'democratic'........

One of the prominent members of the organisation, a Catholic 'of sorts', told me that he agreed to no religious teaching in the schools, not that he was against it at all, of course he wasn't, but that he wanted to give the priests and Sisters a jolt....which of course they need........

Most of the officers of the Brotherhood, whom I have met recently have been very apologetic about the brief, explaining everything in the finest fashion. There is a very real danger of Communist penetration among them, I have this on the very best authority........

In spite of the fact that I have read Hansard through I have been feeling very worried about the outcome of things, but I was quite a little relieved when I saw your appointment in the paper the other day.....all my prayers and congratulations go with you.
If it would not worry you too much to give me a few remarks about the general situation, I should be most grateful.

Now I have something I should like to have your advice about. Josephine Hazel Tait...age 9.....daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Tait of Cloose, V.I., a baptized Catholic has been admitted to the ex-methodist school at Alberni. Mrs. Tait is a Catholic and was married in the Church to her husband a non-Catholic.

The mother allowed the child to go to Alberni, partly because she did not realise all that was involved, partly because the half brother, a non-Catholic was going there. Mrs. Tait is very anxious that Josephine should be transferred to Christie School.......'Quid faciendum'.....I did not mention the matter to Mr. Tait, but of course he has made the promises'........

I shall not speak to the Agent until I hear from you. Unless I am much mistaken, he is a very wooden gentleman. Of course you may be sure that your confidence will be respected.

Imagine the hullabaloo if a Catholic school had a corresponding protestant.....

A letter would catch me at the following address:
Convent of the Sacred Heart, Point Grey, Vancouver, B.C.

The new Bishop has kept me on the same job...so far......What with Indians and whites, I have not much time for joy riding........

Please keep me in your prayers and ask God that I may be able to do something for the Indians before I die. Personally I should like to retire to a reserve and try my hand there.....May be I should be a dreadful failure. Actually I am on my way to visit Nootka and Christie School.

Very sincerely yours,

J.H. Bradley.
Ottawa, November 29, 1947.

Dear Father Bradley:

I have for answer your letter of November 9. Having been present for practically all of the briefs presented to the Parliamentary Committee, I feel that the men selected for the Committee are really very industrious and sincere in their efforts to improve the lot of these native people. Some of the presentations, of course, have been rather radical and some indeed very impracticable. However, I feel confident that the members of the Committee will be able to sift the grain from the chaff and arrive at a suitable revision for the Indian Act. Insofar as Indian Education is concerned, a great deal has transpired that of course does not appear in the published proceedings. This Sub-committee has yet to make its report to the Committee, and I hope that their deliberations will prove satisfactory to those most interested in Indian education.

The delay in answering your latter has been due to the fact that we have had to dig back into our files concerning the Tate children. There has also been some confusion because we have a family of Tate children also attending the Alberni Residential School. The application form for Josephine Tate states that she is the daughter of Henry Tate and Jane Bob; that she was born on October 15, 1938; and that the religion is United Church of Canada.

Therefore she was admitted to the Alberni residential school. As you are probably aware from previous rulings, the Department of Justice has decided that the father of the child is the one who will decide the religion in which the child should be reared. This has led to many controversies with regard to the

Reverend Father J. L. Bradley,
Convent of the Sacred Heart,
Point Grey, Vancouver, B. C.
admission of children to our residential schools and we have many voluminous files dealing with such cases. Your remarks concerning the Hullabaloo if a Catholic school had a corresponding Protestant ...... is pertinent; for we have had several such cases. The main point is whether Mr. Henry Tate is the father of this child. You make a statement concerning a half-brother who is also attending the residential school, which would indicate the possibility that Josephine is not the daughter of Henry Tate. However, I will expect to hear further from you, clarifying this particular point - which, as you can see, is most important.

I sincerely appreciate your congratulations and good wishes upon my appointment and I sincerely hope that I will be able to fulfill your expectations of me in this position.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Mr. N. W. Garrard, Indian agent at Alberni, B. C. has returned Application for Admission for Frank Geddes Wilson and your request for information as to why institutional care is required for this child since both his parents are living and the day school is in operation at Kitamaat.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wilson have seven children of which Frank Geddes is the only one of school age. Four are past school age and two younger ones have not yet attended school. Since they spend a great deal of their time away from the village at Butedale Cannery, this child has not had much opportunity to attend school. He was living at Kitamaat with his grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. John Bolton who are not able to give the child proper care and whose house was in such a delapidated condition that it is now being torn down and a new one built for them.

It will be appreciated if you would re-consider this child's application and the form is returned herewith.

for, I. P. Pruden,

Dear Father Bradley:

Your letter of March 6th was waiting for me when I returned from a recent inspection trip.

We have also been advised by Mr. Carrard our Indian Agent at Alberni that the father of Josephine Tate had her baptized in the United Church as he desired that she be raised as a member of the United Church and attend the Alberni Residential School.

Unfortunately, Father Bradley, we have had other instances of a similar nature in which "the boot has been on the Catholic foot" and we have always had to abide by the Department of Justice ruling to the effect that the father can decide the denomination in which he wishes the child concerned to be raised.

I regret very much I have been unable to give you any satisfaction in this instance but the Indian Act as interpreted by the Department of Justice leaves no alternative.

Very sincerely yours,

1937.

Josephine was born on Oct. 15, 1938 at St. Joseph's Hospital, Victoria and baptized by the priest there. Dear Mr. Neary,

The greater proportion of the pupils of this school require to be transported to their homes by steamer; to Bella Bella, Bella Coola, Kitimat, the Skeena and the Nass Rivers and Prince Rupert and inland points to Hazleton by the Union Steamships, Ltd., and to the West Coast of Vancouver Island by C.P.R. Steamships.

The Steamship Companies have always been very considerate in providing accommodation, but, owing to the heavy passenger traffic at the end of June caused by staff going out to the coast canneries and the fisheries, there is great difficulty in fixing dates that coincide with the regulation closing of the school. Transportation of the Alert Bay pupils by the Union Steamships also complicates the arrangements.

I have had the application for transport with the Union Steamships this year since March 1st, and have just received the sailing dates on which the pupils can be accommodated. There will be two trips on the inner coast, one on June 23rd, from Campbell River (on Vancouver Island) to Prince Rupert, and the other on June 25th, from Campbell River to Bella Coola. This will necessitate concluding our classes a few days earlier than the scheduled date of June 25th. Last year, owing to particular congestion of traffic on the Union Steamships line, accommodation had to be taken on June 11th, with the alternative of transporting the pupils in small parties during July and August. This caused an enquiry from the Kakawis School, which school has not the same transportation difficulties, as to whether Kakawis could get permission to close early also. I am glad to say that this was explained and the explanation accepted by the Principal of the Kakawis School at that time.

May I request the sanction of the Department in accepting the above dates for the transportation of the pupils this year?

Yours very truly,

Florence (Bonnie) and William Herbert Carpenter - These children are now motherless and the father finds it rather hard to look after his large family and work at the same time. They will have better care in residential school than at home in the village.

Johnny Benson White - although this child's parents are a good type of people there is rather a heavy load of unfortunate relatives living in the home including two sub-normals. It was therefore thought wise to give this boy a better environment for a year or two.

W.P. Pruden,
Indian Agent.
